description:
My husband and I were desperately craving authentic sushi, after being in Norway for 6 months where all they have are $15 salmon rolls. We saw that Wayo was right down the street from our hotel, and decided to walk down. 

We were pleasantly surprised by how warm and inviting the space was, especially with it being right on noisy/busy Van Ness.  The staff were super polite, and you could tell right off the bat that the Itamae was old-school - super quiet, and always working on his craft. I knew I was about to get some quality stuff. 

I ordered Seaweed Salad for an appetizer (my husband hates it, so I got it all to myself), then we ordered Unagi Maki, Spicy Tuna, and Salmon roll (yes, my Norwegian husband got salmon because he was scared of everything else)  

Suffice it to say, the food was delicious, the waiter was polite & attentive, and authentic sushi bar was a great aesthetic touch. Will be going there again!
author: Zelma S.

description:
Came to Wayo because it didn't have a line or a wait time. Honestly a decent little sushi joint, totally worth skipping long lines for. I give it 3.5 stars.

I would like to start off by saying the sashimi is top notch, especially the albacore (we also got salmon). The pieces were perfectly cut, the taste was delectable. Some of the best sashimi I've had, I highly recommend it here. Everything else we ordered was pretty good... alright. We had a few rolls, with the dynamite roll probably being my favorite. Honestly it was a little surprising to me the contrast between the taste of the sashimi versus the rolls. I wonder if maybe the recipe for the rice needs altering (since they say the rice makes the roll!). Overall though, the food was decent. I've had better rolls elsewhere but again, with the wait times being insane at most other places in the area, the quality of these rolls suffices. 

The place itself is quite small. There are just a handful of tables and seating around the sushi bar. I would not come here with a large group, unfortunately. But with a small group of friends this place is perfect. We got a fantastic spot in the corner by the window. It was nice to look outside and people watch while hanging with friends.

Overall, Wayo is a pretty good sushi spot. I appreciated the lack of wait time and amazing sashimi. I would like to go back and try the rolls again to see if anything changes (I'll update you all when I do!).
author: Camille G.

description:
There's this type of relaxed, cozy, non-pretentious atmosphere about this small Japanese restaurant that I really do enjoy, and after a long day at work, these mellow type of establishments are precisely what I tend to aim for. No frills, dim lighting, and just the bar table separating me and the chef. 

I started off with a round of sake to get my tastebuds rolling. 

Here's my order:

Edamame - Pretty standard and not much to actually write home about, but I enjoy ordering these as an appetizer to suffice the munchies. Boiled and perfectly salted. 

Mango Crab Salad - I didn't know what to expect when ordering this, whether I would get real crab or imitation, but it just so happened that this came out with the real deal, albeit frozen. The crab texture wasn't too bad and I was surprised that it wasn't even stringy; quite pleasant. The mango was wonderfully sweet and at the perfect point of ripeness. All this was served over a bed of lettuce. Really light and flavorful. 

Hiyayakko - Contrasting Agedashi Tofu, Hiyayakko is served cold and slightly swimming in a light soy dressing. Topped with sliced scallions, bonito, and a hint of ginger, this refreshing dish can get quite addicting. 

Salmon Salad - This dish looks unassuming and plain, but I'd say that this was probably one of my favorites as a starter. Fresh salmon slices with lettuce and simply dressed with a ponzu vinaigrette; this was definitely one that yielded brightness and crisp texture. Great starter. 

Amaebi - I'm super picky about my raw shrimp preparations. My 2 criterias are that it better be plump and it better exude the natural sweetness. Here, I can tell it's completely fresh. The only slight let down is that I wasn't given the shrimp heads alongside, but I figure that's only from restaurant to restaurant. 

Tobiko - Delightfully sweet and salty. These were done with great deft. Usually at other restaurants, it only highlights the saltiness. 

Unagi - It's pretty hard to screw unagi up. This dish was equally great and on par with other surrounding Japanese restaurants. Yum!

Hotate - Silky and fresh, these scallops were clean and slightly sweet. Mmm so good. 

Sake - Fresh and perfectly cut. Very enjoyable. 

Ebi - Tasty cooked shrimp served cold. Good complimenting nigiri to the table. 

Maguro - Fresh tasting and with great texture. I love when tuna is slightly firm, yet still provides a soft clean bite. 

I've had super duper high quality omakases before and there's really no comparison, but with that said, considering how service was incredibly attentive and the given freshness aligned to pricing, this place is awesome. Although there were only 2 people handling the entire restaurant and with maybe around 8-10 patrons, the food came out quick and water glasses were promptly filled each time. 

Great neighborhood restaurant. Kudos to this wonderful mom and pop shop!

Oh and keep in mind that parking can be limited. Located on busy Van Ness along with crazy construction.
author: Ann S.

description:
I feel quite blessed to be  living so close to both Akira and Wayo. Wayo does not have a very extensive menu. Also the restaurant is run by one waitress and one chef and so the wait can be long... however, the food is great! Wayo only offers a small sushi selection but the sushi is excellently prepared. The sushi rice is perfect in flavor and texture. Also, the fish is some of the freshest and most delicious fish I have had at a non super high end restaurant. The best fishes in my opinion are the uni and hamachi. Both are so ridiculously good! The  chef's choice is also fairly affordable for the amount of food (I believe miso soup, salad, a tuna roll, and 7 pieces of nigiri.) I usually get that and an order or uni. 

All in all, I would recommend Wayo if you are in the area. The place is not super fancy but it's good and low key. Definitely lucky to have it close by!
author: Jocelyn K.

description: Came here for dinner on a double date. The restaurant is managed by, I'm assuming, a couple. So if it gets busy, be prepared to wait for your rolls. For the city, the rolls and sashimi are priced at the lower end. Everything is fresh, tasty, and made to order! Good service and I'd definitely come back.
author: Jerrica N.

description:
It always surprises me when I noticed I haven't reviewed one of my favorite places.

It was about 5 years ago when we tried eating here. Someone have rave reviews for this place and we decided to check it out. But the chef told us it was an hour wait. Me being hangry, we went somewhere else.

The place is pretty small. Don't expect to have a large party to be able to be seated together. I made that mistake but it turned out okay.

I finally started coming in about a year ago, and it's been my go to sushi place ever since. In fact, I recommend it to about everyone I meet in the city.

You can't go wrong with anything you order from here. Because everything is made with the most priceless ingredient, love. Aside from the tea and sake being nuked in the microwave, this place is exceptional! And y'all know how I feel about places with microwaves. Lol.

The chef carefully prepares the entire tables menu. So it takes time and he does it with care and preciseness. My favorite things to have here are the smashing and I always have it with a roll. 

The prices are surprisingly not expensive. I literally come here every couple of months. It's always a joy to eat here.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Just tried "Spicy Tuna Salad". Excellent! Healthy and perfect complement to beer!!
Also a great laidback place where a woman can visit alone. There were 4  ladies enjoying sushi at the counter by themselves when I went there.
author: Misako G.

description:
One Friday afternoon, I was on the 47/49 bus going towards the Regency Ballroom for a conference site visit, when I passed Tommy's Joynt and thought, "Mmmm that sounds like an amazing place to eat lunch." Then the bus kept going, and I totally forgot to get off. Fortunately I discovered Wayo Sushi just down the block from the Regency and decided to stop in here for a quick bite.

Good job, Stefanie. Solid choice. It's a tiny place that's open for lunch from noon until 1:30 PM and it's not busy at all. There's one sushi chef and one woman handling all the customer interactions. There's bar seating that wraps around most of the restaurant, as well as tables below for bigger groups. I sat at the bar and ordered the dynamite roll. 

The sushi made here is so simple and tasty. Whenever I have a dynamite roll, it's baked in some day and drenched with sauce. The sushi chef here emphasizes the freshness of ingredients inside the roll and allows customers to add flavor with the usual wasabi and soy sauce. Refreshing, for lack of a better adjective. As I finished up my first roll, I ordered the spicy salmon skin roll. The salmon was baked in foil and spread across the roll. Amazing!

In total, I spent around $19 inclusive for my lunch. It was such a peaceful and lovely experience. The two individuals that work here are so respectful and customer service oriented. I heard it gets crowded during dinner, so I'm glad that they bring in good business! I wouldn't want to wait to eat here, but now I know that lunchtime is the perfect time to visit.
author: Stefanie C.

description: Was nervous eating here because it was empty but decided to give it a shot because it was a late afternoon on a Tuesday so figured it could be that. Service was terrible and food was bleh.
author: Mandie C.

description: One of the best sushi I've ever had. Although nothing fancy, but authentic and standard, fresh fish, cozy store. Highly recommend sweet shrimp and sea urchin sushi, salmon sashimi, dragon rolls with eel. Some fish for sushi are little bit cold. But nothing bad
author: Daniel W.

description:
First time in here and forgot to check yelp reviews first. But I scored, it was all so delicious. 
It is a one woman and one man show. So it took a little while to get order. But it was well worth it. 

Had edamame- good

Saba Maki( Mackerel) very good
Hamachi Maki (yellow tail) very good 

Tiger roll (yellowtail with teriyaki sauce) it was the best. 

It wasn't very busy but it was 1:30 in the afternoon.
author: Jim R.

description:
This was my favorite little mom & pop sushi spot in SF. When I say little, I mean little! Blink and you might miss their tiny place on Van Ness. What they lack in size, however, they make up for in quality and heart. Wayo is run by what I assume to be a couple - the husband makes each and every piece by hand himself, while the wife waits on customers. Expect a wait because of this, but they'll let you know as soon as you walk in how long you can expect to wait for your food. It's typically 30-45 minutes, but I never had a problem relaxing and waiting in this quaint little spot with some hot sake. 
They don't have the largest variety of rolls - if you're in the market for a wide range of specialty rolls, then this probably isn't your spot. However, they do have all the classics and a specials board (it never changes) that features a variety of rolls with mango that are all delicious. The fish is high quality, and the craft that goes into their food makes me really appreciate this spot. Though their menu lacks a little diversity, the food and atmosphere is far from generic. 
I'd recommend trying it at least once!
author: Traci A.

description:
The perfect little sushi bar - the chef was incredibly attentive to each step in his process, the waitress was kind and the meal was delicious. 

We had a totally yummy mango salmon roll (special item in the white board - try it if you can!), a chef's special, mackerel sashimi (my favorite!), a side of rice and hot sake - ~$60 for two. 

Look forward to making this a regular place!
author: Celina T.

description:
5 stars for the food. I've eaten my fair share of sushi over the years, from the cheap $2.25/plate to fish that's flown in from Japan daily. Wayo Sushi's fish is up there on my list. The chef takes great care in preparing each piece. For example, I and my friends ordered eel nigiri (for me) and a roll with eel in it (for my friend); the chef put each individual piece in the oven one by one.

Before coming here, I read the Yelp reviews, and yes, it IS a small establishment, consisting of one chef and one waitress. Be prepared to be patient and wait for your food. We arrived ~12:15-12:30PM. With four of us ordering something to-go, and only 1 person ahead of us, the next party that stepped into the restaurant was told that it'd be a 45 minute wait.

I ordered the lunch combo (~$18), consisting of miso soup, salad, and 10 pieces (6 pieces of California roll, 1 eel nigiri, 1 salmon nigiri, 1 yellowtail nigiri, and 1 tuna nigiri). Small curls of green onion were plentiful in the soup, which I liked. The California roll uses real crab meat instead of the fake 'krab' kind, so I was pleasantly surprised. The eel was so fatty, buttery, soft, and delicious! The salmon looked so fresh, and the slice was hefty. My friend commented that it's difficult to make the rice just right, and so she was impressed with the chef's skills.

Yes, the prices are a little pricey, but then again, the restaurant is on Van Ness, so when you factor in the rent and the fish and level of detail that the chef puts into his food, I think it's kinda reasonable (just not an everyday meal for me).
author: Dana L.

description: Small sushi joint with a pretty limited menu, but probably the best priced place for the quality in the area. I came here on a friday right as it opened, and we were able to snag a table of 3. There isn't much seating, so I would expect a wait if you are more than a group of 2. I ordered the salmon sashimi and the rock 'n roll. It's not the absolute best quality fish, but it's pretty dang good and affordable enough that I wouldn't mind coming here regularly.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
The sushi here is hella good!  I love that it's a little mom and pop shop, with just two people working here.  One waitress, one chef.  They were incredibly nice, but unfortunately because it's just the two of them...there can be a wait for your food.  Good thing for us, we got there early and totally beat the crowd.  As we were eating dinner we heard them tell people it could be a 1.5 hour wait (on a Friday night).

For 3 people, we each ordered 3 kinds of sushi, I got unagi, mango salmon, and salmon skin roll.  The presentation was adorbs, it came out on a sushi boat.  We were all really full and our bill wasn't even too bad.  Come here but just be patient.  It's worth the wait.
author: Lyn C.

description:
You can tell they really care about each piece of sushi they make, but I wasn't "wowed" by anything  I ate.

The nigiri was superb, but the rolls were a little lacking. Especially for the price.

3 stars for the food, 5 stars for the service- I'll settle on 4!
author: Omri G.

description: A small, no frills, sushi joint. It's run by 2 people so might not be ideal during rush hour. I ordered 6 assorted sashimi pieces for $15 and and a spicy salmon skin roll for $7. The sashimi was really fresh and their green tea was delicious. The salmon skin roll was a little dry. I didn't order the tempura but I could see that it was being microwaved and not made fresh. A good and safe spot to eat at if you order sashimi and rolls that requires fresh fish. Also, you can request them to substitute the white rice for brown rice, something that I haven't come across in most sushi restaurants in SF.
author: Ridhi S.

description:
Was looking for some Japanese food for dinner when a friend suggested Wayo. Hey, it's got some good reviews and you're a trusted friend source. Why not?! Let's give it a go!

They open at 6pm for dinner, so we ended up walking around the area until they opened. Once inside, there were a few tables and a bar that surrounded the sushi chef. Most of the patrons that ended up walking in decided to sit at the bar. We chose to sit at the tables to give ourselves more room.

I was pleasantly surprised that we ordered 4 rolls or so and it filled us right up for dinner! Better yet, it was so affordable! I was caught off-guard as to how inexpensive dinner was. Probably could've ordered a few more rolls if you know what I mean. Given there was only one chef preparing all the food, it can take a while to get your food served to you if there are a lot of people dining at once. So if you decide to order a second round later, make sure you're ready to wait around for it to be prepared. We ordered everything we were planning to eat at the beginning, so we were quite satisfied.

Quality of the fish was great. Wish the shrimp tempura in one of the rolls was crunchier? Tasted a bit soggy - not sure if that was because of the sauce or not. I recommend ordering what catches your eye or stick to your favorites.

PARKING: I'd say probably relatively easy to find street parking on a good time/day? Street parking is metered, free starting after 6pm.
author: Wing L.

description: Like others have stated you have to get here early for dinner otherwise you will have to wait a long time before you get your food. They only have one sushi chef and one server to serve the entire place. The fish is very fresh and well prepared. The portions are reasonable for what you pay and it is definitely worth a try.
author: Andrew P.

description:
Wayo Sushi was my wife and I's secret little spot when we lived in Lower Pac Heights for 4 years. We'd go on weeknights, after a movie, random Saturday's. It's tiny and it's sort of hit or miss on whether they'll be super busy. It's a husband and wife I believe that own it and they're the only staff too. My suggestion when you order, order big! Get it all in, because it just takes time when you have 1 chef and 1 server. 

Anyway, why do I love this place? There are plenty of great sushi spots in SF. Well, maybe it's because this place is just so damn unpretentious. All they care about is serving, simple, very fresh fish and at affordable prices to boot. We always start with their homemade miso soup and edamame, which is perfectly salted. Then we just go home on sashimi and nigiri, split a large Sapporo and get one of the "special rolls" - hint they're on the whiteboard behind you near the front door. Btw, we moved away to New York for 4 years and recently came back, hence my review, and the specials are still the same. Ha - but they are very good. Any of the rolls with Mango are insane, can't go wrong. Now that we're in Marin, it seems even more of a treat when we get a chance to visit. We come to the city often, but of course we always want to try something new, visit with friends, etc. but I think we'll be coming back here for as long as they stay open.

Final note - I don't think we ever sat anywhere else, only the Sushi bar, but that's what we both prefer in general. It's amazing watching this one-man show at his craft. I wish I knew the owner's names, but if you two are reading this - we just want to say thank you for the great sushi and fond memories!
author: Nate E.

description:
This isn't my favorite sushi spot in SF, but it's special and worth a visit. A small place: three to four sit-down tables and sixteenish bar stools in a U-shape around the workspace. No frills---it's clean and modestly decorated. Wouldn't recommend for larger groups. Good for a solo night out, or maybe a casual date.

Other reviews have suggested that it's inexpensive relative to nearby places---it's not, it's comparable. Portions are on the smaller side. The fish-to-rice ratio seems average, there are other spots in town that are a bit more generous.

The food is undeniably fresh and delicious.

If you arrive 10 minutes after the doors open and more than two other parties are ahead of you, you'll be warned that your order will take 40 minutes.

This is what makes it special. In a city full of restaurants trying to be cool, Wayo beats to its own drum. There are just two people running the show here---the chef and the waitress. Somehow they manage to keep up with orders and tend to customers in a timely manner. It's fun to watch them multitask. When you're served your food, it feels very personal---they did this for you.

About timing---I started with two items, ordered two more, and was out of there within an hour. Perhaps the 40-minute warning is to keep expectations at bay. Get there when they open and you'll have a great time.
author: Ian M.

description:
At the risk of revealing my favorite SF sushi joint, I am writing this review...

- Price is right
- No frills authentic sushi
- Expect to wait 30-45min+ for your sushi but well worth the wait
- Intimate atmosphere
author: Ben M.

description: My girlfriend and I just flew in from ny and were  starving.  After checking into our hotel we checked good ol Yelp to see where to eat and we're pleased to find this just down the block.   This is a small and intimate sushi spot with one host/waitress and one sushi chef.  It may take awhile to get your food if it's packed but we got to sit by the bar and watch him prepare our food.     Our food was tasty and fresh.   They can also do To go if you'd like
author: Are J.

description:
Quite possibly the freshest sushi I've ever had. As a child, I used to go fishing for king salmon in Alaska with my grandpa. He would clean the fish on the spot and cut a few pieces away and we'd eat them raw... My first experiences with "sushi". Wayo's salmon reminded me of my grandpa's and that's saying something. Their rice is somehow also superior to other sushi places.

Wayo is small with one chef so it takes awhile to get your food, but it's worth the wait.
author: Justin J.

description:
Went here to eat with a friend. There is only chef when I went there so our food takes a while to serve. We order cucumber salad with octopus, dynamite roll, salmon maki, and snow leopard roll.  

The cucumber salad with octopus : taste is pretty good, though the serving is small. The salad is sweet and sour ( contain vinegar ) ;  the octopus is fresh. 

Dynamite roll : its good. The spiciness give the roll a kick. 

Salmon maki : Average. Plain salmon, white rice, wrapped in seaweed with a bit of wasabi.

Snow leopard roll : The ponzu sauce is sour with a hint of citrus. Taste almost like the salmon maki 

Overall, it's a good place to eat, the service is good and the food is average.
author: Elitè T.

description: Every time I'm on van ness and craving for sushi .. Wayo is where I go . The fish are always fresh and the rolls are delicious. The best part is there's always parking.
author: Larry L.

description: Wayo Sushi is tiny, providing an intimate dining experience with excellent sushi and great service. My boyfriend, his business partner, and I arrived for dinner and were warned about the possible wait, since there was only one itamae preparing everyone's sushi. We were seated at the bar, which I recommend, because you can watch the sushi being prepared - dinner and a show! There was a large party that had ordered ahead of us, but we didn't mind the wait. The server was friendly and kept our waters filled. The quality of the fish was great, and we left with happy bellies. The best part is that the meal didn't break the bank - the prices of our sushi rolls were extremely reasonable.
author: Sarah B.

description: Wow, I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet! Wayo is one of the handful authentic Japanese sushi places in SF. Two Japanese folks run it and serve all the food, it's just the two of them every single night! I love that! And the sushi is so buttery and fresh, just lovely fish that reminds me of sushi in Japan. If you go, expect a wait around dinner - but don't leave it's so worth it, this will become your new go-to place.
author: Anca R.

description:
This is like stepping into a sushi place in Japan. Excellent sushi and great "Mom and Pop" feel. 
Not a chain. Small space with few tables. We sat at the sushi counter and the main person came right to us and got our drink order then was back to make our sushi. The small space and close quarters with a great, focused eye for quality and presentation, again, felt like I was in Japan. I highly recommend.
author: Deg P.

description: We went here earlier this week and, even though they were officially closed already, they still let us in. There's only one sushi chef and he prepares it fresh, right in front of you, which is really cool. The sushi was amazing, so we went back today and ordered a whole bunch of sushi and got a boat! Again, we were not disappointed. We were informed when we entered that it would take about 45 minutes for the sushi to be prepared. For us, this was no problem, especially as we ordered miso soup as appetizer. Definitely would recommend this restaurant.
author: Leo V.

description: I almost don't want to leave this review because I don't want Wayo to be more crowded. This place is great! They have a simple menu, the fish is always fresh, the pieces are very reasonable, and the owners are wonderful. I love uni! They always have it and it is always good!
author: J. L.

description: Great little "hole in the wall" local spot. It can sometimes take a bit for your order to come only because it seems to be family run and they have one sushi chef accommodating everyone. All the rolls here are very basic and good. The fish is always fresh. The prices are amazing. One of our new favorite spots.
author: mackenzie e.

description:
Love, love, love Wayo Sushi!
Always fresh and tasty - it's a small place so tables of 4 or less are cool. Sapporo beer is always cold. Can't go wrong.
author: Delta M.

description:
Came in on a Monday night around 8pm and was able to get a few seats at the bar with no wait.  There was only one chef working and they warned me that it would be 30 minutes prep time.  I really appreciated the concern but wasn't in a hurry.  It's a pretty small place and had basic decorations neither good nor bad.  I barely remember them, but I do remember the food.  

I sat in front of the sushi chef and watched him work.  He paid close attention to what he was doing and took care with each dish.  I ordered an off the menu chirashi as I usually do a sushi bar.  It included a miso soup which was good. Nothing out of this world but I was happy to have it.  The chirashi had 8 well sized pieces of sashimi that were all well cut and good quality fish.  The rice was excellent, good firmness and flavor.  

The hot sake came out super hot.  The service was great and for $30 this was a great value.  Well done!
author: Scott M.

description:
Nice spot with fresh, tasty sushi at decent prices. I wouldn't come here if you're super hungry since the rolls and sushi pieces are quite small, but the atmosphere is great and cozy.

The rolls were delicious, even though it did take a long time for them to be made (and we got there right when they opened). A couple walked in whrn the restaurant was only half full and were told that the sushi would take 40 min to make. Really strange.

But like I said, the food was great and the price was right. I'd come back for sure.
author: Lee L.

description: No frills great sushi at a great price. I mean, really almost perfect. Also it was quiet and only a few tables, we loved it.
author: Claire L.

description: Popped into this place the other night and went two nights in a row, really good sushi! I was quite surprised, really small place with one sushi chef. The nigiri was awesome especially the scallop and the sunomono salad had real fresh crab in it, loved it. A great find on Van Ness.
author: Susan F.

description: I started coming to Wayo in 2014 as it was in the neighborhood I first moved to in SF. I didn't realize that 4 years later, it would start off as and continue to be the best sushi in San Francisco. The husband-wife team are excellent on the service side and the quality, presentation, and precision of the food is unmatched. They could double prices and I'd still come here/rate it best. I have sent countless friends here for dates, not a good group place, and no one has been disappointed. If there are a few people in the restaurant, the waitress will tell you it will be 45 minutes or more for sushi. In fact, even if you are first in line when they open it will usually be 30-40 minutes before you get the main portion of your meal. While waiting order a drink and a side, good things are worth waiting for. As long as this place is open, we will come back.
author: Michael G.

description: Excellent sushi. The best neighborhood sushi spot along the Van Ness corridor.
author: James G.

description:
High quality sushi and great ambiance. The place definitely reminds me of a restaurant straight out of Japan. 

Luckily we came here when the Warriors game was going on so they were almost empty (great time to try out restaurants with long waits!). My friend and I were actually the only 2 people in the restaurant at one point. The waitress and chef were both so friendly and very attentive! It was fun to watch the chef carefully make the sushi from the sushi bar.

The menu is pretty simple they don't have too many of those crazy combinations which seems more authentic. I ordered 3 rolls for $5 each - salmon, tuna, unagi (eel). They were all so noticeably fresh! My friend got the salmon salad for $8. I think the prices were very reasonable considering the quality. Although I still didn't feel full after 3 rolls.

I was surprised that the tuna roll had wasabi inside while the other 2 rolls I ordered didn't. Make sure you mention to not add it if you don't like wasabi! You also have the option to order your roll with brown rice (my friend loved it). Will definitely be back here and recommend to others.
author: Linda X.

description:
Then there is Wayo. When you are in a sushi pinch and don't wish to fork out $100+ (per person) at a high-end sushi bar, it's ok to come here! The downsides are twofold. Firstly, do not expect anything fancy or top notch.  Fish are not purchased from Tsukiji Market. Secondly, you need to have patience or time as the wait can take up to an hour. So do not expect to be fed promptly. Bring a book to read or a friend to shoot the shit.
 
The sushi chef and the server, both Japanese, made up the entire crew. The assortment of fish they carry cannot get any simpler than this. We are getting down to brass tacks in a no frills environment. Wayo reminded me of a sushi restaurant straight out from the 90s that looked like a diner. I was perched precariously on one of those backless stools at the sushi bar. Time seemed to have stood still and so did some of their prices. It was a hole-in-the-wall alright but herein was their old world charm although with none of the remnants of the 90s raucous crowd that used to chase outlandish rolls with sake bombs!

When I say brass tacks, I was referring to the run-of-the-mill maguro ($5), hamachi ($5), shake ($5), ebi ($4), ika ($4). tako ($4) and the like.  Don't get me wrong! The sushi was not inedible albeit lackluster. Didn't I say it would be a good place to come when you are in a pinch? The priciest nigiri sushi was amaebi ($7), ikura ($6) and uni ($7). I was surprised there were no white fish, even like the common hirame (flounder) or tai (sea bream).  Don't even think about hikarimono sushi where the fish has a silvery skin like kohada (gizzard shad), aji (mackerel), iwashi (sardine). The basic yellow fin tuna and hamachi were as expected, middle of the road. There was no question about their freshness only that they got boring after a few pieces. No amaebi heads, no ankimo, no hamachi kama....nada! Sushi rice was fine though not great but with perfect fish to rice ratio. For the health conscious, Wayo offers a brown rice option!

In summing up, Wayo has cheap fresh sushi. A little more variety would be a definite plus. I can see the reason for the long wait. The chef is a tad slow even though he  works his butt off. It may be wise of him, although not necessarily a smart business move, to turn away his customers right off the bat if they can't wait. 
 
Gochisosama deshita (Thanks for the meal!)
author: Geoff G.

description:
We've been here a few times but seem to be striking out lately.

We came on a Thursday evening around 7:45 only to be told that they are running late and sushi won't be served for an hour.  

Same thing happened the last time we came.

I learned calling ahead doesn't help.  I called twice from the road to see what the wait was like but they never picked up the phone. 

I love this 2 person operation and they have fresh fish.  I'll have to try again and maybe come much much earlier.
author: Susan C.

description:
Very impressed by this sushi place. 

Pros:
- Small restaurant with friendly vibe
- Decently priced
- Extremely fresh and high quality fish. Excellent nigiri!
- Interesting specials
- Sushi chef is friendly

Cons:
- If you get there during rush hour (between 1930-2030) it can be up to an hour wait to get your sushi.
- Seating can be an issue if it is busy

Verdict:
Favorite sushi restaurant in San Francisco. Highly recommended.
author: Omar R.

description:
I'm embarrassed, nay, ashamed, that I originally gave Wayo a mere four stars. When we first moved to SF, Wayo was our neighborhood sushi joint and I guess I didn't think much of it because I assumed SF would be teeming with great sushi places. As it turns out, SF may have more expensive sushi restaurants, but we haven't found one that's better.

The sushi at Wayo is ALWAYS perfect. They don't have the rare stuff and they don't have anything particularly fancy, but when it comes to the basics, they do it right. The fish and rice are always the right temperature, nigiri is made with the perfect amount of wasabi, the rolls are incredible (especially the special ones with mango), and the wait is always worth it.
author: Megan B.

description: Priced nicely for quality. Cute cozy spot. Professional and the staff gives a real Japanese culture to the atmosphere. Miso soup was spot on. The roll was delicious and fresh. I'll be back :)
author: L J.

description:
This is a small, no-frills sushi place with great fish. I walked by it probably 20 times before I even noticed it was there, which is often the mark of a good spot. 

When I say it's small, I mean they have maybe five 2-3 person tables and a sushi bar. I came with 4 others and we had to move two tables together. We went around 6:30 on a Thursday and were a few of the only people in there, but it did start to fill up around 7-7:30.

The menu is very simple, but there are plenty of choices as long as you're not looking for anything fancy or over-the-top. We had a few orders of sashimi, which was great, and some basic rolls. The fish was excellent quality, which is the most important thing when it comes to sushi.

As others have said, this place is very minimally staffed. There was only one waitress when we were there, and she seemed very busy even before the place filled up with customers. Because I read the reviews, I expected to spend a while here and planned accordingly. We were in and out in about 90 minutes, but it was fairly empty when we first arrived so things were moving a bit quicker. If you come after 7, I'd recommend setting aside at least 2 hours for dinner.

This place has great sushi and it's worth the wait. Just make sure you're not in a hurry, and you'll enjoy your meal here.
author: Blair H.

description:
~ Boom boom boom, let me hear you say Wayo ~

I've walked by dozens of times and looked at the sign and just said to myself, "wayooooo," but today I finally went and had lunch. Very glad I did.

The restaurant has a really endearing layout with a small number of tables and a slim winding sushi bar, unpretentious and very clean. The quality of the fish was excellent, especially given the price point and portion size. There was a bit of a wait from the lunch rush, but I was just humming that Wayo song the whole time anyway. Pay them a visit, I'm really glad I did.

Atmosphere: 
- So a diner walked into a sushi bar

Try: 
- I was surprised how much I liked the hot tea
- Spicy scallop hand roll was A+

Notes:
- Menu says $10 minimum
- Brown rice sushi on request!
- Say Wayo
author: Taylor S.

description:
Very cute and cozy restaurant. As many have mentioned, it is a 1 man sushi chef show, with 1 waitress helping out. They directly tell you it takes 1 hour for the food to come to ensure you are okay with it. So we got a couple rolls (snow leopard, alaska, and dragon), as well as salmon and scallop nigiri. We indeed waited for awhile, though it felt more like 40m than 1 hour.

In short, the sushi was nothing special. The chef put too much wasabi on the nigiri pieces, and the rolls had little flavor and too much rice. I am surprised people recommended the snow leopard, it was probably the worst roll out of the three we ordered. It ended up being about $20 per person, not expensive but I can get the same quality sushi for cheaper at Nara Sushi on Polk St that takes less than 10m to prepare even on busy nights. 

The service and ambience were great, but I don't think we'll be coming back again.
author: Elisa L.

description: Great sushi, run by just two people. You might have to wait for a bit if the sushi queue gets too long, but it's worth it.
author: Damien B.

description: Do these people ever answer their phone? I've call 4 times in the last 24 hours during the posted business hours. Unbelievable.
author: Ben T.

description: This is not a spot I would go out of my way for. But, it is everything I can ask for from a neighborhood restaurant. The food is simple, fresh and made with care. The décor is humbly quaint. And the service is always honest, sincere, and respectful.
author: Warren T.

description: My fiancé and I came here at 6:45 on a Saturday night. There were only 2 other tables there when we arrived and we sat right down. The service was friendly and prompt. We couldn't get over how fresh everything tasted. They do not drown your sushi in sauces or extras. They are simple rolls but that's how they should be! We ordered a miso soup, the spicy tuna salad, 2 rolls (spicy tuna and one I can't remember) and and the salmon and tuna nigiri. I would order them all again. Next time we will try the chefs choice! We will definitely be back soon. I have read that you often have to wait a while for your sushi since there is only one chef but I would be more than willing to wait.
author: Emily S.

description:
This is my second time here. I want to say it's a family ma and pa sushi joint, small inside and only 2 workers. The host and the chef. We sat down immediately on a Friday night, and the host said our order will take approximately 45 minutes. (Ouch) But we decided to wait. We sat at the bar and ordered the unfiltered sake, which we both really enjoyed. Since we sat at the bar we could watch the chef make roll after roll after roll, to say the least, the chef himself was on a roll, he wouldn't stop making sushi. And he was calm, cool and collected throughout, as the orders kept coming in. (Pretty cool). I asked to take a picture, which he very politely agreed to. Anyway, approx 45 minutes later our food arrived. It was a beautiful variety of fresh sashimi and delicious! Tasted like, "butta!"  Once the bill came I felt a bit sticker shocked at $90 for 2 of us, but the quality and freshness of the fish was well deserved. We ordered edamame ( it was warm and lightly salted) YUM and 4 sashimi dishes, 1 roll and 2 glasses (each) of sake. Obviously the wait time was a lot and the place wasn't packed, but I give them an extra 1/2 star for being spot on for telling us exactly how long we would have to wait to eat! I would go back and wait again! 

FYI: Parking not the best, since it's on Van Ness. You'll have to circle the block to find street parking.
author: Anie L.

description: Delicious, fresh, quick (on a Thursday evening) and excellent service! Would recommend to anyone looking for sushi in Nob Hill. The house roll is delicious. And get a side of spicy mayo!
author: Nicole H.

description:
Brown rice sushi?!? Yes freakin please!! 

Sushi is my weakness. I crave for it several times a week and I'm constantly having to contain myself and hold back on excess carbs that my body doesn't need. I know that this whole "brown rice" ordeal may be a mental thing, but hey, it works for me! 

Everything was so good! I will definitely be back.
author: M W.

description: Best sushi I have ever had. Uni is on point every time. If they say it will take 45 minutes to be seated, just order some sake and wait.  It will probably be closer to a 25 minute wait.  And, after the time it takes to decide on option "b", which may have a wait also, you'll be kicking yourself.
author: Brian B.

description: Great sushi joint with one sushi chef and one waitress-- the wait for food can be an hour but there's always seating as you wait for your food. Affordable and good quality, although there is no cooked food -- just sashimi, nigiri, rolls. Highly recommend the nigiri and sushi over the special roles, particularly their hotate and amoeba.
author: Shirley L.

description: Best sushi in San Fran in my opinion. Spicy tuna is amazing  we went twice when we were there. I do recommend xoxo
author: Guta P.

description:
I adore this little mom and pop sushi spot.  It's easy to miss if you're passing by, but do yourself a favor and stop in when you're not in a hurry.  There's only one sushi chef and one server there at a time, and they're both very nice and will tell you in advance what the estimated wait time is for your food when they're busy.  The menu focuses mostly on classic rolls with fish and veggies, not a ton of tempura or sauce - I LOVE this.  They also have brown rice rolls available.  Prices are low and reflect the small, simple rolls.  Great quality of fish, made with care.  
I work nearby and have been here a ton of times for lunch and dinner.  It's consistently great and won't break the bank, but be ready to wait a bit.
author: Liz B.

description:
Food: All their rolls and fish were very good and considering the price, they're a steal. You can tell the fish is of good quality. The execution of the rolls was not the best, but in no way affects the taste. 
-Mango salmon roll: Simple but yummy. The mango doesn't overpower the salmon and compliments it well. 
-Sea Fairy Roll: This roll was just okay. Not bad, but if I ever return, I'd probably try something else. 
-Hamachi sashimi: Delicious! 

Service: As others have said, expect to wait. They will be very honest with you. Upon entering, the waitress immediately informed us it would be an hour to get our rolls. The sashimi came out after 40 mins and the rolls came out at exactly an hour. There was one sushi chef and one waitress. We waited for about 15-20 minutes before getting our order taken and water. After that though, the waitress was very attentive. Amazingly, the waitress promptly refilled our waters and brought our check when we were ready. 

Ambiance: Simple and clean. Not good for groups larger than 4; 2 is ideal. 

The sushi here was definitely good quality at a shockingly low price. However, I was not blown away enough to return based on the wait. I didn't ding them a star for the wait because they were very honest about this up front and we willingly waited. The lost star was simply due to the fact that their sushi was yummy, but not 5 star in my opinion.
author: Susan G.

description:
A slew of bad reviews.

The fish wasn't that fresh, small cuts. Two people over worked there. Dinner took longer than 2hours...
author: Ninja R.

description: Super authentic japanese restaurant so don't expect spicy mayo or chicken teriyaki. It is a very small place with one sushi chef and server. We had to wait about an hour for our food because there was only one chef but we didn't mind because we ate a bit before coming. So by the time the food came we were hungry again. The rolls were all really good and the salmon was very fresh. Prices are super reasonable.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
The wait is not fun since there's only one chef (45 minute minimum) but the sushi was pretty good.  Good quality fish and the appetizers were yummy.  We had the tofu, seaweed salad and tuna sashimi salad.  The toro, ebi, spicy tuna roll, hamachi and tako were all good.

I'd definitely come back.
author: Chris L.

description: The sashimi is expensive at $15 for 6 pieces. The quality is decent but not worth the price. The mango and salmon roll had way too much rice and was hard to eat in one bite. The rainbow roll was also mediocre.
author: Beth K.

description:
This place is so cute. I came here before a concert with some friends and we arrive just at opening. With one chef and one waitress, get there early if you want to be able to eat soon after you order. 

We ordered 5 different items: mango and salmon, mango and spicy hamachi, snow leopard, hamachi sashimi, uni, and hotate. The fish overall was so fresh tasting which is great. The hotate (scallops) were delicious. I've never had scallops like that, but so good! The uni was delicious as well. 

I know I see some reviews that say that there's going to be a long wait for food, but I did notice that the ONLY waitress was telling the customers that they would have to wait for food. The sushi was made fresh and that's the best part about it. Only one chef and one waitress doing it all. 

Overall, be the first few to order and you won't have to wait for your food - best policy. Or maybe call in your order if you're getting it to go. 

Protip: get there early and be ready to wait. Uni and scallops are delicious.
author: Nina Y.

description: Hands down a wonderful experience! A bit of a wait but worth it. Fresh sushi and excellent service! Will definately be back!
author: Demetria S.

description:
The sushi chef came to our table and looked at the plate of fish we had ordered that had been sitting on our table for some time, mentioned he gave us the wrong piece of fish, and then took the 'wrong' piece of fish with his bare hands! Was so shocked he picked it up with his hands rather than take the plate back or use chopsticks that I was literally speechless. Also concerned that fish that had been sitting on our table and perhaps touched by our own chopsticks may then be served to someone else. Absolutely disgusting. Previously gave them a two star, but the more I discuss this with friends, feel a one star is the most appropriate review.

Previous review:

I try to avoid ratings lower than three stars, but this place was so extremely disappointing. People trickle in because of the great location, but even with the restaurant only half full there was still a thirty-forty minute wait as there is only one chef and one server. The quality of the fish is not bad. The cut of the fish is inconsistent, with some pieces thicker than others. The rice also did not seem to have the right consistency, which is critical for good sushi. The warm sake tasted of cheap quality. Most disappointing part of the meal was that the sashimi was served on a bed of heavily seasoned lettuce and seaweed. It begged the question of whether the chef knows anything about fish, as the seasoning overpowered (and smothered) the taste of the fish. This was also the first time fried shrimp head was not available with an order of sweet shrimp... probably because they don't have enough people to provide such service. Most surprising part of the meal was when the chef came to our table and removed part of our order with his bare hands because he gave us the wrong piece of fish! Sushi is hand-made, but actually seeing someone physically remove food directly from the plate with their hands was not something one cares to witness. Read less
author: Kimberly H.

description: It's a nice restaurant. Clean and inviting. It's intimate because it's not very big. The waitress and chef are welcoming and friendly.
author: Centeria S.

description:
Man, I think I lost the draft of my original review. :( Need to recreate from memory. Anyways...

Wayo is not near Japan Town but the fish is nevertheless really fresh!

On our first night on the town in SF (Monday) with the wind blowing us around, we seeked refuge in Wayo. The place has some tables and a sushi bar, but space is definitely a premium after 7 pm. We wanted to try a little bit of everything, so we ordered some appetizers, nigiri, and rolls. Here's how it went:

- Snow leopard roll, which has seared albacore and ponzu dipping sauce. Pretty bomb and pretty fresh.
- Hiyayakko, which is cold tofu with green onions, dried bonito flakes and a little bit of ponzu sauce. We added this order last and it was a nice way to end the meal.
- Spicy tuna roll and spicy yellowtail roll. Definitely preferred the spicy tuna roll. Spicy yellowtail was not spicy at all.
- unagi roll. I didn't eat the unagi roll but bf reported it was seared pretty well.
- uni nigiri and salmon nigiri. Uni was super good--one of the best I've tasted. The salmon was pretty fresh too and the slice was pretty generous.

We also got miso soup and salad--forgot which item it came with.

There was only one server and one sushi chef. They got pretty busy so the sushi chef actually delivered two of our orders, which I thought was nice instead of waiting for the server to bring it by since she was slammed. We bussed it to SF so we didn't have to look for street parking. Cards are accepted and I am glad to find a sushi place I liked in SF where we can get quality fish (none of that terikyaki and california rolls nonsense--yay!)!
author: Grace C.

description:
Came here around 5:50 on a Friday for an early dinner; they open at 6. Always good to arrive a little earlier, especially for a small restaurant like this! When I say small, I mean SMALL, you open the door, go up the 3-4 steps and they have regular seating or at the bar, but total the place can probably fit between 10-15 people. 

There's only one waitress and one chef, so again, COME EARLY so you don't have to wait on other tables to get their rolls. Everything is freshly made to order, but be warned that rolls take about 30 - 45 min, but they all come out at once, which is nice. But I can only imagine, if it took my sister and I about 45 minutes to get our food AND we arrived early, how long it would take for them to come out when the place is packed. 

All the rolls were very delicious, my favorites would definitely have to be the salmon skin roll, house roll, and dynamite roll. But, all were very tasty! Although there was only one waitress, she was always refilling waters/tea and making sure everything was good. 

I would definitely come back again and try the other rolls/ appetizers! As for parking, just remember that it is right on Van ness, so anywhere downtown generally doesn't have much, so I would recommend taking the 47/49, super easy, the bus stop is right in front!
author: Carrie L.

description: Outstanding sushi in a city that is full of sushi bars. It is a small mom and pop place, the service is a little slow, and the ambiance is nothing fancy, but the sushi is top notch. His rolls are simple, the portions are perfect, and the fish is of the highest quality. Definitely worth checking out if youre in the neighborhood!
author: Keith H.

description: Please go!  Seriously.  Best sushi I have found in SF area after many years of searching.  And it's so great that only circa 12 people can fit in at a time.
author: Poppy B.

description: Very small but lovely sushi restaurant featuring clean, simple flavors that I highly enjoyed. I had the mango crabmeat roll ($6.00), the snow leopard roll ($6.00) and the Saba (mackerel) Nigiri ($4.00).  All were excellent. Was also very pleased with the prices which seemed extremely reasonable for the quality.
author: M A.

description: The fish had a butter-like texture. A very nice surprise for the price. Spicy tuna was actually spicy. I also ordered a seaweed salad and I appreciated it wasn't drenched in sauce. Perfectly dressed! I sat at the bar and truly enjoyed watching the sushi being made. I was more impressed by only two people running the show. Ambience was a warm hole-in-the wall feel. Service was great! Yes, the wait is a bit longer, but sit back and enjoy a beverage!
author: Sarah O.

description:
A bit hyped up since it is so small and only  has one waitress and chef. 

Small menu, the sashimi only comes in plates of individual types with 6 pieces, would have been nice to have a sampler sashimi platter option.

The fish was fresh, but the rolls, presentation and ambiance was very simple.

Not a bad experience but would definitely try other sushi in the city before returning.
author: Javi Alexa A.

description:
That nearly every bad or mediocre review cites the long wait as justification for their rating while noting THAT THEY WERE TOLD how long it will take tells you something about the people writing them. 

It was a great little restaurant with a waitress who worked hard and a chef who made sushi in the middle of the room the whole time. I don't care why it takes them as long as it did. They can run their business however they want. They were upfront with us, and we decided to stay. They said it would be a 45 minute wait, and it took about 30. But if it took 45, I'd be alright with that, because they told me it would take that long. If it took 50 minutes, I'd be understanding, because it's five minutes. Don't come here if you'll flip out over five minutes.

We drank sake while we waited, enjoyed a conversation, enjoyed watching two people run their business, and enjoyed being in a small room of people doing the same. We also ate edamame. The time flew by. The sushi was awesome. I think you should try it.
author: Zach P.

description: Ordered hotate nigiri, amaebi nigiri, and eel roll. Liked everything. There is only one chef so we waited a bit but it's worth it!
author: Di W.

description:
Wayo is way-overrated.

Think of Wayo as glorified supermarket sushi, and you won't be disappointed.

Flavorless rice, a boring fake crabmeat california roll, and a not so spicy-spicy tuna roll brought me back to my undergraduate days.

This isn't high quality sushi, or even good sushi for that matter.

But, it is filling, probably because their nigiri resembles a Twinkie sized rice portion on top of a relatively small slab of fish.

If you need a quick and inexpensive sushi fix. Like a tourist who doesn't know the lay of the land then...

If it's not out of your way-o...then come here o.
author: Jack R.

description: Really good little sushi bar.  Hours are limited, but man the fish is fresh and you notice that right away.  I had a spicy tuna specialty roll with edamame and it was amazing.  Would definitely hit this spot up again.
author: Bobby R.

description: This was a great neighborhood sushi place. There is one sushi chef so there might be a long wait even if it seems like there's no one in the restaurant.  Prices are great.
author: Tessa C.

description:
This place is the real deal! It felt like a little bit of a long wait for the amount of customers however, once you get your food you will understand. Very simple menu but very well thought out combinations to highlight the flavors. Definitely the best sushi dinner I have ever had. 

one thing that really stood out to me was the spicy variation (spicy tuna or spicy yellowtail) which is typically minced fish with sriracha but not here! they give you a slice of fish with a light dried chili combination that really blew me away. I cannot recommend this place enough
author: Rebecca R.

description:
3.5 STARS

I AM...

Way picky 
Arduous
Yammer
Overcritical 

Even more so with sushi restaurants. It's like the saying, "Once you go black, you never go back." I don't know from experience but the same thing applies, once you've been spoiled with high caliber sushi it's hard to go back to mediocre sushi. 

So why even go to Wayo?

Two reasons: 
1) Cheap Sushi ($80 for two people which is cheap; I normally spend $80-$100/person);
2) You can substitute Brown Rice in any of the rolls and nigiri. 

Wayo Sushi is a hole-in-the-wall, Japanese owned and operated sushi restaurant. It's strictly a sushi restaurant with Salad ($3.50-$9.50), Sashimi ($9-$12), Maki ($3.50-$5.50), Nigiri ($4-$7) and Rolls ($6-$11.50) on the menu. CC's are accepted and there's a $10 minimum per a person. It's relatively small with just 4-5 tables and counter seating. 

Service is already SLOW so if I came on a busy night and had to wait 40 minutes - 1 hour for my sushi (like other Yelpers), my rating would have probably been lower. I know it's a one-man show but so is Ino, Okina, Kiss Seafood, and Tekka and service is much faster there; hence the rounding down on my rating. 

We ordered the following:
*Salmon Sashimi (6 pieces - $12) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/f6G4fFuwx_hQOMxvZPmqjw?select=rOpocpGTCC2J37DuMhma5Q#rOpocpGTCC2J37DuMhma5Q
All the sashimi were PRE-CUT and pulled from a tray (we sat at the counter). I've never seen any sushi bar do this which made me weary. The salmon was silky smooth though and a good value for $2 bucks a pop. 

*Hamachi Sashimi (6 pieces - $12) - 2 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/f6G4fFuwx_hQOMxvZPmqjw?select=rOpocpGTCC2J37DuMhma5Q#UgayRgsyJEhCgCCKUukN5w
Ok so everyone raves about the hamachi here but WHY? Maybe we came on an "off" night but the hamachi had a fishy finish. No bueno. 

*Brown Rice Dynamite Roll w/ Spicy Tuna & Avocado Topped w/ Tobiko ($6) - 3.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/f6G4fFuwx_hQOMxvZPmqjw?select=rOpocpGTCC2J37DuMhma5Q#n_vzb68i1851zE72s4Z1ww
A roll you can feel good about eating, the tuna was nicely firm and the avocado buttery with a nutty flavor from the brown rice. It was a good filler. 

*Brown Rice Dragon Roll w/ Shrimp Tempura Topped w/ Unagi & Avocado ($10.50) - 3 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/f6G4fFuwx_hQOMxvZPmqjw?select=VbdTX3WJ9JLPfRq-btSmTA#Nk1szHk1MAVSrpyRe-SuEg
I'm not a fan of rolls but the Dragon roll is usually another good filler. You can never go wrong with rich eel, fried shrimp, and buttery avocado except I wasn't a fan of this one. The shrimp tempura was previously fried and reheated causing the tempura to be semi-soggy.

*Unagi (Eel- $5) - 3 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/f6G4fFuwx_hQOMxvZPmqjw?select=VbdTX3WJ9JLPfRq-btSmTA#sfpBBv5QMwtiqCjGyKulJA
Unagi is usually rich and fatty, this one was much leaner. Wasn't a fan of the shari (sushi rice) which was too sweet and ruined the integrity of the fish/seafood of all our other nigris as well. 

Kani (Snow Crab - $5.50) - 3 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/f6G4fFuwx_hQOMxvZPmqjw?select=VbdTX3WJ9JLPfRq-btSmTA#7Th_0WrCw8A5GTBTTngnfw
Although the snow crab was tenderly sweet, the sweetness from shari was overwhelming.

*Hotate (Scallop - $5.50) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/f6G4fFuwx_hQOMxvZPmqjw?select=VbdTX3WJ9JLPfRq-btSmTA#Q2MYk5P8cPVK2oaoILibVQ
Plump and meaty with a delicate sweetness. 

Amaebi (Sweet Shrimp - $6) - 2.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/f6G4fFuwx_hQOMxvZPmqjw?select=VbdTX3WJ9JLPfRq-btSmTA#8dbFIVMEcVjtRMevIADY_g
Sweet as it should be but it had a slimy texture. No fried shrimp head was provided. BOO! :(

Uni (Sea Urchin - $7) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/f6G4fFuwx_hQOMxvZPmqjw?select=VbdTX3WJ9JLPfRq-btSmTA#3C3E2WAIotwijEGw-wt-bw
Creamy custard texture with a kiss from the ocean sea taste but once again the shari distracted away from fully enjoying it. 

So this morning, I asked Mr. NSS what he thought about Wayo Sushi...

Him: "It was REALLY good. About the same as Ino..." http://www.yelp.com/biz/ino-sushi-san-francisco#hrid:eMb3QqMXwVRHrlmoF5UlSg
Me *thinking*: "WHAT THE F*CKKK?!?!?...Lay off the booze please!" but what I said, "It wasn't the best quality...as you know, I'm very very very picky with sushi so it's hard to impress me."
Him: "Well, you ARE more refined in your dining experiences and palate."

GOOD ANSWER because someone would have to see his WAYOutta the door IF he had said something else. I'm kidding. I'm not letting this one go...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Fell in love with the simplicity of the place! We came on a Thursday around 8:45pm and it was not packed. So we really came on a good night and had great parking too! Sweet! The menu is not extensive and they do have specials on the wall and tables that are not on the basic menu. I applaud mom and pop establishments because they have to compete against corporate run companies and other places take shortcuts to make profit. This place stays true to what they stand and represent. Yes there are great pros and cons to mom and pop restaurants especially if the only ones employed are the same ones who own the place, but in this economy you do what you can to make your dreams a reality. Now on to the food:

Appetizers:
Miso soup $2
Seaweed salad $4.50

Main:
Hamachi sashimi $12
Sake sashimi $12
Crab cream cheese & avocado brown rice roll $8.50
Dynamite brown rice roll $6
 Everything was so good I wanted more, but I had to maintain to control the mogwai inside.
Service was good and very attentive. It was cute that the owner came out with a big pot of green tea to refill our cups because she is petite.
author: Mary Ann B.

description: Great food, great service. You just need to be patient because there is just one sushi chef and one server for the entire restaurant (it sits ~20 people). If you are a in a rush, this might not be your spot.
author: Javier S.

description:
Well, if you are not in a rush, this is the place for affordable good quality sushi. 

As everyone else mentioned, small operation, usually it is about 30 to 60 minute wait for your sushi, but if you understand and accepted that, it is all good.

Appetizer comes a little bit faster, the only waitress here will keep you hydrated. 

As for the sushi, really yum, all the normal varieties are available here, it is not the most amazing sushi, but it sure is darn good, and you can sub out white rice with brown rice. 

The two of us got a decent amount of sushi and walked out only $60 poorer, didn't order booze though.
author: Alice C.

description:
So far my favorite sushi ever.
I ve been going there since 2008.
The only problem is that it is popular now.
Tip: either you arrive when right when it opens or a good hour later.
author: Stephane R.

description: Go.  If it's a weekend, plan to wait (not to sit down, but to receive your food).  They will tell you up front what the estimated wait time is for your sushi.  It's worth it.  You'll get quality sushi at low prices.
author: Meaghan P.

description:
TLDR: come here if you want a mom and pop feel for Japanese sushi/ are prepared to wait 45 minutes for your food to come out/ want some fresh sashimi

I've never gone into a sushi restaurant in Japan but going into Wayo sushi feels probably like the closest thing. There is only one chef who only speaks Japanese and one waitress, who speaks English. It feels like a very mom and pop shop. When we entered this place, the waitress told us immediately it would take 45 minutes for food. So if you decide to come here be prepared to wait for your food. What's interesting is that all rolls/ makis are just $6 (for 5 or 6 pieces) and nigiri is $7 for two pieces with the exception of items like the rainbow roll which is $11. It's surprisingly cheap so that you can sample a lot but each piece of sushi is small. So don't come here expecting to get full unless you order maybe 4 rolls per person. My friend and I ended up sharing 5 rolls amongst each other. They were really good! The sashimi is warm and so you definitely know it's fresh. It was yum! I don't know what authentic Japanese sushi is but if I had to guess this sushi was pretty close to it. We ordered the hamachi maki, rainbow roll, dynamite roll, snow leopard roll, and some roll with saw on the white board with mango and raw salmon.

They were all great and id recommend the rainbow roll and the hamachi maki.

Tip is that in addition to the main they have some special rolls on a plastic stand on the table and also some things on the white board near the entrance.
author: Derrick C.

description: I enjoyed this place. It's a cute little restaurant with almost a hipster like vibe. There's a bar-like seating and a few tables. I came during lunch with my boyfriend, a little after they opened. There was about 8 people in the restaurant total. The food doesn't come that quickly since only one person was making the sushi. The sushi was pretty good but just average for the price of the sushi. I didn't hate it though. My boyfriend also enjoyed his sushi, and was really proud of himself for picking the place to eat.
author: Shannon C.

description:
My. New. Favorite. Sushi. Place. 

Full disclosure, you will wait for your sushi because there are two people that work here (1 server/waitress and 1 sushi chef).  So don't be a rush and don't be a d*ck about wanting quick in-and-out service, go elsewhere. 

This is the PERFECT place to go for a leisurely meal or go during off hours and it will probably take 15/20 minutes but it is worth the wait!!  The sushi was some of the freshest I have ever had, the fish was cut masterfully, the wasabi was fantastically spicy, and the price point literally can not be beat. 

We started with a bunch of appetizers to hold us over the ~45 minute wait (which we were warned about) for the sushi.  The edamame was warm and salted, the seaweed salad was on point and the cucumber and crab salad was amazingly sweet and tangy (fresh crab!!).  

I ordered the sake sashimi and the hotate nigiri and the BF ordered the mango/spicy tuna roll and the hamachi roll.  The sake was amazing-melted in my mouth and were quite generously cut.  The hotate was also delicious (i gave one piece away and wished I had ordered more).  I tried the mango/spicy tuna roll and it was not diced tuna, but cut and rolled with ripe mangos with a spicy sauce (not mayo based I think).  They also offer brown rice with their rolls, which is an (oddly) rare offering in SF.  

We also had a beer/cold sake and I wish they had more wine (just chardonnay) but I think they may be BYO.. 

LOVE LOVE will be back!
author: Raina D.

description:
This is a pretty atypical sushi place! It's nestled in between neighborhoods on the Van Ness corridor, so it definitely doesn't get much foot traffic - one of those places you always pass by when you're in a car, but never end up trying.

On a Friday night, I expected to have to wait, or at least for the place to be near full capacity, but it was neither! The small restaurant was about half full. Since there was only one sushi chef, we were told we would have to wait for 45 minutes to an hour after ordering for our sushi to come, and that was pretty accurate - we ordered and waited an hour. The sushi itself is a great deal. Most rolls are $6! You get 5-6 pieces per order. And these are the real deal - rolls with salmon, tuna, avocado, and tobiko. They were all pretty good with a good amount of fish given the prices!

There was also only one server, but she was able to work the whole place pretty well. She refilled our water really often. Unfortunately, one couple came in, sat down, was ignored by the server, and ended up leaving after about five minutes. So I guess you just have to understand that this place works a little differently!

Overall, it felt like a nice mom-and-pop place. They seemed to just enjoy running a restaurant and providing sushi to the neighborhood. They didn't seem like a money hungry business, which I liked!
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
Sashimi-Maguro, Sake, Hamachi -fresh and buttery

Nigiri-Tobiko so sweet :) Tako, Uni, Ebi, Hotate

Rolls-mango shrimp brown rice , just okay 

Special rolls- Dynamite, snow leopard, sea fairy -fresh.simple

True Mom and Pop shop, it's true wait for food can take up to 30 mins, totally worth it.
author: Connie N.

description: This is the hardest review I need to give. I really like wayo and have eaten here many times. Sushi is absolutely great and worth the wait. I usually come about 30 minutes before opening with my wife to wait in line. My wife recently gave birth to our first son and was craving sushi after nine months of prohibition. So to be nice to my wife, I waited in line, ordered sushi to go, and bring it home to her. After doing this three times, the sushi chef told me no more. He will no longer serve me for take out even though I am waiting for an hour just like everyone else. I tried to explain my situation but he would not listen. It is hard, but I don't think I will come here anymore after being loyal for all these years.
author: Rasheq Z.

description:
Food
Select nigiri - Good but expensive

Service
Takes very long time haha like 1 hr wait time after you place your order it's just one sushi chef I think that's why literally mom n pop


Atmosphere 
Pretty tiny small bar seating and few small tables
author: Angela L.

description:
Wayo sushi is a small and cozy restaurant located off of Bush & Van Ness. Very casual and nothing fancy. I decided to give this place another chance after turning it down the first time due to the long wait. The wait is very long and they'll warn you upon your arrival. 

There's only one sushi chef and one waitress running the restaurant. The menu is very simple, a la carte style with a few specials for the day. The sushi is pretty fresh and the prices are reasonable. You can substitute for brown rice if you want to be healthier. They didn't have any toro, but my favorite was the Hamachi.

Great place to try out, but I wouldn't return considering the long wait.
author: Helen C.

description:
All the fish in the sushi place say,
Waayyoo wayyooo o waayyyo wwayyoooo!
Wait like a cus to mer.
chka-chka-chka-chka-chka-chka-chka-chka
Wait like a cus to mer.

Are you reading a novel? Did you not finish your homework?
When did you last check your Facebook? Are you crafty?
Angry Birds? Stalking people on OkCupid? Scrabble?
DMV papers? Gossip on workmates / classmates / roommates?

* It's 30-40 minutes between ordering and receiving food. *
So whatever it is that you've got to do, bring it.

Seriously. Next time I walk by, I'd better see some AAU students laying out projects over the bar.
Or hipsters doing a photo shoot with the light-bouncing umbrella and everything.
It doesn't matter.

You know the date behind me was the opposite of happening.
Neither of them wore a smile when they got up to leave.

The server woman and sushi maker antennae man were polite.
Food was homey rather than flashy - I respect that.
The caterpillar roll didn't look like a bug.
But I ordered it because I'd wanted a bug.
My mango spicy tuna roll was _____. That is a blank space.
Pieces were also smaller than at other places.

There were a few funky art pieces, one drawn by a customer's child.
While the kid waited for sushi, I bet.

Approximately 2 3/4 stars.
author: Dan B.

description:
Based on everyone's reviews, I was a bit worried coming here and having to wait a long time, but I actually didn't have to wait long for my table! For my sushi though, it was about a 45 minute wait (there's only one sushi chef).

We tried:
-hamachi sashimi = Meh, I've had better
-salmon sashimi = so good and fresh! The salmon melted in my mouth like butter!
-mango salmon roll = unique and I loved the combination of the salmon with the mango
-chef's special with tuna, hamachi, unagi, ebi, octopus?, saba and salmon = always in love with unagi. Didn't eat the octopus (it scares me a bit), and the Saba was a bit disappointing :-/

Overall 3.5 stars rounded up to a 4. Would come for the salmon and prices were pretty decent and portions were filling.

Tip: come on a Sunday night and remember to be patient :-)
author: Christina C.

description: This is not a place for you if you don't have the time or the right knowledge to appreciate proper sushi. The temperature of the sushi is right and the rice is sticking together nicely and there is wasabi in some of the sushi ( which it should!!!!) Fish is very fresh and bbq eel nigiri is amazing! THe chef is simply  trying to bring the most authentic Japanese food to people and some even complain there is no spicy source when they are eating rolls! Are you kidding me ! If you want nasty bullshit Americanized sushi like that go to Walgreen and buy yourself a box of plastic rice !!!
author: Clyde Duduo Z.

description:
Looking for a decent place to grab some late dinner after a movie, Wayo pop up on top of my search. I am always in mood for sushi so I ventured into this little restaurant. 

First impression was mixed. On one hand, I was happy to find a small local restaurant ran by a genuine Japanese couple. On the other hand, restaurant was rather quiet at that point and there were no Japanese customers. The menu also offered too many fusion rolls for my comfort. 

I decided against getting any of their rolls and went for a straight nigiri fare. 13 pieces later, I was happy and satisfied. The nigiri were authentic. Good sushi rice, perfect fish to rice ratio and all in small bite size pieces. Even the quality of the fish was much better than I have expected. The shiro maguro that night was excellent. The uni was fresh. Hotategai, kani and amaebi all nice and sweet. I also appreciate how everything was served in the logical order starting with lighter shiromi (white fish) and slowly progress to stronger flavors.

I like the intimate ambiance of the restaurant. If you sit right at the sushi bar you get to watch the chef in action. He is a man of few words but works diligently (despite a bit slow) to prepare your delicious meal. Customers were later informed of a longer wait (40 minutes) for sushi and that eventually turned away some potential customers. Those who were willing to wait, will be rewarded in my opinion. Food was good and the price was very reasonable. 

Even though I can't give Wayo a solid 4 stars review, I still highly recommend this place. I might even try some of their rolls next time I am in the neighborhood.
author: Mona W.

description:
A solid, unassuming find. Eons ago, I used to frequent a hole-in-the-wall on Church everyone called No Name Sushi. Yeah, you remember it. It was the ideal spot for the 20-something looking for fresh cheap sushi, and you could brown bag your own beer. I heard it went downhill and finally closed after a fire about six years ago. Flash forward to the present and I am no longer a cherubic youth living from paycheck to paycheck. Now I am an aging curmudgeon who can afford fresh sushi every now and then. When I entered Wayo, I had a flashback to No Name though it's much tidier. You can tell it was once a coffee shop once since it's dominated by a U-shaped counter (photo: http://bit.ly/1g55kZF) and offers only a few tables next to the front window. With no support staff, this compact spot is run solely by a couple much like Ino Sushi in J-Town, even if it does look a bit like Mel's.

There were three of us, ravenously hungry, and surprisingly, we were able to saddle up at the counter with ease. It was a relatively quiet weeknight, so we were able to watch the chef displaying his artistry right in front of us. We started by sharing a couple of salads - the $9.50 Spicy Tuna with Avocado (photo: http://bit.ly/1dsGX8o) and the $8 Salmon (photo: http://bit.ly/1guzk1O). The sashimi pieces were fresh, but the presentation itself was nothing too exciting since the fish was simply sitting on top of just chopped Romaine leaves. The nigiri sushi, on the other hand, was near-flawless thanks to the pure freshness of the fish. At $5 for every two pieces, the Maguro (Tuna) and Hamaichi (Yellowtail) were flavorful and thick with great texture. The specialty rolls turned out to be the better deal. The $6 Dynamite Roll (six pieces) offers spicy tuna and avocado topped with a dab of tobiko, a sort of California roll with a kick.

Meanwhile, the $11.50 Sea Fairy Roll was a true California roll with the luxury of a tobiko-accented scallop on top (photo: http://bit.ly/1asU59g). More plates of nigiri sushi came in the form of Shiro Maguro (Albacore Tuna, $5 for two pieces) and Sake (Salmon, same price) (photo: http://bit.ly/191jpby). We wrapped our meals up with a quartet of Ikura nigiri (Salmon Roe, $6 for two pieces) (photo: http://bit.ly/1hkXEGl), a couple of Tako (Octopus, $4 for two pieces) (photo: http://bit.ly/1a5u5oe), and a couple of the velvety Uni nigiri (Sea Urchin, $7 for two pieces) (photo: http://bit.ly/1a5u5oe). That was a whole lotta fish for three people but well worth the ultimately hefty price tag. I had no complaints on what we had, but I was a bit surprised at the omissions - no tamago (egg), no toro (tuna belly), and no ankimo (monkfish liver) - in case you were looking for deeper variety.

FOOD - 4 stars...grade-A sushi, a bit more variety would be nice
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...the old diner vibe is still there, but it's more about the sushi
SERVICE - 4 stars...the wife is ever-patient, the husband a true master
TOTAL - 4 stars...one of the diner...uhh, I mean finer sushi places in town
author: Ed U.

description:
Umm. This is a terrible place. Don't come here. 

*sigh*. 

But if you *do* end up here and the nice lady tells you sushi is going to take an hour because there's only one chef, do yourself a favor and sit the f*ck down.
author: Dilip P.

description: Amazing! One server, one sushi chef, soooooo many options of fresh sushi rolls without all that extra sauce and unnecessary toppings. This is the real deal!
author: Paul J.

description: This is a little gem. The food and service is great! Fresh and faster than you would think with one sushi chef. If you are in the area, don't just walk by this one. Stop in and give it a try, you won't be sorry.
author: Patricia G.

description:
I'll keep this short sweet and to the point. 

3.5 stars

Service: nice but slow, only 1 sushi chef making sushi- they definitely need to hire someone to help out as the wait is much too long

Sushi: pretty basic/traditional no real special rolls but the fish is super fresh, rolls could use a bit less rice 

Price: decently cheap but all rolls are 5 or 6 pieces rather than 8

Decor: typical, clean, basic

Won't be my go-to place but may be back
author: Sarah G.

description:
Clean! Unbelievable. Fantastic sushi.  Very fresh fish. Well worth the wait. Great, attentive service.
The place is spotless. The sushi is so good that we would've paid double for it. 
5 rolls, 2 salads, 2 large saki = $60.
author: Suzanne P.

description: Great little spot if your trying to get away from all the chaotic restaurant vibe scene. Food was good, service was good.
author: Shira T.

description: I still love their mango salmon roll. The chef and waitress are sweet. However, I was craving for uni, but the ones we ordered were not too fresh. It had a mildly odd taste and it didn't satisfy my uni craving. I guess I'll be sticking to the rolls.
author: Mandy D.

description:
Probably the freshest sushi I have had in a while. Such a great find!!
There is one sushi chef and one waitress, so be prepared to wait for a while. But... trust me, it's worth it.
