My roommate and I ordered a few rolls and the sweet shrimp nigiri. The only thing we were not completely in love with was the seared albacore roll.

After a few rolls and a large beer, we walked away stuffed for less than $20 each.

Definitely will be back!
author: Michelle L.

description: Several friends recommended this place, stating it's their favorite sushi place in the city! It is definitely one of my favorites now too. There was only one sushi chef but they let us know as soon as we ordered that it takes about 30 min to get your food which I appreciated knowing in advance.
author: Shilps S.

description:
Was looking for a good sushi place that also did lunch and this place popped up. 

I give this place a 3.5

Sushi: the rolls and sashimi pieces were fresh and tasty, but wasn't amazing. 
I tried the snow leopard roll and I'm not sure exactly what it was supposed to taste like, but it certainly didn't live up to expectations. 

Service: there was only one sushi chef so it was pretty slow. 

Price: average for a sushi place. 

Overall, it was good sushi but wasn't too special for me.
author: Yong K.

description: This sushi is really good. It's a shame they discourage you from eating there by giving you ridiculously high quote times. I walked in minutes after they opened and there were only 3 other 2 tops sat. The lady greets me with,"Sushi is going to take 45 minutes." It's very common for them give you 1h+ quotes for food when the place only seats about 25 ppl. I don't think I will be coming back here again.
author: Luis V.

description:
Run by only two people, seems like husband and wife, so service was a bit slow.

My boyfriend and I walked in on a random weeknight for dinner and they immediately told us it would be a 45 min wait for sushi. We waited and snacked on beer and edamame as we waited. 

The wait was definitely worth it! We were treated to extremely fresh cut sashimi, and each roll was carefully constructed and delicious. I reccomend sitting at the bar so you can watch the chef cut and make everything right in front of you.
author: Mindy T.

description:
San Francisco Little Japan is full of sushi places but this is by far my favorite in town. It's an odd thing to point out but the TEA is exceptional--its traditionally brewed and full of flavor and beautifully served. 

The sashimi was fresh and fantastic. The selections and combinations really fantastic and the daily special was top notch. Try it!
author: Alexandra S.

description:
We took a little hiatus after a bad experience here on the customer service side. They are always trying to run dinner service on 1-2 staff, which by my observation, has never seemed to work out well. 

We decided to give Wayo another go last night. Service was slightly better but I felt the quality has gone down. With sushi, that's not a good thing. Rolls are a little sloppy looking and the nigiri didn't seem as fresh as past experiences. 

Still a solid, affordable, no-frills spot, but in my opinion it's just a so-so experience all things considered.
author: Brianna M.

description: I found this hidden gem while at a conference.  The place is very small but the service was great!  The fish was fresh.
author: Janae N.

description:
Very small sushi bar with cozy atmosphere and great sashimi. They take the orders very promptly and bring the food very fast. I think the place is owned by a couple, and it seemed like they were the only people working there. 
Loved the food and loved the ambience!
author: Luba Y.

description:
My sushi-appetite recently gravitated towards Wayo Sushi, and I couldn't be happier with the results of this gravity. It's a wonderfully humble operation, and you can tell that it's geared towards quality and love of the craft. 

The menu is perfect -- simple, small, and well-priced. With lack of frills comes great tastiness. I had the best sake sashimi I've ever eaten, and I can admit to probably depleting much of the world's salmon population with my taste for the stuff. The nigiris I tried were perfection on rice. I can recommend the shiro maguro and hamachi for sure. The pieces are arranged simply on a plate without any extra stuff. No decorative leaves or fancily sculpted lemon bits; you are just presented with the good stuff.  

The spicy tuna was de-licious. Many places tend to under-spice the tuna, but Wayo certainly kicks it up with plenty of spicy bite. We also tried one of the mango rolls I heard so much Yelp about, and they did not disappoint. Perfect balance of flavors, and you can choose from a few different combinations with fish and crab. 

Not sure if they've considered hiring one more person to work the joint -- I only saw one chef and a lovely woman taking orders. One customer was told that he would have to wait 40 minutes for food which seemed excessive; the place wasn't extremely busy. I guess that just goes to show that patience leads to delicious. 

Definitely set aside an evening to check out Wayo. They open at 6PM during the week. I was able to arrive right when they opened so my mother and I enjoyed some nice alone time at the bar for about 20 minutes before other diners came.  Simply lovely!
author: Chelsea B.

description: This maintains its position as one of my favorite sushi places of all time. Yes the wait is long, yes it's one chef, and one waitress- all of it is a little manic and eccentric but the sushi is legit, fresh, and with no gimmicks. This is sushi at its simplest but with a few fun twists like the mango in the sushi... Yum that's good. The central location of the restaurant is also desirable.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Came here last Thursday night because the wait at the House of Prime Rib was over an hour. 
Found this 4 stared restaurant nearby on Yelp...so gonna give it a try.  
When we walked in, there were 5 tables being seated n we were the only Asians.  Next i noticed that every tables orderd sushi rolls and rolls only!!  By this time, i started to have a bad feeling ... i was being cautious and only ordered 5 items. It turned out that the sushi was quite fresh but the rice was a little too hard, nothing fancy tho .... not sure why it gets the 4 stars, more like a 3 stars to me!
I have had much better sushi elsewhere, so i dun think I'll be coming back again.
author: Mark H.

description:
I thought this place was just okay. 

It was delicious to me when I ate it because I had just hiked Alamere Falls and our group was FAMISHED. 

I got the chirashi with only salmon and hamachi and I literally got 4 thin slices of each fish. The hamachi tasted fresh but the salmon was only alright. 

I also ordered the Tiger roll with was broiled hamachi which was also just okay.Usually when I order chirashi I am full off of just that, so it really says something that I was hungry enough to share a roll as well. 

Overall, an okay experience.
author: Rachel C.

description: This place gets a solid 3 only because price is not the best value and quality isn't consistent. Been here 4 times and no consistency. First 2x were great, fish was fresh. Last 2 times were disappointing.
author: Miguel Y.

description: Lovely people, nice sushi. No "fancy," but very well priced for SF and for the quality. There's only one couple working in the restaurant, so sometimes there's a wait. Please be considerate of that if you choose to dine here (they are very upfront about how long the wait is before they seat you).
author: Thea S.

description:
Amazing sushi, best I've had anywhere in the city. The wait is usually somewhat long (40 mins -1 hour) unless you get there really early or late. But don't worry, they'll tell you in advance if there is a wait. I guess this is the price to be paid for having everything done perfectly, by an artisan who clearly takes pride in his craft. 
So if you simply must have the best sushi in the city then this is the place. On the other hand, if you think fast food is a great invention then this might not be the right place.
author: Alex C.

description:
Probably can't give a full review on this place since I don't eat raw fish. The restaurant itself is not the large one in the world which means it's not rally suitable for parties larger than 4. It looks like the whole place runs by just the married couple, it's really amazing how they manage the whole place just by them two.

The service isn't exactly fast but it's excepted with just the two of them (husband slaving behind the counter making sushi and the wife working the floor). I had the caterpillar row, California hand roll, and the seaweed salad. Everything was decent, I'm surprise they use real crab meat in the California hand roll, guess they really believe in fine ingredients. Don't forget to check out the board menu behind the main door. I totally missed it and didn't see the special rolls of the day!!

I keep hearing they tell the customers walking in after us that sushi order will take 45min to prepare,  not exactly sure why. I'm guessing it's because of the lack of staff? Can't say this place is worth the wait, but I'm not going to write it off as a place not worth trying.
author: Elaine Y.

description: I have had the sushi here before and it was delightful, however the last time I came in, it was 7pm on a tuesday night. The restaurant was somewhat full, but there were still plenty of open seats. I walked up to the bar by myself. The owner told me it would be an hour before I was served food. "An hour?" asked. He nodded and walked away. Not sure what it was about and he provided no explanation. Bummer.
author: Megan J.

description:
The sushi here is quite good.  It's not amazing as the reviews lead you to believe, but they are good.  The rolls are quite cheap - definitely try the mango rolls.  BUT the wait is long (that's where the 2 stars went).  

Example #1:
One weeknight, I tried to order take-out, calling 30 minutes ahead of time but no luck - called several times and no one picked up.  I go in, and was quoted an hour wait time for my take out order...

Example #2:
Another weeknight, I went in with 2 friends.  We were seated promptly but was told service will be slow.  We didn't expect it to be TOO bad since there were only 2 other parties of 2 in the restaurant, and definitely many more open tables.  But she was right, service is slow.  We didn't receive our food for an hour.

I understand it's a husband and wife team running the operation, but if you can't support the volume, maybe hire extra staff?  It makes no sense to have a restaurant size beyond what you can support.

If you want to come here, which I do recommend that you do, come early.  Be the first party.
author: Joyce C.

description: I walked in on a Saturday night and the place was 50% full and the sushi chef told me it would be an hour and half wait to get served. Why only have one chef working on a Saturday night?
author: Alex R.

description: Great mom and pop sushi place with crazy great fresh fish! I worked in the area for a year and loved their lunch box special at least twice per week! Small and sometimes busy so plan ahead.
author: Brook M.

description:
I came here on a Friday night at 8:30PM and was able to get a set for two. It's a small shop so it could definitely get crowded fast during prime time. The service was good but a bit slow when getting your order, but if you're with good company then it's all fine.

The fish itself was great. Very fresh and properly made. If you're looking for custom fancy rolls, this is not the place to go, but if you're looking for fresh fish without all that fluff then give it a try. The Mango Salmon roll sounded delicious! I am definitely coming back to try more of their options!
author: Kathy V.

description:
Very small cozy place on Van Ness. Good thing we arrived at exactly 6 pm got lucky to find parking close. A few minutes after opening all 4 tables were gone.  The cook warned us that it take about 45 min to serve us But it was worth the wait we sipped on Saki ,Sapporo and Miso soup freshly made. 
Sushi was great we tried many since prices we decent.
author: Dom A.

description: Cute, cozy hole in the wall sushi joint, visited spur of the moment walking around SF. Salmon sashimi was delicious, its just like what you would find in tokyo. The chef was nice, even though he had more people in than he could handle alone. Loved the authentic Japanese feel to the whole place, A+
author: Iman Y.

description:
Me and my boyfriend went right at 6:00PM when they opened in order to avoid the wait that a lot of the yelpers have mentioned. We waited for around 30 minutes to get our food, which was much better than we thought. 

The hamachi sashimi was AMAZING. It's 6 pcs/$12 which is such a steal and SO fresh as well. We also ordered the hotate (scallops), amaebi (sweet shrimp), salmon sushi. My boyfriend especially thought that the hotate and amaebi were disappointing- the texture and taste weren't as fresh and tangy as those that we've had in Seattle. Lastly, we ordered a salmon skin roll- the salmon skin is baked on the spot so its really hot inside, and also paired with cucumber and yellow pickled radish. We were both pleased with the roll, especially for the good price (5 pcs/ $6).

Overall, I really recommend this restaurant and I'll be back! The fish is fresh and it is not too expensive compared to other sushi places in Japantown :)
author: Molly L.

description:
Chefs night off and I was craving Sushi.
Decided to come back after 6 months of not coming here due to my busy schedule.

Just like clock work I was greeted with the warm smiles I had remembered from before . I ordered 8-12 items and left my crazy world behind as I indulged in the best kept sushi secret of San Fran!! 

I will be back soon !!
author: BigDog E.

description:
Nothing super fancy in the way of specialty rolls, but the fish is fresh and the sushi chef sure knows what he's doing!

Love this place. Also super reasonably priced for the high quality of sushi.
author: Brooke L.

description: This was a surprising treat to find on Van Ness. Affordable rolls and a clean and inviting sushi bar inside. There are not very many complex combination rolls, but the quality of the fish shines. The also have brown rice for any roll.
author: Nic F.

description:
In business 25 years, old school sushi guy.  Expect no smiles or pleasantries but good no frills sushi. 

Take off a star because it is no the most fun in there.  But we go back for the food
author: michael d.

description: This is good quality sushi. But you'll normally wait 45 min, unless you're way early or late and beat the dinner crowd. We usually get their special combo sushi plate, and I like mine with brown rice. Just remember about the wait, so if you have time to spare, come here for nice sushi.
author: Olga A.

description: Top notch sushi. It's hard to believe they're so cheap. The tea is legit! And you will get free refill after refill! Went here with a three person party and although there were plenty of seats, we were told sushi would take one hour to get. It's because there is one sushi chef and one waitress whom both kick ass. I appreciate their model, it's an intimate place and if you want amazing sushi, you just have to have patience. Everything about the space was charming. Felt like I went into a real sushi restaurant filled with love and SF quirk. The sushi itself was very authentic, the cuts were prime, and the rice was perfect. Honestly, not one complaint. I truly feel I had the ultimate sushi experience tonight and look forward to returning. I've dined at some of the best sushi places in the world, and this spot really is top notch.
author: G M.

description: I went here last night and the sushi was not very good. The service was subpar. When we sat down there was maybe 3 other groups in the restaurant, and they told us that it would be a 30 min wait for any sushi.  I was Ok with that because I thought the sushi guy was taking his time and making quality sushi. Boy was I wrong!  My Hamachi sushi came out and it was clearly half bloodline, when i sent it back telling them, "this is half bloodline and looks old" they just cut off the bloodline. Now I have been spending my morning on the toilet.  We also got alot of other rolls and they were just ok, not very creative. The only good thing was that it was simi reasonably priced.
author: Mike B.

description:
By far the best sushi in the neighborhood and the best I've had in the city, too. Incredible sake sashimi. The friendly service doesn't hurt, either. 

There may be a wait for sushi if they're crowded, but the food is well worth the wait.
author: Ted S.

description: So I would totally give this place 5 stars because the sushi was delicious and fresh and well executed. The reason I can only give 4 stars is the delay. To be fair, there's only one sushi chef and one waitress so I can see why they have to take their time. Also, as soon as I say down (7p on a Saturday) they told me outright that if I ordered sushi it would be a 1 hour wait. I was not starving and I had no agenda so I decided to have some sake (mediocre) and miso soup and wait. I placed my order and while my drinks and soup arrived with little delay it took (as the chef warned me) almost an hour to get my sushi... But it was worth the wait. However, by the time I left at 830 the wait was minimal. So, sushi is excellent but be prepared to wait....
author: Sheetal P.

description: Nice food, cheap price and friendly staff. I marked it down to three stars because of the wait, almost an hour. I was among three people through the door when it opened at 6pm on a Saturday. It quickly filled up after me. Only one chef working for a full restaurant. He made everything from scratch, which is great, but just being third in the queue meant forty minutes from my order time (which was around ten minutes after arriving as the only waitress was still setting things up). Only head here during peak times if you've got good company and don't mind the wait. It's the only fault I can give it (portions were a bit pricier for smaller servings compared to a restaurant just a block away) though  if you're happy to nurse a drink or two while chatting you may not even notice.
author: Guy C.

description:
Best sushi I've ever had. Unreal. 

Long waits at prime time but always worth it.
author: Jessica K.

description:
My friend Natasha may not write Yelp reviews, but I love that she uses the site to make suggestions on where we'll meet when we have dinner together during my visits.

This week was no exception.  I was excited that I had a free night to see my friend, and even more excited when she suggested sushi.  Wayo was a convenient location for both of us, and in addition to the great company, we both enjoyed their fresh fish, casual atmosphere, and moderate prices.

Forget about the fancy schmancy sushi places around town.  There wasn't a wait at Wayo and it's so casual, there was a party of girls that came in shortly after we did, and they were in workout clothes - I love that!  Along with that, just know going in that the rolls and fish options offered are the basics; nothing wrong with that though!

Between the two of us, we shared yellowtail sashimi, two spicy scallop handrolls, a dynamite roll, a shrimp tempura roll, a cucumber crabmeat salad, and a house salad with their Italian/Japanese dressing.  It's worth mentioning that the crabmeat on the cucumber salad was fresh (not imitation) and delicious.  I really liked the dressing on the house salad and was pleased that it came with mixed greens and avocado too.  Of all of the sushi, I think we both enjoyed our spicy scallop handrolls the best, but it was all good.  

We washed it all down with green tea and sake.  All of that for under $30 a person - not bad!

Since you read this far, I'll clue you in on a little hint I learned from Natasha years ago: order a side of ponzu sauce and dip your sushi in that instead of soy sauce.  Even if you're a purist, a tad of ponzu makes everything better!

Another San Francisco trip down, another sushi place to cross off my list... but I'd totally return.
author: Gabi M.

description: This place is great ! I am a sashimi nigiri type of guy so this review is for that. If your looking for rolls with sauce all over you will be disappointed. The chef is the real deal cranking out nigiri and sashimi all by himself which will take time :/ its worth it though. Cheap and fresh with great presentation. Will come again for an omakase!
author: Nate E.

description: This is my go to sushi spot and my recommendation for anyone that wants terrific, simple sushi. They are not fancy but you can count on great quality and consistency. The couple that own the place are the only two that work (the guy is the chef and the woman serves). They always give an accurate wait time and even when it's long, your edamame and drinks will come fast so you can relax while you wait for your sushi, and it's always worth the wait!
author: Caity Y.

description: Everything from the seaweed salad to the sushi tastes fresher and more vibrant than most spots, but I think I like it equally for its husband/wife feel (guessing a young Japanese couple), that provide a secret locals spot, albeit improbably on Van Ness!
author: Patrick B.

description: Small mom and pop shop with delicious fresh sushi. Very nice service despite being understaffed.  Good value and very affordable for what you get in an expensive city like SF.  Go if you are not in a hurry.
author: Jay H.

description:
Wayo's chiefly utilitarian decor is accented by cheery touches in the form of rainbow paintings and a well-placed sake barrel, while wide windows let plenty of natural light pour in.

Sit at the bar and peruse their drink list. Choose between beer, wine, or (un)filtered sake. (My accomplice and I shared beer and a bit of calming cold sake, perfect for lunch.)

The sushi rolls are a solid value: try a dynamite roll ($5). It packs a punch, fresh, spicy tuna mingling nicely with avocado and tobiko. Their meticulously-wrapped mango and crab meat rolls (also $5) are a winner, too. It's flavorful, but throw in wasabi for kicks; the vivid contrast between mango and wasabi can't be beat.

Enjoy outstanding, personal attention from chef-and-owner Mamoru but be prepared to wait during busy hours, as there's only one other server.
author: Dave L.

description:
My husband and I love this place. It's tiny, and often has a wait of ~45 minutes for sushi, but it totally worth it. The sushi is fresh, and I really like the edamame there since they boil fresh ones. Many restaurants use frozen edamame and some places even microwave them (they're awful!). 

We went on a Tuesday evening most recently, and were pleasantly surprised we didn't have to wait at all. We had the tako sashimi, hamachi rolls, rainbow roll, salmon and cream cheese roll, and mango spicy tuna roll. They all tasted great, and the service was also good as usual.
author: Yuki S.

description:
Very small family owned place, which is usually filled to capacity and is hard to get to. Probably not worth the wait since there are plenty of other options around, but I always check it out when passing by, and make a stop if there is a table available there.

The sushi is really good there, great sashimi, all of the standard rolls, some creative special rolls, nice miso soup. The prices are on the low end compared to other sushi bars in the area.

Intimate and quite, with good service, if you are lucky to get in.
author: Stacy A.

description:
Been here only once so my review is based on that.

It's a mom and pop shop with mom waitressing and pop making the sushi behind the counter.  I ordered 4 nigiri (8 pieces in total).  The fish was good and the portions were very healthy.  I look forward to eating here again. 

My only complaint would be that some of the fish (the tuna in general) was colder than it should be.  Granted, I showed up 10 minutes after they opened at noon, but still, it was clearly not fully thawed.  

I've also seen other posts state that the sushi isn't "pretty."  I agree with those comments.  The rice was going in every direction and the fish was not cut perfectly.  With that said, I didn't really care at the time.  I'm not sure if I would if I frequented this place regularly.  Also, since I sat at the bar, the chef was putting out the sushi onto my plate as he prepared them.  I'm fine with that, but if you have a preference for the order you eat your fish and you want to sit at the bar, you might want to tell them to bring it all out at once.
author: John K.

description:
Worth the wait: this is one of those no-frills secret mom-and-pop sushi places that looks like nothing from the outside, and inside holds a world of charm.

Excellent value, nothing super fancy, but everything is of serious quality, with great attention to detail. Real crab meat. Mango and avocado specials worth trying. As others have noted, unless you come for lunch or right at the start of dinner, you'll probably have to wait a while for your sushi. We came in after spending the entire afternoon walking all over SF, so it was actually super-pleasant to take a load off and snack on some appetizers, so the ~40min wait went by in the blink of an eye.

Definitely making this a regular stop when I'm back in town.
author: myrrh l.

description:
Alright so it's been a while and a review is long overdue so I am glad to make Wayo my first review from my hiatus. Why you ask? Well it is no surprise to people that knows my huge affinity towards sushi and wherever I travel I try to find a consistent sushi joint that I can hit up. I appreciate the high class sushi joints but there is something special about a no frills joint that is just focused on the quality of their fish. This place is exactly that type of joint. It is a small joint on Van Ness with limited seating so I can see how the line would be long on certain days. Parking is not bad as there are plenty of metered spots all around the surrounding streets. 

We walked in on a Sunday and were greeted promptly by a waitress. The menu here is focused on and concise which I appreciate. It also makes sense given there is pretty much one sushi chef and one waitress running the entire shop. Each order of nigiri comes with two pieces and the prices are extremely reasonable here. After perusing the menu we decided to have one order of each nigiri (don't judge) and one roll along with a plethora of hot sake of course. The hot sake was brought out promptly and standard. The roll is something that was solid but I am not much of a roll person... why rolls when you can enjoy fresh fish. All of the nigiri was extremely fresh and delicious. The highlight for me was definitely the Hotate nigiri but honestly all were just delicious. My one gripe that is minor is that the rice to fish ratio was just a tiny bit off where they served a bit too much rice with each piece of fish.

I wish I could give this place a 4.5 because the quality of fish is just excellent. Just the rice ratio and the fact that the rolls were just ok (trying to balance out so the review is not too focused on just sashimi). If you are looking for no frills and just good sashimi this is your spot for sure. Definitely check this spot out.
author: Dan M.

description:
If you come here you need to be ready to sit and wait for a while. After sitting and waiting you will get your water. Then you will sit and wait some more (you get the idea)

The only waitress/hostess/busser was very clear at the beginning it would take a while to get our food. So we were prepared and talked for the good hour wait.

The sushi rice was probably some of the best I have had. I thought the maki rolls were hit or miss but the sashimi and nigiri were some of the best I have had because it was so fresh.
author: Kyle S.

description: This is our neighborhood sushi joint and we stop here basically at least 1-2x every week. You can call me biased but wayo truly has the best sushi in town. Although the selections are limited, it always delivers on freshness and quality. Our go to is the dragon roll, sake nigiri and spicy tuna. It is a one person show though so don't come here expecting fast service. Come leisurely to enjoy the one of the best in sf :)
author: Mo S.

description: Fabulous. Fish is fresh as are the vegetables. The mango rolls are delish and unique. They have gluten free Tamari. Lots of veggie sushi options for vegetarians and vegans. Brown rice sushi is available. Service is great. Prices are reasonable. This place is a gem.
author: Karma K.

description:
Wayo may have earned go-to sushi spot status. Fresh sushi, unpretentious atmosphere, good service, very reasonable prices, brown rice option.

If the place is full you'll wait a bit for your food as there is only one sushi chef. But he knows his stuff and wears a fun hat. So go with someone you like talking to, sip a drink, and the wait time will fly.
author: Jenny V.

description: I don't recommend this place. The reason why, because it's horrible sushi that I ever tasted. Only one person make there sushi, he was so slow I had to wait with my husband 45 minutes, plus I was so hungry and I wanted to eat. So we ordered , and I though, okay if he takes 40 minutes that means that the sushi will be delicious and I really wanted to taste them . But when we tasted them  I just wanted to throw up. So we didn't   eat them at all , we just spent our money and time  for nothing, I do not recommend this place at all.
author: Alina M.

description:
Service is really slow. This is one of those places where your waiter will avoid eye contact with you when you're trying to get a glass of water.

Reasonable sushi for the price. 

However, I ordered tako (octopus sashimi) and it was still partially frozen. 

I wanted to love this place since it's a block away from work.
author: Bianca D.

description:
DAM!!! This place is DIRT CHEAP!!! The sashimi & nigiri were of good size and pretty fresh. The uni however, was not so you might want to stay away from that.
I loved the vinegar they used for the cucumber salad.
They have a bunch of special rolls for $5 on a whiteboard in the entryway so be sure to check those out. I had a very good mango hamachi roll.
The rest of the rolls on the regular menu are just mehhh so so. Stick with sashimi and nigiri here and you're in the clear.
author: Susy C.

description: Totally worth the wait ! I don't understand why most people give them crap just because of the waiting time. you guys are notified like the moment you walk in that it's gonna be an one hour wait ! Just Take it or leave, seriously ! On the other hand , I really love the one chef one waitress setup . Everything is laid out in front of you and you know exactly what you are getting and it is super fresh and super authentic. You can see how skillful and dedicated the chef is and he controls the temperature and texture of sushi perfectly! Some people say sushi is just ok here , obviously those people don't understand sushi at all. I have been to Japan and many upscale sushi places around world but this place is by far the best sushi place .Yeah it's decor is kinda plain but that's what keeps the price low. I would recommend it to anyone who like to chill in a nice place and spend sometime to enjoy real sushi
author: Jacqueline Z.

description:
Excellent sushi; sticks to the basics.  The menu is almost completely sushi, without distractions.  If that's what you're looking for, this is the place.

As others have mentioned, this is a small place, with a staff of two.  When it gets busy, the wait for food can get quite long-I heard the chef tell someone it might be an hour before they would get their food.  I think it's great that they're honest about it (especially compared to other places that just make you wait!) but it means that if you're in a rush, this place might not be for you unless you get there right when it opens.

If you're not in a rush, and have someone to pass the time with, I'd recommend ordering a couple of beers and waiting.  The food will be worth it!
author: Sofia C.

description: Small place is a refreshment to these over busy and packed places. Food was good, service perfect so what else you are looking for. You need to bring some time but if you don't have that go to the big M  yuk!
author: Andreas H.

description:
We were on Polk street last night and were craving sushi... So we yelped a nearby sushi place. Based on the 4 stars, we headed to Wayo. WHY IS THIS PLACE rated 4 stars?! 

First of all, they don't have sriracha or any spicy sauce for that matter. I was in shock. How is that possible? I hate wasabi or that "spicy" powder and have never been denied sriracha or another hot sauce at a Japanese restaurant in my life. 

Now onto the service. There were at least 20 people when we arrived. We sat ourselves as there were tables open and no one to seat us. Before saying hello or how are you, the lady simply said, "it will be 40 minutes wait." We say no problem but ask to see a menu and order sake and beer. She gives is the menu... No sake and definitely no beer. A good 10-15 minutes go by and she asks us if we were ready to order. I just sat there... Confused. Anyways, we ordered the food and once again, the drinks. 

The sushi wasn't anything special. In fact, it all tasted the same to us. We had the mango crab roll, mango salmon roll and the cream cheese shrimp roll. For some reason, every roll had wasabi in it. Gross! 

Given the service and the fact that the sushi was pretty bland and in all honesty, didn't even taste fresh, we definitely won't be back!

Please hire another waitress. The poor lady ran around in circles and still never remembered anything.
author: Anastasia N.

description: Really fresh, well-prepared cuts. Brown rice available. Delicious Mackerel - proof of the freshness. Mango rolls are great. I'll be back for more, soon!
author: Ben A.

description:
I love this place and I don't want to let anyone else know about it. 
However, I owe it to the wonderful couple (the only 2 people) running the restaurant together. 
This is one of the best sushi spots because... they are an actual JAPANESE couple. She gives you the receipt in Japanese characters and you smile because you can't read the receipt but you are completely satisfied with the food and service.

Yes. It is very very very slow to get your food, but the waitress warns you it will be an hour before you even decide to sit down.
So you should leave if you are super hungry or you should just suck it up for the most fresh, delicious sashimi that you have ever had in your life. 
You can always drink plenty of beer while you wait for your food ;)
author: Dee N.

description:
This place is definitely overrated! Decided to come here today for lunch with my friend since this place has a decent yelp reviews. There were not that many people during the time when we came. We ordered two rolls and waited forever... okay, I understand there was only one chef... I believe its owned by wife (server) and husband (chef). The lady looked mean and had poor service..

Awhile after, our rolls finally came! My friend and I literally saw a strand of black hair in our roll.. 
I was pretty starving that time.... and I saw my sushi had a hair inside.. ugh.. Okay.. I thought to myself.. okay.. I could wait for the chef to make another new roll for us.. Since I used to work in the restaurants.. I understand sometimes it happens when the food accidently has a strand of hair or whatever in it... I was being considerated so I tried not to put the owner on the spot. I waived to the lady (owner/server) who served us to come to the table and I politely pointed at my sushi, kept my voice down to tell her "there is something in the roll". I said "something" just cuz I did not want to let other customers hear it. The lady took our plate back and discussed something to the chef in japanese. I was expecting them to make us new roll and apologize. Surprisingly, SHE CAME BACK WITH THE SAME ROLL THAT HAD A STRAND OF HAIR (she just took away that hair from the roll) and explained that was a string from fish... She even tried to say it out loud to let other customers be aware that was something from the fish..... I still cannot believe she played dead and defended herself when that was obviously a strand of hair... Oh Come on! At least an apology?! I did not make a scene in the restaurant.. Instead of that, I planned to spread the world through Yelp!
author: Candy C.

description: Wayyyyy yummy. So quaint and delicious. The mango rolls are my favorite. Try to grab a seat at the bar to watch the chef work. Not overpriced and still a lovely shop. A great spot to go before the movies.
author: Carly K.

description:
Gave Wayo another go, so glad I did.
I think the trick with Wayo is knowing what to order, not every single item is amazing (big no to the spicy tuna) but a majority are top notch.

I still can't get over how good the nigiri is here. Also, the shrimp tempura roll is mighty nom-able. 

Go to Wayo, get the Maguro Nigiri and Tempura roll for sure!
author: Rachel R.

description:
If all you want is great sushi in a relaxing environment then this is your place! 

This is a place where people come to enjoy sushi...not rush in & out! Don't let other reviews push you away...it's worth the wait!

Fresh, friendly...can't be beat! 

Great first date place too.
author: J B.

description: I completely agree with all the other reviewers about how LONG it takes to get food here. These peopleare completely incompetent. They had 7 people tonight - most already eating - and I was told it would be a 40 minut wait. 40 minutes! Have been here 3 times -a nd each time the same thing. Once I was told 45 minutes with 6 people in the whole place. It is a husband and wife team I think - or father daughter. They are too cheap to hire any help. I find their apparent penny pinching to be very disrespectful to customers. I love to support mom and pop type places - but this place need to be shut down.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Don't bother with any of the rolls - stick to the nigiri or sashimi... and if you get the nigiri, eat the fish off the top on it's own, and then the rice after. The fish quality is so good and fresh, it's a waste to put it in a roll with rice and other stuff to dilute the taste! My favorites in order: 1) Scallops, 2) Yellow tail, 3) Salmon. They all taste like butter and melt on your tongue.

Sit at the bar and watch the owner make all the sushi. He's super darling.
author: audrey k.

description:
I go to Wayo everytime I am in San Francisco. It is a hole in the wall and service is very slow, but I love this place! The fish tastes very fresh and I love that the tuna in the spicy tuna roll is whole pieces, not the chopped up mix that you get at most places. Wayo also uses real crab instead of immitation grab, which makes for muhc better California Rolls. Prices are very reasonable for sushi. Wayo is cozy, but lacks any type of atmosphere - if you're looking for a fun place to go with friends on a weekend night, try Osaka. 

Make sure you're not in a rush, grab a table by the widow, and enjoy some of the best sushi in San Fran! Note that Wayo doesn't serve cocktails, just Sake.
author: Cindy S.

description:
Tasty appetizers, fresh sushi, friendly staff, calm, quiet and cozy atmosphere.  I don't ask for much in a sushi place, but Wayo's got what I need.

Started with some miso soup to warm up on a rainy SF night, then some cucumber cucumber salad to cleanse the palate a bit.   Then came the spicy tuna salad.  The tuna was fresh & delicious, and the salad had a nice wasabi/sesame dressing with some sliced avocado, quite good.

I never order the California roll, usually can't stand it.  But the lady asked if it was real snow crab or nasty imitation.  It was real crab, so she ordered some, along with the tuna and shitake rolls.  Best California roll I've had in a long time.  Not mixed with a butt load of cream cheese or whatever, you could really taste the fresh crab.

I had Uni, the Unagi special roll and scallop nigiri.  I never see scallop in other sushi joints, so I had to have it.  Scallops were fresh as could be, smelled great, tasted great.  Unagi special roll was fine, a bit too complex, I should probably lay off the special rolls for a while.  And the Uni was a nice texture, flavorfully marinaded it seemed.

Moreover, Wayo is just a nice small sushi place to hang out.  I'll definitely be coming here more often.
author: Jonathan B.

description: Really fresh, great food. Came back for a late dinner and the miso soup was spot on. Very fresh nigiri and the rolls were great too. If you want really great sushi this is a great spot in the pac heights area highly recommend
author: Ribec F.

description:
THIS PLACE DESERVES MUCH MORE THAN 4 STARS!

Anyways this place is really small and hard to spot but please find it (Its right next to a Starbucks)! 
As soon as you walk in the chef lets you know itll be a 30-45 minute wait for sushi. Be grateful and have a seat, I promise you itll be worth the wait. We loved it so much we even went again before we went back home.

Any sushi you get is delicious. It takes so long because he takes his time with every single dish and treats every roll like its favorite. If you sit by the bar you can see what I mean, he stares it down and puts "love" into the sushi. You will not get someone so attentive to their work as this place Stay away from the california rolls though, they are amazing but why would you want something you can get at your local super market?
We loved the spicy tuna and my favorite was the cream cheese/crab rolls. Ive never had cream cheese on sushi but it is now a favorite.

When I hear someone is going to San Francisco I will make sure they stop by at this place if they are sushi fans.
author: Dark C.

description:
I walked in just wanting some solid sashimi, it didn't have to be memorable...I was just craving sashimi.

I was pleasantly surprised. We walked in slightly 7PM on a Tuesday night and sat right down. There were maybe two other tables with customers, totaling about 6 people. I think we came at a good time because by the time we left, all the tables and 1/2 the bar were full. The shop was not well staffed, having only one waitress and one chef, but they were working quickly and with dedication. It would be difficult for them to keep up when the restaurant gets crowded, but at least I know they're not loitering around as it is clear they care about their customers as they race around the restaurant. In any case, I walked in expecting slow service and I think that's the mentality you have to walk into the place with to have a good experience (i.e. don't go when you're in a rush or need to make a movie).  In our case, we were served promptly and had great service. 

Now onto the food - we enjoyed our sashimi so much that we added two nigiri orders to our meal:. 

OK items; miso soup ($2/bowl), edamame ($3.50 I think), shiro maguro nigiri ($5/2 pieces - added at the end). The shiro maguro was fresh but had a slightly mushy consistency that some fish have that I did not enjoy.

Tasty!: hamachi sashimi ($12/6 pieces), sake nigiri ($5/2 pieces), unagi nigiri ($5/2 pieces), saba nigiri ($4/2 pieces - added at the end)


- Hamachi was melt in your mouth delicious, I would definitely get this again! 6 pieces cut medium sized (then again I compare that to tekka which is crazy in size) served on a little mound of wakame salad. 
- Sake nigiri - I really liked the ratio of fish to rice on all of their nigiri, it wasn't too much of one or the other and in this case both items were solid. The salmon had a very pleasant flavor and texture. 
- Unagi nigiri - the unagi was served warm and was very soft and delicious. nom nom nom.
- Saba nigiri - i love the strong flavor of saba and thought that this was very tasty 

The price seemed very reasonable and we're looking forward to coming back soon.
author: Karin L.

description:
Super small restaurant. Maybe 4 or 5 tables plus counter seating. 

The sashimi is really fresh. The rolls are just okay, nothing special. Very slow service. Our order took 30 minutes to come out. I think they only have one sushi chef. Be prepared to wait for awhile. 

Id come back for the sashimi only.
author: CL S.

description: Superior fish and rice. Kinda makes you paranoid that you're gonna wait forever for food, but the food is GOOD.
author: Sarah H.

description: Soooo yummy and what all the positive folks said held true. The only bummer is we should have ordered more at the start because we had somewhere to be and couldn't wait for a second order and I wanted MORE! We will be back for sure.
author: Donna W.

description: Delicious sushi at a great price. There's nothing flashy about this place; they just serve quality, fresh ingredients with a great attitude and prices that can't be beat. Not a bad ambiance either. We had the dynamite, California, dragon, mango/salmon, and unagi/avocado rolls, all of which were delicious. Top that off with some perfectly salted edamame and a large hot sake, and we had the perfect meal. It does take awhile to get your food because they're short staffed, but to me, that was kind of part of the charm. I'll be back for sure!
author: Michelle H.

description:
I love this place! It's a hole in the wall Moms and Pops place that serves really fresh fish and always feels homey. The Alaskan Roll is great and all the Mango Specialty Rolls hit the spot.

My husband and I used to live pretty close to this place and had to move. We still try to go but haven't been going as much. We miss it!
author: Ley M.

description: The sashimi is amazing! It's fresh and melts in your mouth. We also ordered nigiri sushi and neither of us likes it so we ordered more sashimi.
author: Erica S.

description: Do yourself a favor and stop in to Wayo sushi. This little hole in the wall off van ness is quite unassuming but completely adorable and quaint. The sushi is no frills classic, on point. Prepare to wait a little for sushi because the man behind the delicacy is a one man show. Wayo is a family owned business for 20+ years. Our favorites were the brown rice Cali roll (yes brown rice, do it!) and the spicy tuna salad.
author: Ali M.

description:
This is a super nice hole in the wall sushi place. I'm not going to say its as good as Kiss Seafood but you won't have to jump through the all the hassles of trying to get a table either.

Its usually just the sushi chef and a waitress so your food is going to come out slowly but the service is attentive in every other manner.

The fish is fresh and some of the best I've had anywhere outside of Japan. Sometimes if you sit at the bar you'll get to see the chef prep a larger piece of fish slowly and masterfully when he runs out of previously prepped fish. Its quite amazing to watch. At most other sushi places you'll only see them cut up the flanks of fish that have already been removed. Here you can see the chef cut up a whole piece of tuna.

Don't come here for a quick meal.
author: Will S.

description:
This is a lovely mom-and-pop sushi joint; no frills, no loud music, nothing but yummy Japanese food.

3 solid stars for reasonably priced sushi (read inexpensive), a menu of rolls that rivals all the other Star Sushi SF Spots (including lots of mango rolls now that it's summer), and your typical classy Japanese service (read unobtrusive, efficient). 

1 solid star for brown rice option with all sushi: just ask.

Give it a try, all the Wayo!
author: Meredith R.

description: I went yesterday just before closing and order the dragon roll, dynamite roll & salmon nigiri. The salmon seemed cut funny but everything was delicious. The sake was priced appropriately ($3.50 for a small). I didn't feel rushed either which was nice. You could tell it is the neighborhood sushi bar most of the patrons seemed to be regulars.
author: Candy E.

description:
I was in love with the curved bar and cushy stools from the second I stepped inside.  

We asked the nice lady what was good that day, followed her directions, and were rewarded with delicious, generous slabs of fish.  And it's clear that the focus is on the fish.  The rolls are pretty basic (which I consider a good thing) and sake's not their strong suit--you can pick from "hot", "cold", or "unfiltered"--but the cold sake was pretty good.  

All that and it's affordable, too.  A great new find.
author: Dana S.

description: My favorite sushi spot in the city. Tiny, busy, you wait longer than average for your sushi but it worth it. Owners are really nice and sincere. Always fun to sit at the bar and watch the chef preparing rolls. Place is pretty clean as well.
author: Lyra S.

description: Solid, no-frills authentic sushi from a mom and pops place. Everything is good here. Try the scallops nigiri for buttery sweet goodness.
author: Quan P.

description: Great sushi. Very fresh and authentic seeming. The mango sushi was delicious. My friend says the mackerel sashimi had a nice texture. The pickled ginger was also fresh. A fun place to visit!
author: Jessica F.

description:
Sat down right away on a Sunday night at 8pm but had to wait 50 minutes for our sushi. And then it wasn't that good - rolls had too much rice and wasabi on the inside with no warning 

On the positive side: sushi was fresh and cheap: $26 for 3 5-piece rolls, a miso soup and seaweed salad
author: Rebecca G.

description: 1 guy making the sushi and a waitress doing everything else...
author: Monica S.

description:
Quaint, traditional, Mom & Pop type of joint...my kind of place.  The fish was fresh.  The aforementioned Mom & Pop were of the sweet variety...simply there to slice a nice piece of fish for your enjoyment.  

We didn't have to wait for a seat, but the place was at 70% capacity, so we did have to exercise some patience before we could gorge ourselves.  I suppose that's what company is for...company, and beer.
author: Ling C.

description: Looks like from reading the other reviews I am in the minority but arrived on what seemed to be a pretty quite Saturday night and the first think the one and only sushi chef said to me is it will be 45  minute wait.  Only three tables and 10 people in the whole place?? Really  So decided to wait since I was there and while waiting watched him turn away four other people telling them if the 45 min wait. It was painful to watch how slow this chef was with zero since of urgency.  Instead of maybe I'm sorry for the wait it was more of a case of, maybe I can just talk them out of coming in.
author: Dakota P.

description: We went here because of the good Yelp reviews and were not disappointed. The selection was great and prices were unbelievably cheap. The service was also top-notch. I'd highly recommend it to friends.
author: Matthew J.

description:
Ordered takeout from Wayo on a Friday night. As others have mentioned, its a small joint, with just one guy who makes the sushi and a woman who takes orders. We tried calling ahead to order but they didn't answer the phone. We walked in to order, and they told us it would be 40 minutes for pick up. (By now, we were picking up on a vibe that they definitely don't want people to order.) My girlfriend was ready to ditch the whole idea but I thought we should still try it. 

We got: Tuna Nigiri, Alaska Roll (salmon and avocado), California Roll (crab and avocado), Tuna Maki, and the Spicy Tuna Salad. The tuna salad was awesome - huge chunks of fresh tuna. The nigiri melted in your mouth, and the pieces were huge. We really enjoyed all of the rolls. It was worth the wait.

Not a huge deal, but the online menu prices are a little different than the actual prices. It was still affordable, but everything was about 2 dollars more than it was advertised online. 

Will definitely be back to Wayo next time we have a sushi craving.
author: Alden Q.

description:
I dropped in here with my mother after she was in the City for a Tupperware party.

That's right. My mother's June Cleaver.

Wayo was really the closest restaurant I could see myself enjoying. 

And I did.

The service was prompt and quick, the tea was warm but not scalding and my avocado maki was incredibly fresh.

My only negative would be that the place is small, so for large groups I wouldn't drag people here.

All in all I'd be back.
author: Meg T.

description:
-- Update 11/6/07

Been back a couple times now and they've been consistently awesome and so damn cheap. Love it, bumping to 5 stars (from 4). Last time I dropped in I had the chance to speak with the owner/chef, what a nice guy. He has been in business for 19 years that is some serious sushi dedication!

-- Original review

Amazingly good and affordable sushi!

Nigiri quality was really high, fish was so soft and smooth and the rice was nicely cooked. Be careful the sushi chef puts a serious dab of wasabi on the rice, yum and it cleared my sinuses, awesome! 

Rolls were excellent too. They had a number of mango roll specials which I highly recommend you try (if available).  Their mango slices were perfectly ripened...ah delicious.

Complaints? 

Yeah very slow service, it seemed to take forever to get our order taken and another eternity before food started showing up. Ambiance was nothing special, the place is clean (including the bathroom) but it's very mom-and-pop so don't bring a first date here unless she/he is a sushi aficionado :)
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Quick and easy bite but nothing to rave about. If you have some energy in the tank, walk 10-15 mins and check out Sanraku (Sutter St and Taylor st). Perhaps make a quick call before walking there to check for space. 

I found the sushi at Wayo quite expensive but if you're willing to pay, it is fresh and good tasting.

Not a great date night location as it's positioned on the fairly unromantic Van Ness Ave.

In 3 words I would describe the ambience as pleasant, quiet and simple.
author: Amy M.

description: Cute place with a limited menu but given the plethora of other options in SF, I wouldn't eat here again. The fish was too warm, the oshitashi was too cold, and we never actually got plates which was odd.  Also the chop sticks were a very poor quality. I know that may not be a huge deal, but it's important for a sushi restaurant, in my opinion, to keep your chop sticks splinter-free.  But hey, we didn't get sick, so 3 stars.
author: Athos K.

description:
I met my brother and his new bride here for lunch.  Working across the street I was lucky to grab a table when they first opened.  

The restaurant is small with limited tables.  
The food is super fresh and delicious.  The service was great as well but the food was the highlight.  

I will definitely return!
author: Chris P.

description: Hidden gem! Finally found my low key, high quality, neighborhood sushi spot!! Do yourself a favor and get a roll with brown rice...you won't regret it!!
author: C L.

description:
I loved Wayo Sushi!  Incredibly fresh fish and very reasonable prices!  It's a smaller place, though, so it can get crowded, and the limited staff, while friendly, is sometimes busy and consequently inattentive.  

Will definitely be back soon!   By far the best rolls for ~$6 I've found!
author: Greg B.

description: A very small and simple real Japanese restaurant. The rolls are always perfect. Because the place is so small sometimes there is a lengthy wait for a seat or food but it's worth it.
author: Serina J.

description: I'm not sure what these 5 star reviews are all about. Came in for a lunch a few minutes after noon. The door was wide open (they open for lunch at noon). I was the first one there. As I walking in, I was met with: "I'm not ready yet. Another 5-10 min". That came from their chef. I stood there in a loss and wasn't sure if I should go away or what. Finally, I was invited to sit down. I ordered a couple of sushi rolls and a salad. The sushi seemed to be very fresh but completely lacked flavor. I mean completely tasteless. The chef might consider seasoning the fish that he cooks before it goes in the sushi or use a sous. I'm a seafood and sushi junky. These sushi were so bad that I had to have a corrective experience and had sushi for dinner (not here of course). The place also smells of oil that they use for deep frying. Btw, they raised their prices so the menus pics that you see on yelp are a dollar short. So add a dollar to the cost of every roll. At the end, paid $25 for lunch and left pretty unhappy.
author: Mikey S.

description:
Had dinner here tonight and it's a small shop that offers a variety of rolls. They also give you the selection of regular white rice vs. brown rice. Be warned tho: brown rice might be healthy for you but it does make the rolls taste different. 

Very cost effective and fairly easy to get parking.
author: Cynthia C.

description: Enjoyed a quiet sushi dinner at Wayo Sushi last weekend and was pleasantly surprised.  Not only was the sashimi fresh and rolls very satisfying, but the price was very unexpected.  This is a sushi restaurant right off Van Ness with a prime location and every dish was reasonably priced.  There is only one sushi chef, which means you might experience longer wait times but it was worth it.  If you're in a hurry, I wouldn't recommend stopping here for a quick bite but if you have the time, DO stop by for dinner!
author: Cynthia V.

description:
This really feels like a 4.5 star joint but without that option I lean towards 4. 

The sushi is good, not great, not awful but solidly good.

The decor is shabby sheik I believe.

The service is good as well. 

The pricing is amazing! 

If your nearby this is the best bang for your buck and feels like a date spot.
author: Joseph M.

description: Went here for dinner on a Sunday night. This is like a small town diner, a long 3 sided counter and 4-5 small (2 person) tables. Nothing fancy, but solid sushi. If I lived here this would be a regular stop for lunch or a quick dinner. Small but adequate saki list.
author: Prescott B.

description:
BEST sushi in the bay! Always a must have when I'm in SF. I like that I can order my rolls with brown rice. The owners are kind, friendly and efficient. The value and price 
are the best in the bay! On average a roll is around $6 and up.

Plan ahead as you may be waiting. The sushi chef runs a solo show but it's all worth the wait. The fish is very fresh and the specials are fun, like a scallop and mango roll.

Never a disappointment. Wayo Sushi can't be beat!
author: D T.

description:
This place is SLOW. I've come here twice and they'll have maybe 3 parties of 2 and they'll say the sushi will take 45 minutes to prepare. The place is a husband-wife team and I remember having a very hard time to get the waitress's attention to just order a drink. 

For the food, the sushi is reasonably well made and tasty.
author: Amy M.

description: Service was good. Place was small, but clean. The salmon salad was underwhelming. The salmon tastes fresh, it was just cubed on a plate with baby romaine and dressing. The dragon, rainbow, etc rolls were average. I've tasted better for less.
author: Therese P.

description: Great place to grab some quick sushi after the gym! Quick and fast service, and also great for protein after a 24 hour workout :)
author: Thach N.

description:
Since this is walking distance from my place, I've been eager to check this place out. Every single time I try a new sushi bar, I always order a rainbow roll. Because a rainbow roll typically has a variety of fishes. And it allows me to taste which fish is fresh. This was my first time having brown rice in the roll. Perhaps it was an off night, but I was disappointed that the fish did not taste that fresh to me. I unfortunately ordered salmon sashimi. It was ok. Overall it was like having sushi bought at the grocery store. In fact, I think I would have preferred Whole Foods. 
Customer service was friendly. And despite the mediocre sushi, I most likely will return simply because of its convenient location. I also like how big the sushi bar is. But next time I will be ordering cooked Americanized rolls with shrimp tempura in it or just a chicken teriyaki.
author: Myra M.

description: There's only one person making the sushi and one person waiting the tables so it took a bit of time for our orders to be fulfilled. The sushi was really yummy and the place is operated by Japanese people, which is almost obsolete these days I feel. Very reasonably priced as well so it's a reliable place for good sushi and not breaking the bank.
author: G C.

description: I came to know this place as it was listed in my hotel restaurants list.  Good food at Very reasonable price, not more than 25 seats.  Looks like many faces are familiar to the Chef.  Food is as good as any expensive restaurant.
author: Sreeni K.

description:
Took the beautiful here and OMG, best salmon sashimi I've ever had hands down!

Small place, no waiting area, long wait, and no real parking, we were lucky to get serviced fast, without any wait, and ample parking.  

The rolls weren't were in the $5+ range.  They do put some wasabi in every rolls.  

Dynamite Tuna - okay, lacked any real flavor.
House roll - just okay
Salmon Sashimi - not wet or slimey, super dense and great texture.  The flavor of the salmon is just great, no soy sauce or wasabi needed.
Mango Hamachi - interesting mix, the mango wasn't too sweet, so it complimented the hamachi fine.

My recommendations: skip the rolls, go straight to the sashimi!
author: Bobby L.

description:
Yum! Pretty gd deal for assorted sushi. Substituted amaebi for ebi, def liked my substitution! I only remembered that I'd bookmarked this place for mango rolls after we'd dined, pity. It's a nice small place, surprising that it wasn't too crowded around 630 on Sunday but it definitely started filling up when we left around 745-8!

Unagi nigiri was definitely delicious. The other fishes were pretty gd too (sake, mackerel, hamachi, maguro tuna) and octopus was not bad as well, not too chewy. Sushi rice was okay, as I recall.
author: Clarissa L.

description: Wonderful, fresh, simple sushi! I must admit, I live in the same building, but this sushi place is the bomb! The only downfall is you do have to wait. Sometimes it can take 1 1/2 hours for sushi!! However, this is obviously a family owned restaurant and the quality is superb. Who doesn't want fresh mango and salmon?? Sooo good!
author: Rosie N.

description:
Slow Service because it is a  Mom and Pop run shop, with a pretty good amount of seating.  The sushi chef is hustling the ENTIRE time to keep up.

Put your order in all at once otherwise you may end up getting your food 30 min apart.

Might be my favorite sushi spot in the city, but only been here once.  Gotta come here a few more times to test their consistency.
author: Steven F.

description: Randomly walked across this place while looking for sushi and found the best sushi spot in the city. You'll have to wait because it's run by just two folks but it's well worth it. Sublime.
author: Nick R.

description: From Yelp reviews I was expecting more from this place. The wait time was shorter than I expected even though 3/4 tables were taken as well as several spots at the bar - probably 15-20 minutes. But when the sushi arrived, they were not what we expected. First, the rolls are 6 small pieces, typically the two of us are happy with sharing 4 rolls, here we had to order 6 and we left still somewhat hungry. Second, the only memorable roll of these six was salmon and cream cheese special, the rest were ok but not something to return to - and that's after a whole day of wandering through the city.
author: Mariya M.

description: THIS WILL BE THE BEST SUSHI YOU WILL EVER HAVE! The texture of the fish is so perfect and the rice is nice and fluffy and done soooooooooo well. The chef is a little old japanese man of wisdom who seems as if he's done this his whole life. I always thought sushi tasted the same until I tried wayo sushi it was MINDBLOWING! The only problem is the hours and size of the place it is very tiny with not too many hours but if your ever in the area and want sushi, defientily go for it!
author: Ariana L.

description:
I'm not sure how this place has 4 stars. I ordered a tempura roll and a Salmon/cream cheese roll. The tempura roll had lettuce in it that tasted like it had been soaked in wasabi- it was really spicy. The salmon/cream cheese roll was mediocre. The list of specialty rolls was fairly short.

The rolls were fairly cheap but not worth stopping in.
author: Chelsea S.

description:
Sorry but just because it's cheap doesn't mean it deserves any slack.

The wait is long. There is only ONE chef and ONE waitress. 

They had a special salmon skin roll for $6. We tried it and we thought we got the wrong thing. The "skin" was a sliver of salmon skin that was barely visible. I thought it would have some fish in it.. nope.. a small black piece of burnt skin wrapped around rice and nori. It was horrible!

The spicy tuna avacado salad was pretty good but was lacking something.. maybe a dressing?

The cream cheese/salmon roll was very good but they cheated by adding so much cream cheese how could it not be good??

The mango rolls were weird. 

The wasabi tasted like horseradish. 

The brown rice didn't "stick" and was falling off the roll before I even ate it.

Was very cheap though so I don't feel totally jipped.  

Went on a Saturday evening. The place was half full. The only delay was the wait for the ONE chef to prepare our food.
author: Kathy S.

description:
The fish is the best fish I've ever had.  I even gave in to my boyfriend's demands that I try the scallop (I usually HATE raw scallop).  But this...this scallop was buttery, magical, deliciousness.  

In addition, I had my usual eel, tuna, and albacore.  All stellar  My boyfriend is a big fan of an assortment of fish, so he had the chef's choice.  He said it was outstanding and a great deal at $40.  

However, yes, there is only one chef.  So...you wait.  There couldn't have been more than eight people in the restaurant when we showed up at 8:30 on a Friday night.  We were immediately told it would be at least half an hour before we could get our sushi.  However, due to the reviews, and the fact that we knew we'd wait ahead of time, we went ahead and waited. And we're glad we did.

Also, we're big fans of engaging and chatting with sushi chefs.  We like to hear their opinions on what's the freshest/best and what we can pass on.  We also like hearing their stories.  This chef...is not like that.  

While the fish was outstanding, I'd still rather go to a place with slightly less stellar fish, but with a great atmosphere.
author: Shannon B.

description:
In one word?

Fresh.

In two words?

Hella fresh.

Three?

Fresh to death.

Wayo is on a relatively dead stretch of Van Ness and when you walk in there's two dozen seats, about half of which are at the bar. There were only two people working - the chef and a server but luckily we came in late enough on a Friday night that we were seated right away.

Everything on the menu is reasonably priced and all the fish put in front of me was super fresh, including some of the best mackerel sashimi I've ever had. Wayo Sushi isn't trying to reinvent the wheel and they stick mostly to tried and true rolls but you won't care about the lack of originality when the sushi comes to your table. All the nigiri and sashimi I had was excellent, and though I've had better constructed rolls in my days of sushi eating, they stayed together fine and the quality of the fish was so good I barely noticed. And while we didn't partake of any, we noted that brown rice sushi was an option.

One of the only drawbacks is that service is slow, as there only seems to be one guy making sushi behind the bar but you can take the edge off your hunger by ordering some miso soup, edamame, and sake - all of which come to the table quickly. If you don't like hearing your neighbors' conversation, don't sit at the bar as it's pretty tight.

The bottom line is if you want incredibly fresh sushi, come to Wayo and you won't be disappointed.
author: Dirty D.

description: The ultimate in quality sushi and absolute value!  Ambience and owners are very nice.   It's how eating sushi should be without paying $18 per roll.  Any of the mango rolls are very tasty.  Should be 10 stars.
author: Cory M.

description:
How do you satiate your hunger before a high energy J-rock concert?  Head straight across the street from the Regency and you'll find the answer.

The dive is fairly small, but authentic.  The couple running the place are actually Japanese, and that fact alone made the sushi taste all the sweeter.  I'll be back again for my next concert at the ballroom.
author: Lorrayne L.

description:
Was quite impressed with this authentic Japanese sushi/sashimi joint. There are a couple of these types of places - small sushi restaurants run by a Japanese couple that is fairly inconspicuous unless you know what you're looking for. 

If you want rolls, you can find those at many other places. If you can appreciate sashimi, come here. Had the saba, shiro maguro, hamachi, and salmon. All were great.
author: Bern H.

description:
Small, intimate sushi establishment right on the bustling Van Ness street...easy to miss but totally worth coming to. Nothing fancy about it but the food more than makes up for the plain atmosphere. There wasn't much seating but luckily we didn't have to wait for a table on a Saturday night. 

They did pre-warn us that there was only one sushi chef working so the wait for the food might take longer than usual which we were fine with. Not a ton of options to choose from but they did have daily specials written on a whiteboard by the door. Prices were definitely reasonable and I really liked their green tea too! 

salmon sashimi ($9.50) - Came with 6 pretty large pieces of salmon and a side salad. The fish was super fresh and not too lean...had some fat which I like. Melted in my mouth...so delish! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/f6G4fFuwx_hQOMxvZPmqjw?select=VbdTX3WJ9JLPfRq-btSmTA)

sea fairy roll ($9.50) - Cali roll topped with raw scallop. This was my first time having raw scallop and I loved it! It wasn't fishy tasting at all...very soft and had a nice contrast with the tobiko on top. My favorite roll of the meal!

mango spicy tuna roll special ($5) - One of the daily specials...a simple roll containing just tuna and a piece of mango in the middle. The mango was sweet and ripe and went really well with the spiciness of the tuna.

dynamite roll ($5) - Spicy tuna and avocado topped with tobiko. Just a hint of spiciness but they didn't skimp on the fish. I liked the creamy avocado and pops of tobiko. Yum!

(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/f6G4fFuwx_hQOMxvZPmqjw?select=th52u0Ewk46bkOqR_l9YkQ)

The sushi rolls had a perfect rice to filling ratio, they didn't really fall apart when bit in half, and the sushi rice was just sticky enough but not mushy. They weren't the prettiest or biggest rolls I've seen, but were made well and above all were extremely fresh! The food filled the both of us up too. Our waitress was sweet and checked on us often...she also didn't kick us out when we sat for an extra hour just chatting.

I will be coming back!
author: Karen Y.

description:
I almost don't want to write a review because it's so small and can be really crowded if you hit it at a bad time. This place rocks!! I discovered this years back when I was pregnant and craving salmon nigiri big time. Fellow yelpers said that they had the freshest fish so I gave it a shot and fell in love. The menu isn't fancy schmancy, but it's all fresh and so tasty. 

The highlight of this place is the unagi nigiri. They serve it hot so it melts in your mouth. Wayo's unagi has ruined other placed for me because now i want it hot - not all cold and rubbery like other sushi joints can dish out. Whenever I go we get a few orders of unagi, plus a bunch of other rolls, walk out of the place stuffed and our bill is pretty cheap.

I love wayo!!

Be warned, the service can be slow since it's just a husband and wife duo, and they do the orders as they come in. But, it's well worth the wait.
author: Liz C.

description:
Cleanliness : tip top! That's why they have 98/100.
Really authentic Japanese food. The chef was really dedicated in keeping the sushi fresh by wrapping it in plastic every single time he had to work on another sushi. Must go!!!!!
author: Kexy K.

description:
I'm going to make it short:

The food was worth the 1 hour wait!

Everything was sooo fresh!

Will be back again for Sure!!!
author: Vickie Z.

description:
I have been in a few times and just like so many others decided I didn't want to wait 45 minutes for sushi so I left.
Last night I dcided I didn't have anywhere I had to be so I'd go ahead and wait. Sure enough the wait was at least 45 minutes but I endured it with a nice cup of green tea and miso soup and found that the sushi was definitely worth the wait. I loved it.
I had a few rolls - the california roll with scallop, seared tuna with ponzu sauce, salmon and avocado and tuna with cream cheese. I had actually ordered my rolls and was a bit miffed they didn't have my favorite, salmon and cream cheese until I started looking around and saw the white board that had a WHOLE BUNCH of cream cheese rolls and the mango rolls everyone raves about. 
The sushi was a dream. Probably not the best sushi I've ever had but totally spot on and much better than I expected. I love wasabi and they are not shy with it here. Some bites of my rolls induced the fire in the nose sensation that only a blast of wasabi can pull off. Kind of like food coaine I guess (I have never tried coke nor will I but the blast of heat in the upper nose must produce a similar sensation followed by euphoria).  
The atmosphere also is something I quickly grew to like a lot. Couples and small groups were there having a great time and no one seemed to be bothered by the wait. Situated on Van Ness there was plenty of street traffic and passersby to evoke the fantasy of being in busy Tokyo. 
I am a little befuddled by the owners' insistence on not hiring more help. They must have turned away a dozen would be diners during my visit. It seems to me filling the restaurant every night which they easily could would mroe than pay for the extra help. I don't quite get why they insist doing everything themselves. I can see the sushi chef / owner (?) takes a lot of pride in crafting his sushi and he probably doesn't trust that someone else could do it the same. This kind of reminds of Jiro of "Jiro Dreams of Sushi" fame. I understand that drive and desire for perfection which is such a big part of Japanese culture, but this is the States and I say if there's an opportunity to make more money by hiring a few extra hands the ROI would pay in spades. 
I left with a smile on my face and a new favorite spot in my hood. Can't wait to go back when I have a little extra time to burn.
author: Matt H.

description:
I still find this place very affordable (as far as SUSHI goes) and maintains a very no frills sushi bar atmosphere.  It is a small neighborhood joint.  I've been here a few times with a few people and alone.  Service is always courteous, not always fast (especially, if there is a crowd), but the sushi is good.  The Sushi Chef is Japanese and so is the waitress (his wife?).  The fish is fresh.  There is not an extravagant list of rolls, so don't expect that.  There is not a big menu, so don't expect that, either.

They offer "brown rice" sushi.  Oh...and yes, they have vegetarian options, too (shiitake roll, mango roll...etc).  East meets West sushi without too many crazily obnoxious rolls.

For enough food to keep me full for 3 days (and a beer) = $25.
author: Hiromi N.

description: This is the best sushi/sashimi place in the city. Run by an older Japanese couple for the past 20 years in a tiny space at the bottom of a traditional SF apartment block, the fish is fresh and delicious, everything is made wonderfully, the hot sake is hot, the rice is what Japanese rice is supposed to be. Get there early or don't bother, and it's totally worth it.
author: Tasha D.

description: I always ALWAYS get the mango crab salad.  so fresh, crisp, and delicious. the wait is always long and gets packed fast.  again, one of the few good sushi restaurants in SF
author: Christina K.

description: One of my favorite neighborhood spots. They have very fresh, delicious fish, and the atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming. This spot isn't good if you like fancy/complicated american style sushi, but if you're looking for high quality simple fare it's a great place to try. It's run by a husband and wife team with no other help, so expect to wait 45 min once you've sat down for your order to be ready, but it's worth it. My personal faves is the snow leopard roll.
author: Ash S.

description:
The food was good. Fish was fresh, rolls were tasty - good sushi!
really good salmon sashimi, albacore was great as well. Spicy rolls are REALLY spicy :)
Solid 4.

Non food related review:
Place is super small and slow. about 30-40 minutes to get the food
author: I B.

description:
Small, mellow and quiet restaurant with excellent fresh fish at a very good value. The apps are great (perfect miso soup, delicious cucumber/octopus salad) and the sashimi is top-notch. Wonderful service as well.
The maki (rolls) are rather less successful, unfortunately. For my taste, they have too much rice and are under-seasoned. I still go to Kiji at 22nd & Guerrero for rolls even though it's across the city. Also, as others have noted there can be a ~30 min wait for your fish.
author: Teo W.

description:
What a great find!
I was pleasantly surprised at how fresh the sushi was. You can't beat the price too! For this sushi quality, I expected $10-15 an order. However, most dishes were about $5-8. My favorite was the hamachi. Overall, the menu is nothing fancy. It's just simple, good sushi!

I suggest sitting at the sushi bar. Watch the sushi chef in action. He's a man of few words and so is his helper. The place is very small but very intimate. I like it. I can actually have a decent conversation without shouting. Service is great! Never needed to ask for more tea or water. Food came fast. 

I hear it can get crowded here but when I went it was half full. No problem finding a seat even during dinner time. 

Don't forget the daily specials near the entrance. They are worth trying. 

If you want good sushi at reasonable prices, then try Wayo!
author: Molly T.

description:
It's about time I update my Wayo review...I eat here at least once a week and usually get the spicy tuna salad, so much so that they know me on sight and remember what I order. The fish selection isn't huge but what they have is fresh and CHEAP. They also do a great cucumber salad, seaweed salad, and the special mango rolls are a fun way to mix things up a bit.

It's a mom and pop operation so service can be a bit slow but it's always friendly and definitely worth the wait. Whether you're in the hood for a movie at AMC or a show at the Regency or just in the mood to try a new sushi joint, you really should give Wayo a shot.
author: phil h.

description:
I haven't been to the actual location. The bf picks it up for me to-go. I like their to-go system because they are put on giant trays and not pushed together. The wait is usually about 30 min according to him, I think next time I'm going to try calling in the order first. 

Good fish. I generally get sashimi and he gets rolls. All taste as they should.
