Overall a good go to spot if you're looking for "quick" sushi.

BTW I've never been to a sushi place that wasn't a wait, that was good. Madfish is an example of a place that serves sushi fast but it doesn't taste or look good. Sushi rolling is a trade and takes time. I'd rather wait awhile and get good/pretty food than rolls that are falling apart as I'm dipping them in my soy sauce. :)
author: Natalie D.

description:
Best sushi in SF and friendly waiters/ chef.
Could use more seats and better atmosphere.
author: Erin G.

description:
Really good food, very fresh fish, but be prepared to wait if you don't arrive first (literally). Run by just two people, who are very nice I might add. But they should think about getting some help to support the volume of business they get!

Definitely not a place for the impatient or hungry. I was almost one of them.

The salmon sashimi is delicious. I also got two orders of rock'n roll. The eel and avo hit the spot!!

I am always an advocate of supporting small local businesses. My family is in the same business and it is hard work. So treat staff with respect!
author: Jeanne C.

description: Amazing sushi and very affordable. It's small so it's fit for couples or small groups. One person does it all with one waitress for help. I absolutely enjoyed the experience.
author: Rassil S.

description:
I definitely do not think this place deserves 4 stars...wow seriously?  I came here for dinner with some friends expecting some really awesome sushi since it's rated pretty high.  Unfortunately, the fish is just so so.  I got some pretty bad cut of salmon, although the other nigiri's I got were ok.  The thing that ruined all my sushi and the one roll I got was the sushi rice.  Ugh it was overly sticky and too firmly pressed together.  Not only that, they're on the big side for nigiri.  I ate some of my nigiri without the rice after the first few and the roll was difficult to finish because of it.  At least the waitress was very friendly and the food came out quick.  

There other menu items might be better but I won't be giving this place a second chance because they only have 1 sushi chef, who in my opinion is very subpar.
author: Steve l.

description:
My favorite sushi place, hands-down. 

It is a no-frills hole in the wall, so if you are looking for a chic atmosphere, this is not your place. If, however, you want cheap (~$5 for specialty rolls like the spicy tuna mango roll and ~$9 for a rainbow roll stuffed with real crab and topped with large chunks of fresh ahi, salmon, and yellowtail), delicious, high quality sushi from a highly-trained Japanese sushi chef, there is nowhere better. (Note: Because the only chef is the owner, be prepared to wait for your sushi... It is worth it.)
author: Alex W.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, mostly because it's a mom & pop, my friend's vouched for it, and because when you walk in the decor reminds you of a nice local place that you want to be your next favorite sushi bar.

Things started looking bleak when I saw her microwave my shrimp tempura. When the scallops were microwaved and placed on top of my imitation crab california roll, my nephew asked if it's supposed to be chewy. I was so sad.

When I saw the man put a dirty towel on the white rice he was pulling from to roll our sushi, that's when I had a vision of Gordon Ramsey walking in and shutting the place down. That and the scallop - I just really felt something growing inside of me after that.

The whole experience merited an Eek! Methinks not x 2.

A reminder:

1. Microwaved shrimp tempura
2. Frozen/microwaved scallops
3. Dirty towel on white rice

Sorry Mom & Pop....

P.S. Go to Zushi Puzzle, Nama Sushi, or Live Sushi --- neither of those will disappoint.
author: Roxy G.

description: Amazing! Brown rice sushi option without an additional charge is a plus! Beat the rush hour wait and dine earlier. Only one man is making the rolls.
author: K V.

description:
This place is great, but not for more than 4 people. Seriously, this place is small. But like it's size, the prices are also small. So small in fact that this place will not break your wallet for indulging your curiosity.

Get everything, it's good. Get here early, it good. I want to live closer to Van Ness just to eat here more often.
author: Eric N.

description:
Yelp drove us here on a Saturday night. The location is a little odd, right on Van Ness. Place was pretty full, but there was only 1 server and 1 sushi chef. 
The server finally made her way to us and informed us it would be 40 min for sushi. This was great to know because we ran and snagged a great bottle of wine from a friend's apt and ordered a whole bunch of starters. Corkage was only $10 which was a plus as well. $10 is nothing in this city for getting able to drink what you want. 

On to the food. The starters were awesome! Crab and cucumber salad is a must! We had to order another one because it was so good. 

Exactly 40 min later we got our food. It was all great especially for the price! 

We will definitely come back, and we ready for a bit of a wait.
author: Annie G.

description: The best part of my experience at Wayo is when they initially brought out the food. The smell of seaweed and wasabi had my mouth watering and I was excited about dinner. But when it came down to actually eating, I wasn't very impressed by the rolls. The sashimi was undoubtedly fresh but that's all I would go for next time.
author: Cindy N.

description:
If you didn't have to wait for your food, it would be fine.  But you do. Went on a Monday, sat down immediately, but quickly realized how long dinner was going to take.  The sushi chef was working alone, but swamped with tickets, and there was only one other woman handling the dining room.  As we were starting to search for another nearby place to eat on Yelp, she finally came by to take out order.  

I'll be patient for good food, but this was not good.  Nigiri had wayyyy too much wasabi on it. Almost like he didn't want us to taste the fish at all....

Dragon Roll was made with shrimp tempura that was soft and squishy like it had been fried hours ago.  

Only been to 7-8 sushi places in town, but this is certainly at the bottom of that list.
author: Stephanie L.

description: The sushi here is pretty average, but it's definitely on the cheap side. Most rolls are around $5. We really enjoyed the rainbow roll and the mango salmon rolls, but the spicy tuna roll was tasteless. The rolls have a lot of rice and not much fish in them. They do offer brown rice which is a nice option. I might come back if I'm in the neighborhood but I won't be seeking this place out again.
author: Diana G.

description: Good sushi and sashimi, but I don't understand the hype. The wait was manageable at 30 minutes, but any more than that and it wouldn't have been worth it. Maybe I just suck at telling apart mediocre raw fish and awesome raw fish. /shrug
author: Shuang C.

description:
A rare gem of a reasonably priced sushi restaurant that serves fantastically fresh sashimi and  sushi, simple, beautifully prepared, with less of those fried mayo-laden faux rolls that sushi bars seem so fond of serving. Since BF was set on having a roll I decided to give them a chance despite usually abstaining from fusion-style sushi. Since our arrival in SF this has been the best sushi we've ever eaten.

We had the House Roll (spinach, cucumber and unagi), Spicy Tuna and Mango Roll, and an order of some of the freshest and most tasty maguro sashimi I've had. The flavors were straightforward and fresh, pure on the palate like Japanese food should taste. Tea came in a large earthenware mug (no tiny cups here) and the miso soup was delicious. While this is a small restaurant with the husband preparing the sushi and the wife serving, so you have to be patient given the wait of about 30 or so minutes - we were well content given the quality of the food. I'd have liked some regular sodium soy sauce as well.
author: Kit A.

description:
What an unexpected find on kind of yucky Van Ness.  From the outside the restaurant doesn't look like much, but don't let that fool you.  It has the best SASHIMI! We had both the HAMACHI and SALMON and they did not disappoint. We also had the Mango/Salmon roll and the Sea Fairy Roll.  Everything was delicious...which made us order even more food.  We left stuffed and happy. 

Yes, the food takes a long time to get to you, but it's totally worth the wait.  The lone sushi chef takes such care preparing your food and it's fun to watch him create your meal.  I will definitely be back!
author: Nita K.

description:
Pro: Fish/sashimi is fresh. Price is $10 max for any roll. Roll has decent size and very tasty.  The only place I know that use REAL CRAB MEAT in their rolls.  Free green tea and cozy atsmosphere of a family-run joint.

Cons: Only come here when you're not too hungry and have time to waste.  There is only 1 chef and 1 waitress!i
author: De S.

description: Awesome sushi and atmosphere with a real chef. Not the place to go if you aren't up for waiting.
author: Dane S.

description:
came here with my coworker for lunch.  love this spot because it's a real mom and pop run joint.  the "mom" takes the order and the "pop" makes the sushi. the sashimi/nigiri is really fresh and if you sit at the counter, you can watch the chef make each and every piece.  prices are very, very reasonable for sushi in san francisco. for lunch, including 6 orders of nigiri, one roll, one seaweed salad, and one miso soup, it was about $40. 

i knocked it off one star because it really takes too long to get your food.  because it is such a small operation, it's really hard to get back to the office in under one hour.  doesn't mean i won't still try to eat there though.
author: Tina L.

description: This place is so so good for quality sushi in the city without paying crazy prices.
author: C. G.

description:
Tiny gem on Van Ness that's worth checking out.

I've been here a few times and have always had a great experience. Fresh fish, reasonably priced, good balance of creative and simple/basic rolls, cozy space. Definitely one of my go-to sushi spots in the city.
author: Karena Q.

description:
I LOVE this place!!!!!  Fresh, simple, very high quality, very traditional little neighborhood sushi place.  I think there may only be one guy putting the food together so it takes a while, but he takes such great care in making each dish that the wait is worth it (especially from the bar so you can watch).  You can tell the chef really takes pride in his work.

I crave this place every week, no joke.  And everything I've tried so far is DELICIOUS!!!!
author: Judy L.

description: The wait can be insane on weekends because they don't have a lot of space or people.  However, if you luck into finding this place at a time when there's no wait then it's a great value.
author: Daniel D.

description: I like this sushi place. I understand this is a "Mom & Pop" place. I understand the service can be as slow as the Hotate scallop on a seabed. I had the hamachi sashimi, hotate (scallop) and amaebi. All were good, but clearly not worth the prices they are charging for the quality of the fish. I was bit disappointed. The wait, seeing the sushi being painstakingly made, the anticipation, seeing customers leave because they are not willing to wait 45 min for sushi (the place was only 1/3 full!)  I can accept all that. This place could be 5 stars if the prices were a bit cheaper OR the sushi quality were higher. When i got the bill, I was like WOW! I thought I was back in Tokyo hanging out in Ginza!
author: Rob B.

description:
I am not a sushi fan, but a friend of mine wanted to go in there while we are in town.

I found this place to be quaint, speedy and delicious!

I can only really eat shrimp when I eat sushi, they had many many shrimp options that didn't have any other fish in it. I had a mango shrimp that was exceptional.

I would highly recommend this place if you're looking to try out a sushi place and you're not a big sushi fan, it will change your mind!
author: Jim P.

description:
Consistently amazing.

Just an FYI that they don't actually open until 6pm now -- business hours listed on Yelp are incorrect.

My friend and I were in a bit of a hurry today when we went, and though there was only one other table seated, since there are only two people that work there we wanted to get our order in as quickly as possible. They were super accommodating and our rolls were immediately made one after another and served to us in sequence.

The albacore sashimi was so delicious. And the spicy yellowtail is still one of my favorites. While everything I've had here is good, at this point I think their basic rolls/ sashimi are far superior to the specialty rolls.

Since the AMC is just down the street, this is the perfect stop for dinner + a movie :)
author: Richa A.

description: Sushi is terrific. Simple and perfect execution of flavor.  The Salmon/Sake is amaze-balls.  I like it as much, if not more than some of the best Sushi in Orange County and Japan. Prices were  so veru reasonable as well.  I would be here all the time if I was a local.
author: Jason T.

description: Make sure you call ahead.  A drop in on a Wednesday for one person results in a 45 minute wait!
author: Gabe R.

description:
What everyone else said...it takes a looooong time to have a meal here. Luckily, the warn you when you first get there. Unluckily, it's not just the sushi that takes a long time. It was about 15-20 minutes before the one server (who also plays the role of sous chef and dishwasher) even asked us for our drink order. She was the sweetest thing but holy crap I just wanted a beer! The sushi chef, also very sweet and such a cute old man, was working as fast as he could. 

As far as the food goes, the sushi was decent. I've had better though. But for the price, I'd probably eat there again. Although I'd definitely bring a book. Maybe War and Peace...I might get served before I finish that one.
author: Laura A.

description:
It's a standard 45 minute wait (if 6+ people are ahead of you) to get your order. I can't imagine how long it would be if you waited for a seat, then waited another 45 mins!

Like the other reviewers said, the sushi is okay but definitely not worth waiting this long for.
author: Kim L.

description:
Not bad of a place. The Nigiri was fresh. I like how there is wasabi in each roll. 

Wait time was 45 minutes for the food. The waitress did warn us about the long wait before we ordered which is very appreciated. It seems there was the old man preparing the sushi, the one waitress and a dishwasher in the back. They seem a bit understaffed but nonetheless they were very nice. 

I wouldn't come here for a quick bite due to the time it takes to sit down and get the food. 

I'll definitely be back :)
author: Derek N.

description: Sushi is pretty good. I do love the brown rice option. They also have tamari which is great for anyone who likes to stay gluten free.
author: Ryan E.

description: Really simple sushi spot.  Been here twice, both times satisfied (most importantly the fish was super fresh).  Quite a bit of a wait both times, so not a good place if you are looking for something quick.
author: Click C.

description:
One of those tiny sushi places tucked into some obscure area. Yes, it's on Van Ness,  but I blame the gigantic tree blocking this tiny place. And yes, I admit was walking on the sidewalk between the tree and the restaurant, but still. I did enjoyed the tree from the inside through the unobstructed display window. 

Arrived here on a chilly weekday , and it was empty. Kinda nice to have a place with your friends. Wayo is one of those husband and wife sushi teams--service was prompt until 3 parties showed up.

As for the food, I think the mango rolls won me over. The rest of the sushi was okay. I don't know which one it was, but try not to get the rolls that have a smaller diameter. The chef seems to put significantly less; the ratio was definitely skewed compared to the larger rolls. Sea Fairy was okay. I felt the scallop on top tasted kinda fishy. Tuna was okay too. Snow leopard, nothing too exotic or special.
author: William H.

description:
The quality of the sashimi was good, and the rolls were decent, but do NOT show up to this place hungry.

They're painfully understaffed, which, on one hand lends to the authenticity of the food and I suppose the experience, but I believe they should at least hire another set of hands to help out.

I had a hard time enjoying my food because I felt so bad for the two people working here.
author: Sara D.

description: As there is only one sushi chef, there is a bit of a wait for your sushi but the time went by quickly as we noshed on a tofu salad and edamame.  Pretty good, fresh sushi!  A bit of a random location but a nice surprise if you find yourself in the area.
author: Lily L.

description:
This place is just awesome. Pretty small family-owned spot with great fish. I didn't notice the mango-sushi on the wall behind me, so I ordered my usual array of items. 

Uni - really tasty, good texture. Uni is hit or miss and generally how I judge a sushi restaurant. 

Spicy tuna was also great. Most people tend to turn their soy sauce into a kind of wasabi-mortar sauce. This is done by americans who don't know you are supposed to TASTE the fish, not sweat profusely and clear your nasal passages. I found myself not using any soy at all. 

They have a decent selection of cold-unfiltered sake for 5$ a glass. Yes, you get your personal glass of sake. Rolls are 5-9$ depending on what you order. 

Definitely come here on a week night, the line can be stupid long on the weekends.
author: David N.

description:
This place is okay, at least a solid 3+ stars but not much more. I don't know what I was expecting, but somehow for a sushi-only place I was expecting something better. The fish was good but (at least in my mind) not much beyond that. It could be just what I ordered. I usually like to go for chirashi of a sashimi combo. Neither was on the menu but I did see someone order it, so they did serve it. That might have given me a better perspective than the items I ordered. half of which were rolls.

Also this place apparently can be slow even when it's not fill. I saw the hostess advise an incoming party that sushi would take an hour (they then decided against waiting and left), and then advised the next party 40 minutes (they decided to stay). At least I give the sushi chef credit for personally bringing me my items to my table despite being so busy.

As for staff, it's just the chef and his assistant (who was pretty nice). This is despite a negative first impression of not much of a greeting or smile by either when I walked into the initially-empty restaurant (I was the first guest this past Friday evening).
author: H K.

description:
I would really love to give this place 4 stars, but you have to wait FOREVER for your sushi if it's busy, which can be a bummer.  To be fair, they give you a fairly accurate estimate for how long it will take to get your sushi before you order.  On this particular Sunday night, the estimate was 45 minutes.  We decided that would be okay, since we planned on ordering other appetizers.  We soon realized, however, the problem was the restaurant is way under-staffed for the size.  There is a sushi bar that seats 10-15 guests, and then 3 or four small tables.  For a place that size, you need at least two sushi chefs and two servers.  Instead, there is one of each.  The sushi chef is clearly working hard, but you can only roll so much sushi at a time.  And the one server was running around like mad, taking orders, filling non-sushi orders, running beverage service, bringing checks, running credit cards, etc.  So, it took at least 25 minutes before we got our appetizers.  Even then, we got them at different times so one person was finished with their salad before I got my soup.  And they forgot the edamame until I reminded them, about 35 minutes in.  My sense is this was a couple who run the restaurant together, but they could seriously use an extra pair of hands helping them.    

We started getting concerned that the sushi wouldn't even arrive within the 45 minute estimate, but it did with a few minutes to spare.  So, I appreciated they were accurate in their time estimate, and it wasn't 45 minutes that bled into an hour.  Once we did get our sushi, it was excellent.  Fresh, generous cuts of nigiri and sashimi, and spicy mango yellowtail roll was delicious.  They could stand to lighten up on the wasabi, or at least blend a bit more evenly so you're not biting into a surprise chunk you can't see in your food.

A nice place, and a place I really want to like, but it just needs more staff!  Worth checking it out, but not if you are in a rush or ravenously hungry.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Does it matter when the owner is the sushi chef?  Yes, yes, yes!  A return visit to this neighborhood gem confirmed that it serves the freshest fish with an enthusiasm worthy of its high quality.  You simply have to ignore the small quarters as you order brown or white rice, tea or a beer with your meal. 

Appreciating the speed with which the owner prepares the orders is possible only if you are sitting at the counter. Whatever your favorite:  Seaweed salads, dragon rolls, ikura or California rolls, as well as unique mango combinations are on the menu.  Be prepared, the interior is modest in this tiny wonder, though the prices run about $30 a person.  If you are visiting SF, know that this is one of the reasons people love this town.
author: Lynn S.

description: Really great sushi! Expect a wait to receive your sushi once you have sat down, but it is only because he takes time to make sure each sushi is made to perfection. Definitely worth the wait. I would recommend Nigiri
author: Francesca D.

description:
This is not the kind of place you order rolls at. The selection of rolls is limited anyways. You come here for the sashimi and nigiri which are deliciously fresh! 

 I highly recommend the unagi, saba, and hamachi. The order of tobiko is huge so expect a mouthful.
author: Megan C.

description:
I really like this place. I think it's family owned, with the husband and wife running it.
Fish is very fresh which makes for yummy sushi and they even make the miso soup one by one!
Service was nice and very attentive. Will go back for sure...
author: Aphrodite L.

description:
Some of my favorite days are when instead of taking a bus, I decide to walk. Feeling the wind tangle my auburn locks, I speed walk around the city.

I like to think that my feet and those handy Yelp stickers found in sometimes the most random of places - will lead me to new adventures and on exciting turns.

My cheap flip-flops did not let me down today. Heading down busy Van Ness, I spied Wayo Sushi. It was empty, but the beaming red Yelp sticker beckoned me inside.

The adorable couple working, who I'm assuming are the owners, greeted me right away, with big real smiles. The kind of smile that make the eyes twinkle.

I sat down and began skimming the menu. Wayo's sushi selection is fairly basic, but what's unique about their selection, is that they even offer brown rice sushi rolls. Great, if you're looking to stay away from over-processed white rice. 

I ordered the mango-crab roll, the shrimp tempura roll, and the avocado roll. The mango was so creamy and fresh, and the crab has not an ounce of fishy taste. The avocado was buttery and with the brown rice - tasted both "healthy" and delicious.

The sushi chef, was so quick and each roll rolled with love, that I found it hard not to bask in both the attention and warm atmosphere that moved around the place. Him and his wife, kept on eagerly looking over at me to see if I needed anything else, and to make sure I was enjoying my meal.

When chefs really care and invest themselves in their food, it's hard not to enjoy it. You can't help but taste their time and devotion.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I think this is the first time I give a 5 star for a place that is not upscale after only 1 visit.
Very impressed.

Not pretentious, run by the Sushi Chef and one waitress only (husband and wife I believe).

Nothing fancy on the menu: they stick to what they do best and it's sushi, sashimi and rolls. And when I say "best" I'm not kidding.
We loved everything we tried, the fish was super fresh, delicious.

We sat at the counter because all the tables (very few of them) were taken. I have a feeling this place is popular and always busy, and as I said there are only 2 people running it, so even though it's kind of small, expect to be waiting a little for your food.
But it is, oh so worth the wait!

I also really like their miso soup. Funny how the big pot of soup is out there for all to see on the stove; very "homey" :)

We will definitely go back. I urge you to do so as well.
author: Vithiet L.

description: Amazing sushi, extremely fresh and great attention to detail. Yes you have to wait, the place is operated by a couple and they service one customer at a time.
author: Kiran J.

description:
Very solid 4 stars. This might be the best sashimi you'll have in SF. We got the yellowtail, salmon, and albacore. They all tasted really fresh and buttery.  We also got maki unagi rolls, as well as a mango spicy yellowtail roll, but those weren't as good as the sashimi, and were kind of average as far as rolls go.

I also have to second the same warning that all the other reviewers have covered already, in that you should expect a bit of a wait since it's just the one chef and server for the whole tiny place. Totally worth it though for the great sashimi!
author: J S.

description:
Mango mango mango.

I love mango rolls and so does the sushi chef at Wayo, hence we're a perfect couple, he makes the mango rolls, I eat them and pay. This is love.. I've been here twice and I'm pretty sure this is one of the best sushi places around and bonus it's one of the cheapest I've been to. My bro and I went here and with drinks our total was sub $70. Pretty awesome... 

It's a small place and differently not a trendy place, it's got bare decor, but hey they're not charging retarded prices.

The place only has one sushi chef -- I think his wife is the waitress. Very nice people. So don't go with a huge group, this is meant for 2 - 4 people max. Also, give yourself sometime, it can get slow if the place is packed, order some appetizers (seaweed salad, miso, sake, etc...).
author: Michael S.

description:
FRESHEST NIGIRI EVER.  Literally buttery seafood.

Mango rolls were blah and no baked rolls with saucy goodness so stick to the nigiri.
author: Karen N.

description:
Was looking for a sushi place so I shopped around on Yelp and found Wayo since it was close by and had pretty good reviews. 
We ate early and the place was not crowded on a Sun evening. Prices seemed really reasonable, even on the cheaper side:
2 orders of Sunomono (pickled cucumber) So tasty, we ordered another round. :)
1 order Ohitashi (spinach with dried bonito flakes)
1 order of unagi sushi
1 House roll (eel with cucumber and spinach)
1 Mango and salmon roll

All for $26, not incl tips yet. We were really surprised considering that we could have paid $40 for the same meal elsewhere. Service was fast and overall was a nice experience. However, the rolls were somewhat loosely packed, was ok tasting but not super fantastic. I would say it's abt 3 star but I'll round it up to 4 to support the mom and pop business! Truly nice and friendly chef and the lady wait staff.
author: Yan M.

description:
It's a very small place. But it's definitely not a hole-in-the-wall.

Menu is not extensive. But I'm not complaining. I love how the rolls are not huge (or expensive) so you can sample everything there.

we had...
-dynamite roll (spicy tuna with avocado & tobiko) *my fave*
-snow leopard roll (seared albacore with ponzu sauce)
-mango & spicy yellowtail roll
-cream cheese and salmon roll
-maguro nigiri
-ikura
-spicy salmon skin roll (spicy salmon skin with picked radish & cucumber)
-tiger roll (yellowtail with teriyaki sauce)
-maguro sashimi platter
-small sake

And that was all for 2 ppl! Yum! And it only came to ~$60 with tax and tip. Awesome!

But like everyone has mentioned before, the food is slow. Even though we were the first ones there, our dinner was more than 1 1/2 hours long.
author: Marti L.

description:
Oh Yelp, you had my expectations set too high for this joint...the cuts of fish were fresh, yet rolls and service left me underwhelmed...
Ordered: 
Shuro Maguro Ngiri- albacore, good quality fish
Hamachi Sashimi- yellowtail, good quality fish
Spicy Tuna Mango Roll- sounds a lot more interesting than it tastes..
Snow Leopard Roll- seared albacore, only thing I liked about this roll was the ponzu sauce that accompanied it, otherwise bland
Eel and Avocado Roll- meh. 
Seaweed Salad and Miso Soup- good
Additionally, I suppose to counteract the blandness of the rice-y rolls, I had each of my sushi orders packed with a good chunk of sinus clearing- tear-jerking wasabi, fun.
Overall I would recommend for those looking for fresh cuts of sashimi at a decent price, but if you're looking to mix in a few good rolls with your order I would say to check in elsewhere..
author: Mahsa K.

description: One of the best places in the city for sashimi! I hate when places give tiny slices of sashimi but that is not the case at this restaurant!
author: Angela S.

description: Absolutely love this place. It is so cosy and welcoming, almost feels like you are in the owner's living room. And with the freshest sashimi ever :)
author: Anny P.

description: 10-15 years ago I worked nights a few blocks away and this place was the spot I went to on my dinner break. There might be a table or two filled and a few people at the bar. I'd sit and read the paper at the bar. They were always asking how I was doing and how was the family. After awhile I didn't even order anymore they knew what I wanted. I always hoped for them to see more customers. Since then, I have moved away and stop in whenever Im back in the city. These last 5 years theyre doing great. I asked how they became so busy and they said that social media has spread the word. So on behalf of two great people that I always hoped would thrive, thanks. Even though now I sometimes have to wait in line.
author: Patrick H.

description:
This is one of the BEST sushi places. I've been a client for over 10 years and I've seen their business grow!  The owner is also the sushi chef and the sushi he makes is ALWAYS consistent. The fish is fresh and you are always greeted with a smile. 

*One thing to note: if you plan on coming here for dinner, you might want to arrive right when they open. If you don't, the wait can me long but it's so worth it.*
author: J G.

description:
Practically empty on a Saturday night and the maki is approximately $3-4.  Being skeptical when it comes to sushi I would say no way to Wayo if I hadn't read the stellar Yelp reviews beforehand...

By no means the best sushi I've ever had, but definitely the best quality for the price! My future sister-in-law and I went to town on the sushi and drinks:

2 large sakes
1 large beer
1 house salad
1 seaweed salad
4 maki rolls
And 2 pieces of hamehachi
-------
All for $50! Seriously- this is the McDonalds of sushi restaurants, although edible!!

If you like all those special types of rolls (ones that usually have crunch in it) this isn't the place for you, but check this out for the good yet affordable basic rolls.

And apparently Wayo is also BYOB so feel free to bring along your favorite bottle of wine...
author: Andrea R.

description:
A Yelp find, I had a nice quick little off-hours lunch here and the fish was fresh and decently portioned.  I am a bit racist in that I like the actual Japanese sushi chef there.  I like the down home feel here as he was the only guy working.

Support local biz!
author: Gene X.

description:
Fresh Fish and Great Value!

This is my new go-to sushi place.  The restaurant is small, so I imagine it is pretty difficult to get a table during peak periods.  Luckily, I stopped by when it wasn't too busy.  There are a handful of tables and ample bar seating (diner style).  

The nigiri (yellowtail, tuna and salmon) was very fresh and portioned just right, not too thin and not too thick.  I also tried the spicy yellowtail and mango roll, which was just okay.  The prices are very reasonable compared to most of the other establishments in the area.

One of the other reviewers mentioned that it is difficult to reach them on the phone when placing take-out orders, which I found to be the case as well.  All in all, a great place to get your sushi fix.
author: Grant W.

description:
Wayo is climbing its way to the top on my list of favorite sushi restaurants. Not only is it a 30-second walk from where I live, but I love the traditional feel of the restaurant. It is a very modest location with an even more modest staff. Even when crowded, the restaurant is rarely bustling and loud... something I have definitely come to appreciate!

Top rolls/dishes I would recommend...

1) Scallop California Roll - this roll is on the special menu in the plastic holder on the table, scallop is paired deliciously with the freshest Cali Roll ever---no imitation crab!
2) Salmon w/ Mango Roll ($5) - you can order this roll with any type of fish: spicy yellow tail, spicy tuna, crab, etc. The mango gives it that extra kick of unexpected flavor.
3) Shiro Maguro Nigiri ($3.50/2pcs) - this is an albacore nigiri that literally melts in your mouth... soooo good!
4) Snow Leopard Roll - this one is a little more decadent with teriyaki sauce drizzled over a roll with hamachi
5) Salmon w/ Cream Cheese Roll ($7.50) - this roll is sort of my guilty pleasure! The chef puts a ton of cream cheese in it mMMmmMm!!!

I love that there is always free tea, and they are very good at keeping tea filled to the brim throughout the meal. Wayo also serves brown rice in sushi now, which is cool. I have never had a problem with the wait staff here, although I've heard service is not great when it's packed. Otherwise, I love Wayo and would recommend it to all!
author: Catherine C.

description: First time here, sushi was excellent.   Albacore sashimi was awesome.  Mom and pop place.  Highly recommend.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Update 02/20/2008

Even if the wait for sushi here can be long, it's still five stars. I've been here so many times now and you really can't get better sushi in SF for the same price. My friends and I love to go here whenever we're starting a night out now.

---------------------------

Definitely one of the best sushi restaurants in the city and it's one that most people don't know about. One of the things I like most about this place is that it isn't pretentious and focuses on serving great sushi. Some of the "trendier" sushi places in the city seem to get too distracted with making their establishment look cool.

The owners are really friendly and I'm happy to report that this is one of the most relaxing places to enjoy good sushi. I've gone here a couple of times on a Friday evening and have been thoroughly impressed. Only downside is that when the place is busy it can take a little while to get served.

Recommendations:
 * Dragon roll
 * Sake (salmon)
author: Bryan B.

description: The restaurant is a small place with limited number of tables. We ordered variety of sushi, including spicy tuna, salmon roll, alaskan, california roll, shrimp and avocado, and a nigiri roll. We also ordered a cucumber and octapus salad. The fish was fresh but the rolls were small and the portions small.
author: Saeideh B.

description:
Wayo is my favorite neighborhood sushi. Much has been made of their brown-rice option which doesn't do much for me -- brown rice is better, but not on sushi. What's more important is the perfect *temperature* of their nigiri and sashimi; rice still warm, fish perfectly room temperature, as it should be. Their more limited sushi selection doesn't bother me as it seemed to some reviewers.

The peacefulness and integrity of the operation are top-notch. Mamoru Ogawa has been grinding away and kicking ass at Wayo for nineteen years this year. Can you say the same?
author: John M.

description: I wish I could give this place 3.5 stars.  I love the cute, cozy interior of this place, and my friends also brought their own sake, and Wayo charged a mere $10 corking fee.  The salmon sashimi was excellent, but it was on top of this salty seaweed that unfortunately detracted from the flavor a bit.  I think that would have put this at 4 stars.  Worth checking out, and is a great hole in the wall location right off Van Ness.
author: Mel G.

description:
LOVE, LOVE, LOVVVEEE their sushi!!! always fresh!!! my mouth is watering, just thinking about it!

the only reason i dont give it five stars is because its sO small. theres room for like 20 people in the entire restaurant. they always only have two people working. the waitress and the cook. this means the food takes almost foreverrr -_-

they dO tell u how long the wait is going to be. always. and they dont sugarcoat it.
author: Lisa N.

description:
This place rocks!
The quality of the fish has shocked me every time I've been there.  It's a pretty modest place, but it has its charm, and the guy who runs the place has been in that same spot for 22 years.  He is a really nice guy, and a perfectionist with his sushi.  He is often the only one there, and he serves and prepares sushi at the same time, so if the place is full, order the seaweed salad and relax.. he keeps pretty busy.  

We are also usually surprised at how low the bill is after everything is finished.  its very reasonable. 

Ah, you can also order anything with brown rice, just for a twist, and anything with scallops (especially the sea fairy roll) is incredible.
author: Eva R.

description:
When there are no complaints from me, and a great overall experience, a place deserves 5 stars. Wayo Sushi is one of those places.

I live a block and a half away from this place, and just tried it for the first time last week. I went with a friend who just moved to the city, and he was craving sushi. This place has been on my Yelp bookmarks for a very long time. These factors made it the perfect excuse to finally go and check it out.

The restaurant is VERY small, definitely would not recommend for groups larger than 4, but who knows. They might be able to put a bunch of tables together depending on how busy they are. I came here on a Thursday night, and the place was pretty much full around 8pm. We were seated right away, by a very nice lady. I think this place is a family owned restaurant, and the staff was very pleasant.

The menu was very simple. They had a couple specialty menus as well, one already placed on the table in a plastic frame (this is where we found tempura rolls which were not on the actual menu), and the other written on a blackboard by the door (I believe they listed all of their mango rolls here). My friend and I started with a bowl of miso soup ($2 I think), and he had some cold sake as well. We each ordered 2 rolls. I ordered the Alaskan and Spicy Tuna rolls (both $4.50 or so). The food arrived not long after we finished our soup, and we were ready to dig in.

YUM! I'm pretty picky about sushi, as I like it to be FULL of flavor. I'm not huge on the seaweed flavor when I eat sushi, and would much rather taste the fresh flavors of the fish. That's exactly what I tasted. It was just the perfect ratio of fish, seaweed, and rice for both of the rolls I ordered. I was so full after the 2 rolls (I think I still had 1 or 2 pieces left that I couldn't eat).

I'm very excited to live so close to such a great sushi place. Wayo will become one of my go-to spots when I'm in a sushi mood! I can't wait to try some of their specialty mango rolls.
author: Ashley D.

description:
I was searching Yelp for a new place to eat Sushi that was near Downtown and stumbled upon this place. Their sushi is fresh, and the overall taste is pretty good. I ordered their Spicy Tuna , Rock n Roll (eel and avocado), and a shrimp with avocado.

The fish tasted fresh, and the unagi (eel) was VERY GOOD and had a good sauce that was put on top. One of the unique things that I noticed from this place is that on 2 of the 3 rolls I ordered, they put some wasabi in them to give it a little kick...which I really enjoyed. It's always nice to see places do things a little different. 

They are open for lunch only for 2 hours, so make sure you get there quick! I came here for lunch at 1:40 to take sushi to go...but they had their CLOSED sign up...the Sushi Chef was nice enough to let me come in and order some sushi to go. 

If your in the area and need a new Sushi place to try...I would recommend coming here.
author: Nick C.

description:
My friend lives above this place, so when I suggested sushi after the YEE WWWDD, he suggested here. First of all, 1200 points for not laughing at me when I walked in in my Belle costume, although it is SF, so stranger has been seen. 
We sat down and I ordered my standard, seaweed salad, sake,and uni. All were scrumptious and fresh, so I was happy. DJ ordered california rolls (amateur), and some other "boring" rolls....guess some people don't have the same love of raw  fish...but he seemed to enjoy them.
Extra stars for the cheap prices, I'll def be back. Couldn't go for 5 stars because I didn't see any out of this world type creative rolls, and definitely minus 1 star for not having my favorite, soft shell crab!!!
author: Bianca L.

description:
An adept sushi chef is often referred to as an artist for their skillfully sliced slivers of fresh fish, gracefully lacerated with enviable precision.

The man behind Wayo Sushi's counter is as dexterous as an artist as a kindergartner is on their first deliverable art project.

The result was a hideous mound of hastily cleft sashimi.

The salmon was mysteriously salty.

Their specialty roll was an unforgivable abberation.

Brown rice with sushi?

I can't go on.

I think I just lost my appetite.
author: Lisa W.

description: Good sushi...We liked the tuna rolls but didn't care much for the seared albacore roll...
author: Kay P.

description: Fantastic sushi for a reasonable price!  I highly recommend this place for all sushi lovers.  The food is great and the service is fast and friendly!
author: Chris D.

description:
Good sushi at pretty affordable prices (most rolls ranged between $5-10).

I got the spicy tuna and mango crabmeat rolls - both of which were delish. Alaskan and dragon rolls (I stole bites from others) were yummy as well.

The restaurant itself is fairly small (would not recommend coming with a group larger than 4) and service, while polite, was slow (only one sushi chef and one waitress when we came in on a Sunday night). 

Minus one point for no one picking up the phone when I tried to call to make reservations.
author: Linda B.

description: This is a great low key sushi restaurant before going to see a movie at AMC. My boyfriend and I tried the alaska, salmon, and dragon, all very good and fresh. The special rolls (mango salmon) and albacore are tasty as well. Most rolls range from $5.50-$6.60. I have yet to try the nigiri, seaweed salad, and sashimi, which I heard were good. I'd definitely return to Wayo, fast service and good sushi.
author: Stephanie M.

description: This place has the best Nigiris I've had so far. The fish is really tender and delicious. Only problem is that the restaurant only seats a handful of people. and the average wait for food is about 30-45 minutes. The restaurant seems to be run by a husband and wife, and they are very nice. I recommend this to those who don't mind waiting a while for very good sushi.
author: George T.

description:
good value
brown rice options
easy and fast
author: Anne-Mary P.

description:
This sushi place is not the cheapest sushi place you can find, but it offers real value. If you like a lot of bells and whistles on your sushi rolls, then this is probably not the place for you. But if you appreciate deliciously fresh sashimi or nigiri sushi, then you will probably really like this place.

Between me and my BF we tried the hamachi, albacore tuna, maguro tuna, salmon, the tuna and mango roll and an albacore roll. Everything was delicious and prepared with care. 

In sum: perfect for the sushi purists who value good fish above all else. 

P.S. It's teeny tiny so its probably best to go during off hours. We went at 5PM on a Sunday and by 6PM the sushi bar and all tables were full.
author: Blond E.

description:
Yummy!
On a cold and rainy Saturday night, my friend and I decided to go on an extra special girls only date night.  She had read about this place and we were both in the mood for some sashimi, no rice for us!

We found parking RIGHT in front, thanks rain! Oh and that Giants game that they won to go to the World Series.. whatever.

We decided to order 3 helpings of sashimi & 2 delicious salads. 

The sashimi was SOOO fresh... I loved it.  We got:
Yellow tail - delicious
Salmon - melted in my mouth & beautifully buttery
Albacore - yum yum yum!
Seaweed Salad - so good and an amazing deal at only $3
Cucumber with octopus - So yummy and the fresh cucumber taste was amazing, another great deal at only $3.50

This place is cute, small, and wasn't too packed last night (which I like).  I would love to come back, maybe try a mango roll? I've heard lots of good things.  Maybe get some warm sake in me on a cold night.

Overall: Great little sushi place, hella fresh fish, run by actual Japanese people, I would bring my actual Japanese boyfriend here... maybe. It's definitely date central, every other table had a canoodling couple, so bring your baby boo too.
author: Isabella O.

description: Once again, I found another decently priced sushi place.  And parking is not too bad.  The place is really small so you have to test your luck on seating.  It was no problem for me when I went.
author: Byron L.

description: BEST SUSHI in San Francisco. Mamoru, the Sushi Chef is so good at his trade, it's so much fun to watch him make ALL of the sushi. He is the only chef creating all of the food so it might take a little while, but the wait is totally worth it. Yukari, is the waitress and she is so friendly and does all the bussing and waiting. So be very patient. This is my absolute favorite sushi in San Francisco because of the quality. Definitely a must go!
author: Austin B.

description: Good spot, Japanese staff, small place so be ready to wait but they are friendly
author: Anthony W.

description:
I only remember two things: long wait times and average tasting sushi.

O Wayo Sushi, i tried to like you...
author: Stacy L.

description:
My initial impression was that this place was going to be a standard sushi place, but it really isn't. The place is small, and produces good sushi rolls. There is no flare with the decorations because there are none, there aren't loud sushi chiefs, just an older man, and a young woman working. 
The menu is what a sushi place should be like...just sushi. There is no chicken teriyaki or crazy rolls that are gigantic, and stuffed with filler items.
The rolls are good, great quality products, and good filling size that hold together well. The food takes a while, but it worth the wait, and you get to watch him make your food. All the items are cheap compared to other restaurants.
If your looking for a neighborhood gem that make good sushi this is the place to go.
author: Nathan M.

description:
I love coming here for the hand made rolls. I usually order something from their daily specials or the dragon roll or the caterpillar roll. My husband likes to go all out and order the sushi boat or omakase. The takosu appetizer is delicious with beer. I also liked the cold tofu appetizer, but I do not recall the name. 

There's only one sushi chef so be prepared to wait a while. He hardly ever talks because he is always busy preparing meals! Sometimes I wish he would hire someone else to help so we could all get our food faster but then again having a lone chef is what makes Wayo sushi special.
author: Paula U.

description:
Wayo Sushi consistently gets really great reviews on Yelp- between 4 and 5 stars. So I went there once a year ago, didn't like it at all, then went back a second time last week to give it another day in court before writing this review.
There is so much excellent sushi to be had in San Francisco--and of all the food I eat when I go out, I eat nigiri and sashimi the most. Therefore, my standards for a 4 or 5 star sushi place may be higher than most, but when I give a score that high you know I mean mouthgasm. The reason I only gave 2 stars to Wayo is that despite the authentic Japanese atmosphere, you should not waste your time on the food or the excruciatingly long wait for it.

Here are the main reasons why:
1. The fish is just not that fresh. They may load on the wasabi (my first time there wasabi was under the fish on every nigiri piece) to try and mask that fact, but in absence of anything to mask the quality of the fish itself (I only ordered sashimi my second time there)- the fish is meh at its very best. This is reason alone to seek fresh, wonderful fish elsewhere.
2. The not-so-fresh fish takes forever to prepare. And I mean, at least a 45 minute wait, even if the place is not that packed.
3. The service is way sub-par. You will probably wait another 20-30 minutes for your check.
4. They only have one kind of unfiltered nigori sake. It's good, but if you are a sake fan, variety is the spice of life.
author: Veronica J.

description:
Meh is the first word that came to mind after I ate here.

I came here with a group of 6, and we literally took up more than half the dining area. After my group, there was just the sushi bar and 1 table for 2 available so this place is small. So seeing as this place was small, I wanted to call in to put in a reservation but after multiple calls, there was still no answer. Fortunately, the place wasn't busy so they were able to accomidate my group by combining all but 1 of their tables.

Anyways, onwards. The place is a 2 person show. 1 sushi chef and 1 waitress. Obviously with a large order, the food is going to take a while especially if it's prepared by just 1 person, so the really long wait was to be expected. The sushi itself was really nothing to write home about. Yeah, it's sushi, it tasted decent. It's not terrible, it's just kind of average. They were pretty inconsistent with the amount of wasabi that went into the sushi. Some pieces of nigiri had a lot more than others and really made it unpleasant. I will say however, that the waitress was pretty nice, and even asked us if we would like to split the check. Overall, for the price, the sushi isn't all that great, and there are other places that are better that isn't a hole in the wall. I will probably  not repeat.
author: Damon Y.

description:
A BIG thank you to YELP being available on my phone!  My boyfriend and I were visiting the City and wanted to get some sushi.  So, I whipped out my Crackberry to find a sushi place near our hotel and VOILA!  We were on our way to Wayo Sushi.  Now, it was late (9:30pm and we were extremely hungry) and with us not being familiar with San Fran we had a tough time finding the place, it sort of gets lost next to the Starubucks, but alas we found it.

As we walked in, we noticed it is nothing like the big commercialized sushi places we are used to.  We found a spot at the bar and sat down.  The ONE sushi chef (owner) let us know that it would be a little bit of a wait, but we were in no rush.  The waitress was quick to get us water an bring us edmame as well as take our order.

The menu is small and pretty basic, but, I have to say, for the amout of food you get and he QUALITY of the fish, it is well worth it.  We enjoyed the quiet ambiance and low key atmosphere of the place.  We had an order of half tuna half salmon sahsimi, spicy yellowtail roll, snow leopard roll (ABSOLUTELY OUT OF THIS WORLD) and another order of tuna sashimi.  The best part is that with the sashimi you get a little bit of seaweed salad on the side! I have never been a big fan of it, but this place had the best I have ever eaten.

After speaking to the owner he let us know he had been there for 22 years!  Obviously, his way of doing business has worked very well.  I applaud him for sticking to simplicity.  I will absolutely visit Wayo Sushi when I am in San Fran next time!
author: Amber N.

description:
"If you ever stood in line for Shake Shack, Ippudo Ramen, or (insert yummy food that has rediculously long waits) then you should wait for food here too"

On the outside of the building, it does not look like a sushi place. I will say when you venture into the restaurant you will not get a typical response. When I sat down, I was told it will take 90 mins before you are served, but if you stay I will take care of you. Keep in mind that this is a one-man show (literally). My patience was rewarded with some nigiri sushi. The sushi itself, I have found to be fresh. Additionally, you will not break the bank having a meal here. 

If I am back in the bay area, I will be here for some sushi everytime.
author: Tony A.

description:
I'm not sure what all the hype is about and all this talk about how fresh the fish is. So... I basically got everything tuna that night - spicy tuna, tuna sashimi, something else tuna.

The spicy tuna was good, really spicy. Lots of wasabi. The wasabi was especially good here... or maybe it was a figure of my imagination?

The tuna sashimi was not my favorite, forgettable. It was a weird texture, even mushy at some bites.
author: Jackie M.

description: After a nice excursion to the Russian bath house, my friend and I were spent and hungry. Sat down and noticed that it was definitely a bit of a date restaurant. We sat by the bar and we were warned that sushi would take 40 minutes. So smart of us, we ordered appetizers to tie us over and it was great. Miso soup was excellent. Best I've had in a while. Sushi was quite fresh, best saba. Totally low key and totally worth the wait. A guy came in to wait for his to-go order, it took an hour and he was OK with it. We knew it was going to be a good restaurant because of it. Sure enough the sushi was very fresh and very traditional. I liked it because it felt authentic. Nothing worse than not-so-fresh sushi. While we sat down and had tea and water, 2 couples going to the Edwardian Ball (which was tonight) showed up, they looked happy and festive. A few more dates came as well. A good looking man came and sat down by himself. I wondered what his story was. A couple showed up but did not want to wait so they took off, but another couple seemed to know the drill and they were patient and sat down and ordered regardless. My girlfriend (but not my GIRLFRIEND) had a nice time catching up and we felt rejuvenated after the meal. We agreed that clean, fresh, tasty sushi was exactly what the doctor ordered after a fabulous day soaking at Archimedes Banya. It's a bit odd place to find  - was hoping to head over to Russian Hill for sushi, or somewhere on Polk Street. But instead we ended up here, and we were thrilled of this find.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Wayo Sushi is great for dinner with a friend or a date. The place is really small and once you are seated it takes about 45 minutes receive your food as there is only one sushi chef. That being said I loved Wayo Sushi. The fish was fresh and the prices were a steal. 

If you are looking for a crazy loud sushi restaurant with tons of non-traditional rolls this ISN'T that place. It's a quiet but pleasant dining experience with simple but delicious sushi.
author: Sarah L.

description: Very suprised of the quality. U know its good when u eat, u keep on thinking how delicious it is. The hamachi nigiri hit home!! Sashimi was so fresh, and it had some kinda salty kick to the hamachi... Which gave it an excellent kick. Love love. Price was a bit cheaper, each nigiri order was $3-$5. Even their uni was $5. I ordered 8 pieces of nigiri and 1 roll, came out to be $20. delicious!!!!!! I came on a weds at 8 and there was only 1 other party. Im soo surprised theyre not more crowded. I guess the atmosphere can use a lift. Service was quick and prompt for me!
author: Juan C.

description:
Uni for $5?? Say what??!

Ok, I'm going to admit, I don't even like Uni.  The only time I had it, was a few year back...and it had quail egg on top...and left me thinking.. I paid $15 for that?!?!

But my eating champion really likes Uni, so I just went along.  
..........And it was the BEST thing I had all month!!!  I actually had to order another round of Uni.. it was THAT good and fresh!!

Now onto the other stuff we had:

(all rolls were with brown rice)

Mango Spicy Tuna Roll  - Meh.. the texture of the soft mango and the tuna didnt mesh to well in my mouth...

Seared Albacore Roll with Ponzu  - Probably wont order again. Too much rice on the rolls, and  WAY too much vinegar in the ponzu sauce.

Tempura Roll - Good. It had a clean tempura taste to it. It was crispy, simple, and good.

Rock and Roll - Good..Ok. It taste like a rock and roll roll.... nothing bad.. nothing extremely wowing. 

Hamachi Sashimi-  WOW. Melt in my mouther, buttery goodness!!! 


To sum it up, I REALLY enjoyed all the sashimi and raw stuff here.  Its realllllllly fresh.  I didn't really care for rolls in general, but that the only reason I took off a star. Rolls = Meh, Raw = YAY!
author: Deanna T.

description:
Wayo is as mom and pop as a restaurant can get. When I first got here it was a one-man show, the owner took my order, brought me drinks, and proceeded to get behind the counter and start cranking on the sushi. Although this could be considered entertaining to watch this guy multi-task and wear many hats, this also means it will take forever to get what you ordered. Albeit when you do get it, it will be freshly made with good care.

They only have sushi, so if you're looking for noodles or teriyaki, this ain't for you. The sushi menu is not extensive but it does guarantee you daily fresh offerings. They have unique rolls, like ones the include mango. I also  like the brown rice option for a more nutritious meal. Prices are good for what you get. What I respect most about the place is that they serve some a legit cup of green tea, no powder or cheap stuff here.
author: Ed L.

description: To this accurate, I would give this place 3.5 stars.  Sushi seems quite authentic. It's more simple, elegant, and just good if you are in the mood for something light and fresh. The mackerel roll was the best in my opinion.  The fish tasted the best in that one.  Their hamachi was pretty good as well.  I was not too impressed with their alaska roll.  Couldnt really taste the salmon. The snow leapord roll was just okay, couldnt really taste the saba.  I would say that it is decent for the price.  Average roll is about $5.  Not too bad for the money.
author: Carrie T.

description:
Yum yum yum! This place truly had me mistaken from the outside, but once you go inside it's just the around the corner delicious sushi spot that doesn't have you wondering.

The salmon and tuna literally tasted like butter.(my own personal ref. just because it was so well prepared)The seaweed salad and miso soup are superb appetizers. Very fresh and made to order.

The menu has a variety of various rolls and dishes including yummy mango flavored rolls. 

The prices are very reasonable, and suitable for an around the way sushi place. Ran mostly by two people(not sure if they are brother and sister or married) but they run fast and efficient food.

A must check out if you are just out and about venturing the city.
author: Hillary H.

description:
Wayo Sushi gives great value for your dollar.  While it is small and simple with a very limited menu, the people are nice and the fish is tasty, especially considering how reasonably priced it is.  

The only real specialties Wayo offers are the brown rice rolls and its various mango rolls, but I typically stick to the normal menu.  Considering you can get edamame, seaweed salad, tea, and four-five rolls for under $30, it's a great place to go when you just want some sushi.
author: Gary C.

description:
Sushi was really tastey. The sushi chef was very friendly and helpful. The specials are on the wall behind the door, make sure you check those out. We had a special with mango and it was amazing.

We got out of here for under 50 bucks for 2 people eating sushi, but thats because we ordered a ton of rolls and maki, and had beer and sake.
author: Steve S.

description:
The 3 stars is probably due to the fact that I was expecting more from the reviews on yelp. Charming and incredibly clean place on California, near Van Ness run by a Japanese couple. The husband is a one-man show as he makes all the sushi and food.

Pros:
1. You get the choice of having brown rice on your sushi?! I loved the concept since I'm usually a big fan of brown rice. The sushi didn't hold up as well as regular sushi though.
2. Affordable - the prices are incredibly cheap for sushi. $5 for many rolls, including mango rolls which were very interesting.
3. The tea there was yummmyyy

Cons:
1. A bit of wait for food and service. As mentioned earlier, only a Japanese couple working there and handling everything all at once.
2. Smaller place. We were there first ones there as we had an early dinner around 5:30pm on a Sunday, but I can see how this place can get crowed real fast. Only 4 tables, seating 2 each and a few bar seats.

If you have a sushi craving and don't want to spend too much, Wayo can help you out.
author: Angela S.

description:
I wasn't going to write a review after my check in but I was so incredibly impressed with the service and FOOD that i was driven to this review!! 
first of all the rolls were amazing!! we had a variety of rolls from the menu and a few of the specials (mango tuna/salmon rolls). if you like real sushi and not over-the-top, over-sauced, dripping with pink mayo sushi, this place is for you. 
the owner is the guy making your sushi, he is extremely nice to talk to and in incredibly talented sushi chief. the rolls are natural and clean and would satisfy and sushi purist. some rolls were a bit heavy on the wasabi for me but nothing I can't handle.
second, the prices are great for what you get. three of us had sake and three rolls each and it was about $75. for San Fran this is amazing.
third, the service was incredible. my friend stole a mango piece from my sushi and the sushi chef leaned over and put in a new piece of mango in my roll.
please go here, you will not be disappointed. we will be back next time we come to san francisco.
author: Veronica S.

description: Don't bother calling they are too busy to pick up the phone.  Still gets five stars bc sashimi and that California roll with scallops is amazing.  I've been ordering hamachi for my recovering cancer kitty and this is his favorite place.
author: Poppy C.

description:
I'm a spoiled sushi eater after living in Vancouver (canada), so much so that after over a year in SF I have only gone out for raw fish 3 times! But I got a craving last week, and my roomate suggested this place.

The atmosphere is great; small, quaint, and extremely polite service.  I can't speak the speed of service as we (roomie, his gf, and I) were basically the only ones in there on a random tuesday night. 

We started with edamame and I got some miso soup, both were great.  Then we all shared a whole bunch of rolls: salmon avacado, unagi, spicy tuna, mango, and seared something or other.  All were good, the unagi was particularly good.  Also, 2 orders of tuna nigiri (2 piece per) which are always my favorite, and these ones were great.  

All in all, the rolls were very sastifying, though the unagi was the only one that really stood out.  The nigiri was cold and tasted very fresh.  The prices are better than most places you see around town.  The woman serving was super nice which goes a long way for me.  It ain't Vancouver, but I will definitely be going back!
author: Sam C.

description:
I made it.  Yes.  After much ado about nothing, and swearing up and down that I was suffering more than you, I finally found myself in the area.  It's farther away than I realized.  Much much farther away.  If it weren't for the plant factory, I don't know when I would have finally "sucked it up" and "stop being such a wimp."

Lou and I sat at the counter.  As others have said, the menu is limited, in that really nice specialized way.  Except for all the jive-ass mango going out.  From our precarious perch, we were able to hear a high pitched Asian girl in the corner complain to the woman-waitress that the Mango-crab roll was REALLY spicy and she actually couldn't eat it at all.  She sounded like ... 

We ordered cucumber salad (with crab for me, tako for him).  The vinegar for the salad is amazing!  They marinated it just long enough for the flavor to infuse the cucumber, but not so long that it has pickled and wicked away any freshness.  

I ordered amaebi, uni, and ika. I know.  Diversity.  All shellfish.  No fish.  What the wha?  Well, I get fish from the place across the street from work nearly twice a week.  So I needed something different.

Amaebi did not come with fried heads.  Uni was a deeper golden color than I would have liked but he did open the container freshly.  I dunno.  I think I need to limit uni to specific Tanuki instances.  Or Okina.  Or Koo.  The amaebi was ok, a bit flavorless, but that's better than fishy, right?  I mean, a dull shrimp is better than a ripe shrimp.  Haha.  

Ika was the highlight of the bunch.  It was crisp, tasty, sweet, firm and not chewy.  

We did not get anything to drink because I thought I was going to go home and write a motion and do my homework.  Also, it was really cold outside.  

I liked the feel of the place.  It's a diner meets traditional japanese hut.  It's like the 50's version of that nigiri place Uma Thurman trains her kung fu in Kill Bill.  Crome, red vinyl seats, U-shaped counter, old Japanese man wearing a satin cord tied around his head.  

The rice might have been a bit sweet.  Or I was very thirsty.  This place makes me want to eat sushi every day.  I want to just empty the fish from his tray into my mouth.  I saw the chef handling some delicious looking salmon nigiri that the white male sitting at the counter four seats down ordered and photographed.  I wonder if he Yelps?  I wonder if he wrote the review before this?  Or after?  I wonder if any Yelper will ever come up to me and say hi?  Instead of opening their eyes really wide until the white is visible all around the iris, and then speed walk to the other side of the street.  

I wonder if I will ever be accepted by my own kind?
author: Christina C.

description:
Thank you, San Francisco, thank you!

Now, this is an overall rating.  
By no means is this 5-star sushi, but it's delicious, very fresh sushi at prices I'd expect from far, far less.  Maybe even far, far, far less.  I found Wayo Sushi to be very charming.  I was visiting San Francisco for the weekend searching my Yelp app for some decent sushi, and strolled down to Sushi Zone.  Excited and hungry, I arrived at the front doors, only to see a sign that said they were closed that day and the next day.  This was a total fail.  

Hungry, tired and frustrated, we trudge back up the hill to Wayo Sushi.  This place is very small, only about four tables and a sushi bar.  It probably took at least 40 minutes for us to eat, but we sat at the sushi bar and watched as the ONE sushi chef created the entire restaurant's meals.  There was something enchanting about his accessibility and determination.  So enchanting, in fact, that I ignored my hunger throughout those 40 minutes.  

I was surprised at how fresh the food was.  I got a sashimi plate as well as a several rolls.  The eel was amazing.  The spicy tuna lived up to yelper's reviews.  I can't recommend this place enough.  Thanks, yelp, you never let me down.
author: Khalana O.

description: Friendly service and a great value. It's my favorite low/mid cost sushi joint in the city.
author: yoni s.

description: I will preface this review with the fact that I have only been here once, but I don't understand all the rave reviews that this place has received on yelp.  This restaurant doesn't have much to offer in the area of ambience.  It's pretty much a hole in the wall.  The service was friendly, but there was one sushi chef and one waitress serving the entire restaurant.  We were told that sushi rolls would take at least 30 minutes.  As far as the food, it was less than average.  The sushi rolls had too much rice, which takes away from the flavor.  The prices were okay.  I have had way better sushi in the eastbay.
author: Saeed E.

description: Really don't understand what people love about this place.  Went to this place recently and really could have gone to Kyoto nearby.  The menu is very limited.  The special of the day was mango based and not tasty.  It was pretty much an expensive meal for nothing.  It was so bad we actually went to Max's Opera House down the street and ate again.  Yes, I had to have second dinner or fourth meal, it was that bad.
author: Marvin P.

description:
Tiny little place between Mattress Discounters and Starbucks. Fits around 20 people. I had high hopes going in because it was recommended by a friend. 
I sat at the bar with my date. Honestly, if I wasn't with someone who I wanted to spend a lot of time with, I would say the wait was definitely too long for service and the food. There was one chef and one waitress, but the waitress warned us ahead of time that sushi will take around 30 minutes to arrive. 
We just soaked up the nice atmosphere in this small little place and had good conversation.
The sushi was above average. Definitely not the best I've ever had, but definitely deserves a high score if you throw in the price. I had the seared albacore special roll and the yellowtail sashimi. My date had the spicy tuna and mango roll. 
Overall a great experience. Would definitely go back again.
author: Ronny D.

description:
Delicious!!! As other reviewers have said, Wayo Sushi is the best sushi in the neighborhood. The sushi is really fresh and they offer interesting choices, especially their rolls with mango. The price is average for sushi in the area.

The restaurant is small but cute. It's usually very quiet and homey-feeling -- for some reason it's always very warm in there so don't dress too heavily! Try to sit at the bar if you can; you can watch the sushi chef prepare everything and he'll serve you right away. 

My favorites: sake sashimi and salmon mango roll.
author: Jackie C.

description:
so far, the best sushi in the neighborhood! 
I love it here!
its tiny perfection!
author: Katie A.

description:
The sushi was average and slightly overpriced.  I've found better for cheaper in the city.  I did like the spicy mango tuna, but be warned... it is verrry spicy.

On the plus side, it is a great location with nice atmosphere and excellent service.
author: Eric R.

description:
Outstanding sushi at ridiculously low prices..... 

I love this place. it's a cute little hole in the wall (hidden gem). Nothing fancy about the decor, just an intimate vibe with a few tables and some bar seating. Service is above average even though there is usually just one sushi chef and one server. I have never had to wait to be sat, altough I've never attempted to go on a Friday or Saturday night. I imagine it may be a bit crowded.

I am a huge spicy tuna fan, this place makes the best, hands down! SOOO spicy!!! A must try is the mango roll, and also the salmon cream cheese roll. The edamami is always perfectly warm, just the way I like it. The daily specials never fail to please the palate. 

If you're looking for superb sushi & modest prices in a small relaxed setting...you simply can't go wrong here!
author: Genie M.

description:
Wayo is definitely one of my favorite sushi restaurants in San Francisco. Wayo is clean, and is run by two people; the sushi chef and the waitress. I would not recommend coming here if you have a large group or if you expect speedy service. It's not that the service is bad, you just must be patient. 

The quality of the fish here is top notch. I can recommend the following:

- Sea Fairy Roll (scallop)
- Hamachi sashimi
- Uni (local)
- Unagi Nigiri (very fresh)
- Amaebi Nigiri
- Ikura Nigiri
- Saba nigiri

Everything was amazing and the presentation is nice as well. My only wish is that they had shiso leaf and daikon for the sashimi. 

Moderately priced for such great quality fish.
author: Bobby D.

description:
Each roll ranges from 5-10 dollars.  They come with about 6 pieces.  BUT don't be fooled.  The rolls are small, so you end up ordering alot, racking up the bill.  I only liked the fairy roll which included raw scallops ($10) and the mango roll with yellow tail ($5).  

This is a one man show, the husband makes the sushi, while the wife takes order.  The service is slow.  If you're looking for  plain rolls with no sauce, this is the place for you.  Also, the sushi rolls include a lot of wasabi,

On another note....the fish was fresh.
author: Joanne H.

description:
Wayo is a great neighborhood sushi spot. I wouldn't call it amazing - the sushi isn't anything special, but it's solid and they have some good rolls. I especially like the spicy tuna and avacado salad to start, I always get it, and then I'll sometimes get the mango salmon roll, or the dragon roll. I love yellowtail so I got the tiger roll (cooked yellowtail and terriyaki sauce) but it wasn't as good as I thought it would be. 

Overall it's good, not too expensive, and a nice place to go to when you want sushi but you don't want to venture far away - but I wouldn't make it a cross-town destination.
author: Ashley H.

description:
Sushi is my SO's favorite food, we are both from the orients, we eat sushi frequently.

My SO needed to get molds for her big fat mouth as her retainers broke so we were in the city.  We yelped sushi restaurants and it was a choice between Wayo and Tataki.

I decided on Wayo because, as much as I want to believe that sustainable food will keep us from eating raw goldfish as sushi in the future cuz all the tuna and salmon died out, I can't fathom that a few posh places happily branding that they are sustainable to attract tree huggers and mac users will make a difference.  It's either gonna have to be most restaurants doing sustainable or f-it.

As the great George Carlin said, the planet isn't going anywhere.  It will be fine.

Place def looks like a hole in the wall.  As we walked in, there was 4 tables it think and a bar with about 6 chairs.  The place looked like a burger joint converted to a sushi restaurant, very small, very quaint.

I looked into the kitchen and my mind was blown as there was no grill or stove it seemed.  I thought, wow, this place is totally dedicated to sushi.

We looked at the menu and it seemed like the lunch menu but was actually the whole menu.  We ordered the spinach with bonito flakes, the hamachi and sake (salmon) nigiri, and the yelpers recommendations mango and hamachi, and the spicy tuna roll.

The spinach with bonito flakes was good, but it was basic items put together to make a good dish.  Spinach was blanched, the compressed cold, served with soy sauce, flakes, and some sesame seeds.  It was rather refreshing as it was a hot day.  This appetizer made me excited for the sushi to come.

We got the mango and spicy tuna first.  Took a bite out of the mango roll and all i could take is mango and rice.  The rice was quite sticky and not very flavored.  I don't want to sound harsh but it seemed like the back-up to the back-up sushi maker was rolling these.  There was a sliver of hamachi which I could hardly taste.

All sushi was made with this hideous rice.  The spicy tuna . . . wasn't.  Again, the rice made it seem like I was eating an onigiri, or japanese rice ball.

The nigiri came out next.  Same rice.  Both the hamachi and sake tasted like it was frozen, then thawed out, with the ice crystals diluting the flavor of the meat.  I mean, seriously?  I've had better sushi from korean/chinese owned restaurants deep in San Mateo.

The sushi wasn't presented in any special way, there wasn't any happiness in that restaurant.  Just seemed like a business to get folks money and get them out.

Wayo, way-no, 2 stars.
author: Dirk M.

description: There are a lot of good sushi restaurants in SF and this is one of them. Went for the first time tonight - tiny little place but the sushi is the real deal. Had Dynamite Roll, maguro, Spicy Tuna Roll and a house special roll with seared albacore. All delicious and well priced for the quality. I'll be back.
author: Bruce W.

description: Visiting SF and stumbled on this sushi restaurant near my hotel. Small place not very fancy had to wait a bit for my sushi but OMG was it worth the wait. The miso was so fresh and well balanced. The cucumber crab salad was tangy and sweet. The sea fairy roll was a Cali roll topped with the sweetest freshest scallops  topped with masago. Probably the best roll I've ever had didn't leave a grain of rice. Great service also. Don't forget to order a Sapporo beer to go along with your sushi.
author: Eric C.

description:
Brown.Rice.Sushi. 

Here again, we have a potential glutinous nightmare turned glorious experience. Brown rice vegetable maki, pickled radish, and bottomless green tea. You can have white rice as well, but, if you havenever tried brown rice sushi, give it a try! It is nutty, chewy, and you tend to eat less and chew more! Tiny place, amenable staff, and a small, but comprehensive menu. My friend ordered the mango salmon roll, and I had endamame (prepared in fresh water, not left over soba noodle water as is often the case) , and no gluten in sight! Delightful, and unbelievably fresh and BARGAiN fare. Such a treat after work!
author: A. H.

description:
We went to Wayo on a recommendation from our neighbor.  Thumbs up for the recommendation and thumbs up for Wayo!

Food = 4.5.  Crazy fresh sushi and sashimi.  I started with the spicy tuna salad, composed of chunky pieces of avocado and sliced tuna sashimi (not mushed up tuna), and dressed with wasabi and a spicy sauce.  I then had a dragon roll and yellow-tail sashimi and salmon sashimi.  The fish was so fresh and rich.  The cuts were also generous in view of the extraordinarily reasonable prices.  My boyfriend had the tuna sashimi, a shrimp tempura roll and the mango crab roll.  His fish was also outstanding.

Service = 4.5.  The sushi chef is one hardworking man!  He was taking orders, taking away plates and serving up his delicious creations at a furious pace!  The waitress was also working the joint like she had 5 arms.  We didn't have to wait for anything and the staff was super nice!

Atmosphere = 3.  Wayo is one of those neighborhood establishments that doesn't blow you away with decor.  The place is clean but really small and minimal.
author: Eddie L.

description:
fresh sushi
cozy atmosphere
bit of a  wait 
we will be back!
author: C C.

description:
Walking up the small ramp and taking in the scenery, you notice that the restaurant seats fewer than 30 people.  A kind of small that's both comforting and claustrophobia-inducing.
