It immediately appeared that it was the owners running the show... a good thing to see every so often.

The Spicy Yellowtail w/ Mango was outstanding.  It had a touch of spice that gave it a healthy kick, helping you enjoy each bite even further. 

The salmon was slightly better than decent... fresh, soft, flavorful. 

Spicy tuna was surprisingly good.  Typically, spicy tuna is served as ground tuna with some kind of spicy chili mixed in.  In this case, the tuna was served intact but with that chili sauce again.  It was different and impressive, to say the least.

We never saw the bottoms of our green tea, which is always a plus.  

Given the price of everything, I'm definitely coming back for more.  I'll be trying out some of their fancier named dishes to see whether they live up to their title.

Till next time.  4 Stars.
author: Johnson N.

description:
I will definitely be back. When I first peeked at the menu on the window, I thought that the choices were very limited but decided to give it a try anyway -- and boy was I glad I did! It was one of the most enjoyable meals at a sushi restaurant that I've ever had. I ordered the Dynamite Roll (spicy tuna + avocado) and the Alaska roll (Salmon + Avocado). One thing that stood out about this place was the rice. YES, the rice. I understand sushi chefs usually take 3 years just to learn how to season the rice just right and the taste was absolutely perfect! The way sushi rice should be. Also, the salmon was fresh and flavorful but packed a punch as the chef put just the right about of unannounced wasabi into the roll. That caught me off guard but the flavors were very well balanced. The spicy tuna roll was one of the best I've had, you don't taste the spicy-ness initially but it gets you towards the second half of chewing. 

This place is definitely quality over quantity. It hit the spot just right and I didn't leave feeling full, bloated, or cheated. The prices are decent for what it is. I will be back soon to try their mango roll creations. 

A note about the service, it was very slow because there are only 2 people working, the chef and the waitress. So if the restaurant is already half full when you walk in, prepare to wait 20-30 minutes for your meal to come.
author: Crystal C.

description:
My favorite sushi spot in the city!! Love this place. They have the BEST sushi/sashimi. Very friendly, always willing to let you know if the wait time will be too long (when you're on your lunch break, you only have a limited time). Not a fancy, frilly restaurant, but the fish is fresh and the sushi is to die for. Love it!
But go after 1pm on weekdays...so I can get my lunch!! :)
author: Sara B.

description:
Ran into this place on Yelp when my friend came to visit Berkeley a couple of years ago, and it became a staple of his biannual trips. It's one of the best sushi I've tried in NorCal; fresh fish, rice cooked just right, and a dab of wasabi. (I would know, I've had superfresh sushi in a fish market in Tokyo.) Not a huge variety of rolls, but their specials are good (Mango salmon roll is my favorite!); besides, I'm a fan of nigiri.

I love that it's a small family-owned spot, just a chef and a server all the time. But I've never had to wait, and I've always gone on a Saturday night. The only downside is that the miso soup is a ridiculous $2 (with no free refills!) and they don't have TORO. Nevertheless, my friends and I are coming back until the chef with the funny headband retires or something.
author: Benjamin C.

description: Small place. Sushi came slow but we were warned that it would. Very good, though. Mango roll specials today.
author: xx x.

description: I LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.  I am a sushi fanatic, and this is place is absolutely wonderful.  the fish is super fresh and the owner and his staff are so sweet and great.  the wait does get very long because there are only 2 people working at a shift, including the sushi chef, so keep that in mind if you are short on time.
author: Foodie R.

description:
Slow but only because they had one person, I assume the owner, behind the bar preparing the food. The waitress was very nice. The water was even cucumber water which was a nice touch.

The rolls were very good. No non-traditional west coast rolls. All the rolls were traditional rolls. There was no other choice of food other than sushi, which was a disappointment for the Wife. No chicken teriyaki or karahi chicken or sushi alternative choices.

It was a nice place aesthetic wise as well simple and clean and not over crowded. A good duck in off the street sushi bar but not a full fledge go out for sushi restaurant.
author: Jesse W.

description:
The sushi here was pretty good. I wouldn't go as far as the best sushi ever but the sushi was fresh and tasty. I came with a fellow yelp friend of mines which was great company. The only thing about our visit here was that we did have to wait quite a while for our food because there was only 1 sushi chef for the whole restaurant. Luckily for us, the time seemed to pass by.

She ordered the sushi plate which had some tuna maki, nigiri, soup and salad. I ordered some different nigiri, a dragon roll and a spicy hamachi roll. I also happened to order an order of uni and let her try 1 after I did. She had a bad experience with it before and I insisted that she tried it again. She was a champ and did try it again and liked it. Uni is usually really good or pretty horrible depending on how fresh it is. It was fresh on this occasion.

Would I come back? Quite possibly.
author: Darryl P.

description:
Classic Japan style experience. Small place, delicious food, excellent attention to detail. The fish was fresh and flavorful. 

I loved that I felt as though I was in my favorite izakaya in Kamakura. Its a new find for me and I'll definitely be back.
author: Mickey D.

description:
Best, freshest sushi I've ever had (and I spent a semester studying in Tokyo!). It's a totally weird location and the only reason we found it was because a guy at Mattress Discounters recommended it, but it is LEGIT. 

I think it's run by a husband and wife team. The husband makes ALL the sushi and the wife waits on ALL the tables. If you come for dinner, try to get there as soon as it opens, or later in the night, like after 9, otherwise "Sushi will take about 45 minutes - 1 hour." It's worth it though. 

Try the sake nigiri (or any other fresh raw fish sushi) and the house roll - my 2 faves!
author: Maria Y.

description:
I love this place.  It's one of my favorite sushi places in SF.  It's not a "scene" so if that's what you want, head elsewhere.  It's all about the food here.

The sushi chef is very meticulous (and clean) so service can be slow if it's busy.  But, it's always worth the wait (just order miso soup and other appetizers while you wait for your sushi).

If you want very fresh sushi at a reasonable price, this is the place to go.  The albacore sashimi literally melts in your mouth.
author: Shelly W.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Monday. Being a newly-minted uni eater, I wanted to try uni at every sushi place I went to. BAAAD idea. The uni ($5) on top of the seaweed and rice was not only sparse, it wasn't good. I hate the fishy taste.

Spicy yellowtail mango roll & spicy tuna mango roll ($5 each) was decent. They added some peppers on it and it reminded me of the mango with lime and peppers that you get from the Mission.

Snow Leopard Roll (seared albacore w/ ponzu sauce - ~$7.50ish): tasteless. I guess that's why the ponzu sauce is there.

Sea Fairy Roll (raw scallop on top of California Roll - $9.50): scallop was fresh but overall still pretty plain. My scallop-loving friend enjoyed it, though.

Heard their brown rice rolls are good but not a big fan so didn't try it.

Three people: uni nigiri, spicy yellowtail mango roll, spicy tuna mango roll, sea fairy roll, snow leopard roll = ~ $35. It's OK...
author: Tina T.

description:
I love Mom and Pop sushi places.  Wanted to get some dinner before hitting the Red Devil's Lounge to see some bands.  Since Mikey U has been talking about sushi on Twitter all week.  I was craving for some badly.  It is a really small sushi place and only run by the husband and wife.  When we walked in there was a number of customers waiting for sushi.  You know the sushi is good, plus they got a Yelp sticker on the front door.  

We had to wait awhile for our sushi but I didn't mind since we were not in a rush.  They pretty much just serve sushi where which was great and fresh. Had some interesting combos like with Mango but I didn't try them.  I end up ordering the assorted sushi and it was good and not bad for the price.  Its a great little place to just have some good sushi and convo.  I say a good place to bring a date. Overall dinner was great and would back when I am in the area again.
author: Donna Y.

description: I was expecting a bit more from this place when I saw the reviews. The decor was simple, but the kitchen area is open and it looks a little thrown together. The food was alright, but the prices weren't too bad. I ordered a spicy scallop handroll and a Philidelpia roll, both of which I am not sure I would order again. Way too much rice on the Philidelphia roll and the Spicy Scallop handroll was smothered with wasabi throughout which typically doesn't happen. I hate to say it, but I probably wouldn't come back if I was in the area...I would try something else.
author: Holly F.

description:
All these people claiming the sushi is well worth the wait are simply incompetent. The sushi was fine enough. The sake sashimi tasted fresh but the presentation was sloppy. Likewise with the rolls. The rice was falling off and it simply was not put together very well. This would be tolerable if the service was impeccable but unfortunately, it was far from it.

We waited over an hour to get our food. There were no more than 6 or 7 other groups there. If this guy is trying to emulate the dining experience of Jiro Dreams of Sushi, then he's got a long ways to go. 

My recommendation: don't waste your time at this place.
author: Steve C.

description:
Where else can you have four rolls (two of them the "special" rolls), two cucumber salads (one with crab), a glass of Chard and miso soup for 36 dollars.  Really?  Really.

The rolls were fairly fresh, although the Mango Spicy Yellowtail roll that I had was particularly bland.  I tasted neither mango or YT.  The Dynamite roll was tasty, though.  My companion, who used to be a regular at Wayo back in the day, had no complaints on any of her dishes, but there certainly was no gushing about.

Point-blank, period, had I ordered the same items at another sushi restaurant in town, and paid the usual crazy prices also in town, for the same experience, I would have been pissed.  Overall, the sushi is just above worth the cost of the meal.  I love tuna, especially spicy tuna, but ventured outside the bento box tonight.  I will go back to Wayo and check theirs out soon.

Oh, and a little dark in there it is, I have to say...
author: Tamar D.

description:
My very first Yelp review, here goes!

First things first, the price is phenomenal, very inexpensive for very good sushi.  A lot of people recommend the Mango roll, it was definitely worth trying since the taste of mango with sushi is very unique.  The sashimi is very fresh for the price you pay.

The tables are pretty close to each other, so people can easily eavesdrop on your conversation or vice versa...we ended up sitting at the bar so we could watch the sushi chef make the rolls.  You may have to wait a while for your order since there is only one chef and one waitress.  However, totally worth it.
author: Irving Z.

description:
Great sushi and sashimi from a Mum and Papa sushi joint. Very tiny place with 2-3 tables and ~10 seats by the counter. 

We waited for 30 minutes for our food, but it's worth every minute.
author: BT J.

description:
For a rare dinner out sans kids, I turned to Yelp for guidance on a good sushi place near downtown. Based on the reviews here, I decided to try Wayo Sushi on Van Ness. 

The good news is that we had no trouble finding parking right out front, and we did not get food poisoning. The bad news is mostly everything else. When we arrived, the sushi chef was the only person working. No server, no one to seat us, no one to take our drink or food order. There were two other parties already seated (one of whom had a super cute baby that smiled easily...bonus!). When we seated ourselves at the last table, the place was at maximum capacity everywhere but at the sushi bar.  Eventually, the sushi chef himself came over and took our order, promptly returning with my Sapporo. 

The menu is short, and for the purist. Standard offerings of nigiri and sashimi, with a few suggested "speciality rolls," none of which seemed all that special. I ordered the Snow Leopard Roll, mainly because I like snow leopards (to look at, not to eat), and asked that they hold the avocado (it gives me a stomachache.) The result was bland, dry and pedestrian. My husband ordered seaweed salad, sashimi, and Uni nigiri, which is one of his favorites. The Uni looked fresh, a relief because old Uni looks like loogies on rice and turns my stomach. Otherwise, nothing remarkable one way or another. 

After quickly finishing our food, neither of us was in the mood to order more so we quickly paid our check and left. We weren't hungry any longer, which is nice, but we certainly weren't satisfied. Nothing special here and likely won't go back again.
author: Bonnie J.

description:
Tiny little place that was empty early wednesday evening. I almost missed it as it was dimly lit and looked closed.

Had some refreshing seaweed salad to start before feasting on a couple rolls and some nigiri. The fish were quality, so it's pretty reasonably priced for the ingredients they use.

It appears as if the place is run by just the couple, so its a pretty small operation. Not sure how they handle large groups.

I haven't been to other sushi places in the area, but being in Japan Town I would expect there are a few places that are more authentic than Wayo. They don't several items that I am used to seeing on the menu (including red or Japanese snapper, my favorite), and they instead have Americanized mango and cream cheese concoctions. Though I guess I should try them before I bash them. Either way, I was satisfied, though it won't leave a lasting memory for me to hurry back.
author: Dennis C.

description: This is a hole in the wall sushi joint on Van Ness with one sushi chef and one server (probably his wife or daughter would be my guess.) The menu is limited, so that is why I gave it only 4 stars; but if you want to know you are getting the freshest fish out there, this would be the place to go.
author: Sharon R.

description: Complete hole in the wall, very small, excellent sushi, come here for extremely fresh fish, not American rolls.  Dynamite roll was great, rainbow roll was one of the best I've had.  Very reasonable prices. Highly recommended for fresh sushi
author: Grant D.

description:
Inexpensive and good quality fish.

1.  I went here with some friends on a Saturday afternoon and were seated and promptly served drinks.  Good job!
2.  The waitress took our orders and brought the appetizer right away.
3.  The sushi did take a while to get since there was only one sushi guy.

the food is very very reasonable.  it tastes good and their specials are pretty nice. 

i also like their sashimi.  

good work.  keep it up.  

reasons not to go:
1.  small
2.  not ur fancy trendy sushi decor
3.  slow service
author: Milan D.

description: Good prices. Not very fancy, a small shop, but good food. There aren't any specialty rolls, just the basic ones offered at most sushi restaurants, but they do it well!
author: John M.

description: I was on a vacation visiting SF looking for a few places to eat. The first night we found ourself here at a single-room sushi restaurant run by a husband and wife team. We arrived a bit later in the night so service issues noted before were not an issue. The sushi was, as most people have stated, good, cheap, and expected. Nothing was too creative but I did enjoy the absence of mayo-sauce on every dish. Being from LA I might be a bit biased but I thought the fish was sold at an incredibly reasonable price. Although this wouldn't be a place I had to revisit, it was a quality meal and would highly encourage anyone who wants well priced sushi to head over to Wayo Sushi!
author: Ryan T.

description: Way overpriced for what you get.. very friendly service but very mediocre sushi.
author: Dan C.

description:
I found this place purely as a victim of circumstance. For the twenty millionth time I tried to go to Sushi Sho in the east bay only to have the place be closed, the wait be obnoxious, two seats be separated by some fat ass who refused to move down one seat or me getting too drunk beforehand to properly behave in a place like that. 

I was not drunk when I dined here. I was, however, seriously craving some good sushi, Sushi Sho had let me down once again, and I had heard this place could fill the void left in my heart and stomach. They did.

There are only two people working here on the weekend and one on weekdays so patience is a virtue, but one that pays off when you get your food. The menu is simple with the exception of a few fancy rolls, at least 50% of them including mango (the reason I could not bring myself to give this place 5 stars). 

If you like fancy crazy deep fried crap and shit sticking out of the ends and piled on top of your sushi then this is definitely not the place. If you like a quiet place where the emphasis is on quality then you will not be disappointed.
author: Drue C.

description:
This place was only ok.. My cousin and I came here after playing soccer and we wanted something light and cheap, so she recommended Wayo. We had the cream cheese crab roll, snow leopard (seared albacore), and the fairytale roll?... well fairy-something (california roll topped with scallops). The service wasn't the best, it was really difficult getting the waitress's attention.. but I could sympathize since she was the only one taking care of the 6 patrons. 

The place was very clean and the food was alright, but beware if you are not a fan of wasabi because they put a bit of wasabi in every roll. I'm personally not a fan of wasabi, I just don't like the flavor... but my cousin loves it, so if you do too you would probably like this place better than I did.
author: Alison L.

description:
I've walked by Wayo Sushi for over 10 years and thought nothing of it until I read the reviews on Yelp.

Met a date there and no reservation was required.  The hostess told us that it would take about 30 minutes to get our order and we didn't mind; It gave us time to talk.  There are 8 tables that seats 2 and about 10 bar/counter seats.  There is only 1 chef and 1 hostess so if you're not in a hurry the sushi is great here.  It was a very comfortable place.

I have to give the hostess 5 stars alone because she is just sooo patient.  She approached us a couple of times for our order and since we were caught up in our conversation, we didn't pick anything out.  She stood there patiently with a smile.

We ordered:
spicy tuna salad --  GREAT!!
seaweed salad - pretty good
salmon sashimi -- so fresh and melts in your mouth
Hamachi - vvery good
ebi roll - very good

We ordered sake and I think she was generous about the portion.

This IS a hidden gem and I'd definitely come back here again and again.  This is my new sushi place to go to.  The price is INEXPENSIVE!!!  My five stars given to the hostess is my own separate rating aside from the five I've given the restaurant.
author: R M.

description:
A small, family run sushi place, with really high quality fish. 

The hamachi, especially, was excellent.  As was the cucumber/octopus salad (which, though, is more cucumber than octopus).  The salmon was melt-in-your-mouth and the eel was super fresh.  

It was empty when we got there at 7:30 on a Saturday but filled up while we were there.

I recommend.
author: Katie Z.

description: Stopped in after yelping sushi next to my friends house as my wife and I were craving some raw fish! Apparently the people eating at this place have not had good sushi. The service was extremely slow, I will not go as far as saying the service was bad, just slow as it took an hour to get our main rolls. Now I mainly attribute this to their being only one chef who is also the owner. As far as the food is considered I would say that sub-par is a fair rating because it takes so long for the food to arrive that the fish is warm when it is served. They also do not use cucumber, they use lettuce which i dont understand. The good is that the rolls aren't too expensive and they use real crab. I will not be returning here again, but not in a bad way.
author: Jay J.

description:
I loved everything about this place and had been wanting to try it for a while...and did so Friday night with a great feeling of success when I left.  

I mark the box YES, for: Delicious and appealing sushi; affordable; clean; courteous staff; good location for people watching; my imminent return! HAZAH for this place. Come by and try a piece yo! (I recommend their mongo sushi roll specials...'specially the yellowtail one)
author: Veronica S.

description: Oooh my roomie and I dropped by Wayo because our movie plans at AMC Van Ness fell through Thursday night! I wasn't disappointed, though, because I got to try Wayo. This is a super cute hole-in-the-wall run by a husband and wife team. We shared a large sake, she had the avocado and tuna roll, I had the snow leopard roll and the spicy salmon skin roll. We sat at the sushi bar while the chef made the rolls in front of us! This is an ideal spot for couples on an intimate date, or friends to sit at the bar. I even saw singles grabbing a quick bite on their breaks or after the gym across the street. Try this unpretentious spot for some high grade, quality Sushi. We both came at about 8:30 pm and were seated promptly but hear it gets awfully crowded at the 6-8 pm period.
author: Patricia M.

description: Great service and clean establishment. Super fresh nigiri and very reasonable pricing for the quality.  I highly recommend this place, its a gem.  The chef and servers are really nice and make you feel welcome.  The place is not over-decorated, over-designed, or over the top.  It gets 5 stars for doing exactly what it means to, and nothing more, perfectly.
author: Garrett G.

description: This place is just lovely.  Very casual sushi place with great specials, a chilled out feel, and incredibly fresh fish. I particularly recommend the sushi rolls with mango in them - listed on the board.  The owner is so nice, and our waitress (his wife?) was incredibly straightforward and honest in telling us what fish was the freshest that day.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Mediocre sushi, slow service, average prices.

Salmon is not supposed to be chewy. Theirs was. I went here with a date and it was a huge disappointment. I was hoping for a cute hole in the wall sushi restaurant  with good food, what I got was really mediocre. And the dragon roll was pretty poorly done, I have had so much better so many times. In my opinion, you would be a lot better off going to Sudachi's - it's cheaper, way better ambiance, faster service, nicer service, and the fish isn't amazing but it is much better than this.

Also my date did not handle the sushi well and got a bit sick, so yeah, that's not good. Not coming back here, there's just too many sushi places to give it a second shot.. bill totaled $50 for 1 large beer and 4 rolls. At that price I can have GOOD sushi not this stuff.
author: David H.

description:
Just got back from dinner here on a Sunday night.

The two of us ordered four rolls (3 of them were 6 pieces and 1 was 4 pieces) and green tea ice cream, and the total check was $29 after tax! Def reasonably priced! I can't remember the names of all the rolls, but my favorite was a california roll topped with scallops. They also gave a very healthy portion of green tea ice cream :)

I also liked having the brown rice option. I liked it, but the BF didn't (he said it tasted too "healthy"). I wish they had tamago bc that's my BF's favorite, so he was a bit disappointed they didn't have that.

Overall - great place!
author: Jane M.

description:
Gotta say I like this this place and been there several times.Seems like it is run by a husband and wife team very pleasant and the food is very good. This was the first time I ever tried Sushi with brown rice, hey I tried it but went back to white rice.
The quality of the Sushi is very good, prices reasonable, people in the establishment cool. My suggestion is to get there early sometimes can be up to an hour wait because it is small, but well worth it.
author: Kenn P.

description:
Nah. 

I like hole-in-the-wall places (+1).
They were playing some old jazz in the background (+1). 
This is a small independent business seemingly run by a husband and wife (+1).
The price is reasonable - I guess. 

I'm sorry, but the sushi here is totally amateur, not up to my authentic sushi standards. I tried a couple of nigiris and quickly switched to Americanized rolls (aka jive-ass-rolls, per Mr. nobu k). 

My brother who used to work as a cook at a casual izakaya-type restaurant in Japan years ago (note: not a serious sushi-restaurant) makes way better nigiri than Wayo's. The nigiri at Wayo is just about as good as nigiri would be if I ever made one (and I've never made one in my life). 

I would not consider it a serious sushi restaurant. However, Wayo has a nice laid-back vibe, is pretty clean and cozy, and the people here seem pretty nice. I might stop by for a glass of Sapporo and a dragon roll after a long day of work.
author: Nana N.

description:
the fish was really fresh and delicious, and the rolls were very simple.  I like my rolls to have tempura shrimp or some baked scallops, but Wayo didn't offer these kind of rolls.  It was more of a simple fish & avocado/cucumber place, but the fish quality totally made up for that.

The place is very tiny, and there is only one sushi chef, so prepare for a wait!
author: H. L.

description:
Affordable, authentic and fresh sushi! Wayo's menu consists of various types of maki, nigiri, and sashimi so if you're looking for fancy/baked/rolls on fire, this is not your place. 

Somethings to note:
- They also give you the option of using brown rice which is awesome, although it doesn't stick together nearly as well and kept falling apart when I tried to use soy sauce
- Wayo uses real crab meat, not imitation.
- GET THE SCALLOPS. They taste like straight up BUTTER. We tried them on the snow fairy roll (california roll topped with raw scallops). I think that was what it was called.
- Wait can get long as the restaurant has 4 small tables and bar seating only. The waitress kept telling customers that the wait would be ~40 min for sushi since they only had one chef working.
- If you're hungry, rolls are on the smaller size so it'd be better to order more than less since you'd have to wait a while for your order.

All in all, a great establishment. I'll def be back!
author: Stefi C.

description: Wayo's been my neighborhood sushi joynt for years (about 12). If you're looking for a Rock & Roll and a noisy spot to hook up don't come here, Please. If you're looking for great sushi from a master. this IS your spot. Yes, the wait can be long (an hour was quoted at my last visit) but it's worth coming in a little early or later to avoid the crowd. I don't recommend it for a large group, the seating's limited and you'll take over the place so I'll never be able to get in the door.
author: jim K.

description: We were wondering the streets craving high quality sushi and happened upon Wayo. The owners warmly greeted and seated us immediately.  The spicy salmon skin & house specialty rolls were very tasty. We also ordered a variety of nigiri - squid, eel, sweet shrimp,  albacore & salmon roe.  It was ALL phenomenal! Lots of yummy sushi for only $40! We left happy & satisfied. Check it out you won't be disappointed.
author: Mr B.

description:
Cheap sushi is an oxymoron; either that or it tastes like shit and leaves you sitting on the porcelain throne the next day. At least, that's what I thought until I stumbled upon Wayo. A very unassuming place staffed by only two employees, the wife handles the waitressing while the husband makes the food.

The crown jewel of Wayo is the hamachi sashimi. At $9 for five thick fresh slices, this is by far the best deal in town. Each slice consisted of magnificent whitish fish with a stunning rose colored tip. These were served at the perfect temperature to maximize their sweet, milky and buttery flavors. They literally melted in your mouth. Waitress, keep these coming please!

Unfortunately, the crown jewel is the only thing reliable at this sushi joint. Avoid the rolls at all costs. With dry bland rice, damp seaweed and flavorless fish, these were major disappointments. Maybe I came on a bad day, but the uni, maguro, unagi and the special mango rolls all tasted like dusty old shoeboxes. The service is also bit slow, but go ahead, I dare you to piss off a sushi chef and order uni nigiri at the same time.
author: Alex C.

description:
I came in here last week for some much needed sushi.  This place is awesome!  I can understand how people complain about the service here, as when we were here there were only two people working; a husband and a wife I assume.  The male rolled the sushi, the female took care of the server duties.  I could imagine that when this place got crowded things would slow down quite a bit.  But, there were only about 8 other people in the restaurant so this was not an issue for us.

The fish came out pretty quickly, and it was all delicious.  We ordered a variety of tuna, some yellowtail, edamame, and a couple of beers for our dinner.  The fish cost us LESS THAN $20.  WHAT??  I think this place will become a regular dining establishment for me based on this experience.  

As long as you aren't in a hurry, this place is well worth it.  The couple who run it is friendly and they know how to do what they do.
author: William B.

description:
Hidden gem no more! I've waited over an hour to sit at the bar and longer for a table. 

This is cheap authentic sushi, when i come here I almost feel like I'm stealing. The rolls start at $5 and the most expensive one is $9.50. If you prefer brown rice in lieu of white, just ask. Fresh grade A fish melts in your mouth, no chewing required. The rolls are very traditional and they have specials written a on whiteboard, it's been mango for a while.

The inside is nothing fancy. There is a picture of geisha girls and Mt. Fiji. 3 tables along the window and a black bar that seats 18. It can get hot inside and there's one fan. 

Did I mention the chef and the waitress is Japanese? I mention this because some of my friends say the best sushi places have Japanese chef.
author: Lola L.

description:
This is one of my new favorite restaurants in San Francisco.

Thankfully, I live close enough to this place that I can call it my neighborhood sushi joint. It's authentic, relatively cheap and tasty. The same one guy prepares all the sushi, so an appetizer is recommended if you've got a burning hole in your stomach. But really, if you've got a burning hole in your stomach maybe dining out shouldn't be your primary point of focus...

Quiet. Romantic. Warm. I bring everyone I want to impress here and liquor them up with hot sake.

(Yes, I brought my mom here too.)
author: Keane L.

description:
Wayo means, kind of a, Japan meets West, something like that.
Wa as Wa-shoku( J-food), Yo as Yo-shoku( Western food), dig?

This place is 100% Japanese.
Very Clean.
It looks like a little dinner before lookin' U-shape counter.
Not too big.
There was a hard-working Japanese couple.
I sat down the counter right in front of the Chef.
I took a little bow to him.
He bowed back to me.

After I ordered 8 Nigiris.

Chef: "...it is very hard to keep my business goin' just making Nigiris..."

Nobu: " I see. By the way, what are you making right now?"

Chef:  " Oh, this is one of my special, Mango rolls."

Nobu:  " ! ? "

Chef:  " Yes, I know. It is not for us but it's not too bad, actually."

Nobu:  " I'd love to try that next time."

Chef:  " Hahaha, that'll be good."

The conversation was all Japanese.
I think this guy is a good man.
But,
He looks just like Koizumi, the X-prime minister of Japan.
Koizumi was such a ham, wasn't he? He was under the GW's thumb.  "Hazukashii", sigh.

Price was pretty cheap.
His Nigiri was not my kind but  "Shari" was pretty good.
The Chef was a very soft spoken man who understands the Sushi-Market in SF very well.
He knows what he is doing isn't traditional.
AT ALL!
So, I don't need to say it.
But,
I do have a mix feelings about this place.
He might be a great Sushi Chef but he makes more Jive Ass Rolls instead.
Well,
this is Wayo the Japan meets West, isn't it.

I do like to support small, local businesses  like this place.
So, I'll be back.
Maybe with friends or my vegan boys next time.
They'll love the Mango-thing.
But,
would I like the Mango roll?
Ahhh,
I haven't decided yet.
3.4 stars.
author: Nobu K.

description: Yes, it is only one sushi chef so you have to wait. Yes, it is fresh and delicious and fairly priced. Get there when they open and there is no wait.
author: Brandon C.

description:
After reading reviews on this place and having a mad sushi craving I dragged my BF here on Mon night.

I am in love. 

We walked in and were immediately told 30 min wait for sushi by the only sushi chef. we said no problem. had ourselves some beer and miso soup in the meantime. 

sushi came after about 30 mins and was amazing. we had 5 rolls for 23.50. UNHEARD OF! spicy tuna was fresh and spicy. crab was seasoned and the shrimp was amazing. yellowtail was fresh as well.

overall, i'm in love. i think i have found my new sushi spot.
author: laura f.

description: My concierge sent me to Sanraku. Way too stuck up and fancy so I came here. Very low key but high quality. Top 10 in my 30 sushi years.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Not as awesome as many of the reviewers claim... decent.. but not awesome.

My girl friend and I left half way through the meal after realizing how tiny the sashimi slices were.  The miso was pretty solid.

We surmised that the inflated reviews were a result of the people that come here from Pacific Heights, and just don't know any better.

Good luck!  The family that works there is nice.
author: Peter G.

description:
I really like Wayo.  It's a small-- almost very small-- sushi bar right on VanNess Ave.  The storefront is so small that you could easily miss it even if you were looking for it.  

Despite their hours of something like 5-10pm every night of the week (no lunch), there is a good chance you will have to wait for your sushi order if you come during peak dining hours on a Thursday, Friday, or Saturday.  This is because all of your sushi is made by one authentic Japanese sushi chef.  When this happens to us and the owner warns us of a good 30-40 minute wait for our order, we order right away and sit back with a nice glass of sake and have some edamame and miso soup (no wait).  But at least he is wise and considerate enough to let you know about the wait *before* you start to order.

I think that there is usually no wait if you eat a bit later in the evening and there are no large parties present.

Street parking in the area can also be very difficult.  All this makes for a bit more effort in getting there and getting situated than some other places. 

But I gave Wayo such a high rating because it does so many things right:

1. Very relaxing, adult, mature atmosphere.  Every once in awhile you get a loud group of obnoxious people, but for the most part it is small groups and couples eating and talking at considerate noise levels.  

2. Good sake.  It goes so well with sushi.

3. Wayo strikes a good balance between quality and value.  It is admittedly not as elite as something like a sushi-ran, but the sushi is consistently good and the prices are fair.

4. Have you ever tried the salmon with brown rice nigiri sushi?  Though they offer something similar at the Whole Foods sushi section, I think that having this along with the other traditional white rice sushi types is a nice contrast at the same meal.  Though not traditional to some sushi purists, there is something about brown rice sake nigiri that is so good.  Try ordering something like this at Ino-sushi and they'll probably throw you out.

5. Sushi places are so often either cheap and unauthentic feeling-- or going the other extreme-- so stuffy, expensive and elitist as to be not fun.   Wayo strikes a very good balance, being a nice, pleasant place that has the elements of class and comfort of the high end places but without the pretension and very high prices.

Highly recommended.
author: Dave N.

description:
Now days it's very rare for me to walk into a sushi bar and find a place where they are passionate for nigri.  Way to often I come in and I see a massive menu filled with different rolls, sauces and a combination mish-mash of different fish stuffed into a roll.    When I go out and eat sushi I want to be able to taste and appreciate the natural flavor, fat and texture that each piece of fish or seafood provides.  I don't want to have the taste of saracha (Vietnamese red hot sauce, which is great in pho but not in sushi. IMO.) or god forbid to go and make a roll and deep fry the whole damn thing.

 I must agree with some of the reviews, at this place it is fairly slow, I was in a party of three and we spent close to about 2 and a half hours eating here.  I will say that if you are hungry to make sure you order a bit heavier on your initial order should you be sitting at the tables, if you try to order a few things at a time you will be in for a longer meal.  That said the shiro maguro, hotate, amaebi, sake (salmon not the drink) , ika, tako and the uni was really really good.  My friends did also try a few rolls, which I thought were decent, but I still felt very satisfied with the quality of nigri.  They do offer a brown sushi rice substitute, which sounds interesting but I think Ill deal with the higher carbs and low fiber for the time being.

The woman that worked here was very nice and was constantly circulating the room to keep every ones table full.  There was only one chef behind the counter but he seemed very in control and did his best dealing with the number of orders that stacked up and not matter how busy it got, his sushi through out the night was constantly good.  Free parking here can be tough to find, there are a few pay by hour garages, still I think it is a worth while stop if you like sushi, it is hard to find and isn't as visible but that said, I kinda like it that way too....
author: Chris T.

description:
I've only been in the city for 2 months and I've been here 5 times. The sushi is DELICIOUS. All of their ingredients--particularly the fish--tastes so fresh. I haven't found anything better in San Francisco so far.  The mango rolls (mango and salmon in particular) that they have been offering this summer are to die for. 

The restaurant is very small, but every time that I've gone (Friday and Saturday nights included), I've managed to get a table. Because they only have one sushi chef (who does a phenomenal job), the wait-time for sushi can be 30 minutes, but they warn you about this up-front if that's the case so that you can decide whether you want to stay or not. I recommend staying! It's so worth it! 

The menu is smaller than some other nearby sushi places, but the product is just so much better. The restaurant also feels very clean and has a nice ambiance despite its small size.

In addition to the sushi, the miso soup is great (and, again, tastes very fresh). The seaweed salad and the green salad are also good. I'll definitely be back!
author: Christine C.

description:
This is a nice husband and wife run sushi joint on Van Ness. Good fish, good service, good prices and no wait. Hard to beat. I will say that the spicy albacore and mango, while tasty was super spicy with an asskicking wasabi blast. Also, if you are into healthy sushi  you can sub in  brown rice. 

Great place to grab dinner before a movie at AMC Van Ness or before a show at Great American Music Hall or after shopping at American Rag or while waiting for your Sprint phone to be serviced across the street.
author: Phil M.

description:
Thanks to all the yelpers out there I tried Wayo last night. I was going to try Fresh sushi as it is in my neighborhood but the thought of real pickled(?) ginger dragged my butt onto the Muni 22 with a transfer to Muni 49. 

I was introduced to good sushi in Tokyo and especially enjoyed the ginger. Whenever I see the pink ginger served here in the US I quickly recall the preservative aftertaste and always take a pass. The ginger at Wayo takes me back to a Sushi dive in Tokyo I visited several times that was bricked into a train overpass.  I wish I could remember the name (somewhere near the Imperial hotel) but I do remember the beginning of my appreciation for Japanese culture and sushi. 

Back to last night, I had:
Small sake,
Spicy Salmon skin roll,
Mango/salmon roll,
Sake (salmon),
Unagi,
Green tea ice cream.
-------------------------------
Total (before tip) $24.95

Based on yelp suggestions I went very early in the evening (6:30 pm, just after opening)  and sat in front of the chef. He worked through my order as soon as he had it and placed the unagi directly on my plate as soon as I finished the sake (salmon). The best strategy for Wayo is come at an off time and order 1 or more appetizers and a beverage as you wait for your sushi platter.

Sake (salmon sushi) is my signature sushi which I use to gauge a sushi bar and this one was actually 4 star. The ginger, excellent price and overall Japanese ambiance pushed me over to 5 stars.
author: carson s.

description:
I'll be honest. I've been eating here for years, and never wrote a review about it.

Why? Cuz I dont want to "blow up the spot" and have everyone under the sun mobbing my favorite Sushi Spot.....

But I gotta come clean. I LOVE IT. The reviews say it all. The fish is impeccable. The staff is awesome, and it's a 2 person show. The ass kicking chef and his faithful waitress aide. These two are the Japanese Batman and Wonder Woman.

Depending on how busy it is, you may have to wait for your food. I go into it with that it mind, and relax with a cold Kirin while I wait. No Worries.

Word is, this place is one of the few sushi resturants owned and operated by ACTUAL JAPANESE PEOPLE, so a Gaijin like me RESPECTS THAT LIKE THE DAY IS LONG BROTHER.

The Brown Rice Sushi is unique and great too!!!!!!!
author: Kevin G.

description:
This place serves extremely fresh sushi at decent prices. Everything is perfect about this place except for ONE thing: The food takes forever to come out. 

It's like its 1965 and you're waiting for the Vietnam War to end. Its like you went to go watch Avatar and by the time you realize you screwed up there's still 2 1/2 hours to go. Its like you just watched an episode of LOST and there was some ridiculous cliffhanger and now you have to wait a whole week to find out what happens.

If you don't mind waiting, this place is awesome. You might want to bring some granola bars though just in case.
author: Richard S.

description: Amazing.  I love the fact that I stumbled into this place while traveling in San Francisco.  The 45-minute wait was completely worth it.  Super fresh; super yummy; super cheap.
author: Yolanda S.

description:
First off, what most people don't know is that Wayo would be a "typical" little neighborhood restaurant in Japan; i.e. it is quite common in Japan to have tiny private restaurants tucked away around the corner or a street or two away from the shopping streets or train stations.  These are commonly small, intimate, and run by 2 people most of the time, usually a husband and wife team.

Please understand that.  I can't stress that enough.

If you want a rowdy party, or are out with your college buddies ready to party but start off with sushi dinner first, please please please don't come here and ruin it for everyone else.  Take it to Sushi Rock on Polk nearby.  I beg of you.

I've been here a few times, and the last time I went there was a party of 20-somethings being loud and drinking, while the rest of the restaurant was filled with couples or pairs of friends.  NOTE I SAID COUPLES OR PAIRS i.e. TWO (2) PEOPLE.

I was appalled to see one of that loud annoying group complain that the service was slow.... ARE YOU BLIND!?  THERE WAS ONE WAITRESS AND ONE CHEF.  I even think I overheard her say "we aren't going to tip if it's coming any later".  I'm not sure, but I heard something like that.

I immediately noted how rude they were to the poor chef and waitress (in Japanese of course).  I don't know how the other customers could stand it.

*******************************
ahem,
Morality tale aside, bottom line is don't bring more than 3 people here at a time, and don't be an ass about the wait time when you can SEE there is ONE chef.

On a lighter note, with the nice lighting and jazz music playing this is nice for a date, or intimate dinner with your loved one, or to go catch up with a close friend.

Prices are good, the sushi is good... sorry for being so scant on the real reason for this place, the food, but I just can't stand this little place being ruined by people who don't understand and think this is any other sushi place....
author: Kitty O.

description: Great REAL sushi place. No silly rolls with cream cheese and special sauces, but true sushi. One authintic sushi chef tells you how long the wait is going to be when you sit down. That's when the best part begins. Converse with your dinner partner in this quite place while enjoying a nice beer or sake. The fish is some of the freshest I've had. Cannot recommend enough.
author: Chipper N.

description: I ate here in April 2011 for my birthday trip to SF. Easily the best sushi I've ever had, but then again I'm used to all-you-can-eat NV sushi. So I'm pretty sure the freshness factor made it all for me.  Love the fact that they have one guy making the sushi, may have to wait a little bit, but totally worth it.  The guy definitely knows what he's doing, and puts out a quality product. Can't wait to come back and try it again someday.
author: Andrew F.

description:
NO WAYO! How can I have lived so close to this spot for so many years (okay 3, but that's light years to me) and never discovered it?? I do try to stay away from Van Ness when possible, but it's better late than never. 

Wayo has extremely fresh fish, offers the option of brown rice with your rolls (which is delicious) and is reasonably priced. 

Ding! Ding! Ding! Wayo Sushi has another die-hard regular.
author: Defne A.

description: We came here during a weekday. I have never been here before so I don't know how it usually is, but when we first entered the waitress told us it would be 45 minutes before the sushi chef could get to our order. We had our hearts set on this place so we decided to stay. There were several empty tables so we figured that there usually is 2 sushi chefs, and tonight there was only one. The poor waitress was the only other person there to help with orders, and it seemed as if she was also doing dishes in the back. Either way it took 20 minutes to be able to order our beers and appetizers. It did take around 45 minutes for him to get to our order, but we were prepared for that. The rolls were great, the tiny atmosphere was quaint. I have nothing bad to say about it other than the fact that they seemed to be a bit understaffed the night we went in. They also have super reasonable prices, cheaper than most sushi places I've been to.
author: Annette D.

description:
Nice find, Jeremy S. and Michael S.!

All I can say is whoaaaaaaa wasabi! Loved the mango rolls + everything else. The owner/sushi chef was so gracious and flexible with our influx of people that resulted in us taking over his entire restaurant. Location is pretty wonky but with all the raving Yelpers, I'm sure he has no problem bringing people in.
author: Susan L.

description:
You Yelpers are going to hate to see this, but yes...we tourists invaded your neighborhood sushi spot. Remember, though, you reviewed it, so it's all your fault!

Anyway, my boyfriend and I were delighted to see such a highly rated sushi place within walking distance of our hotel, so we hoofed it over on a Wednesday night and were shocked to find the place empty at 630pm. We were also shocked to hear "Let It Snow" playing on the stereo in July, but we won't go there. 

The food was fantastic. No, it doesn't have a huge selection but everything was fresh. We loved the laid back atmosphere, and we also loved that the waitress gave us huge glasses of wine whenever we ordered one. See, in Utah the glasses we got would easily count as two drinks. 

If I ever make it back to SF, I'm heading straight to Wayo.
author: Monica T.

description:
Got my sushi on at Wayo last night and was made into an instant fan!

A buddy of mine has been wanting to go for awhile, and I had been running by it for months on my way back from the gym, so it was about time we made the visit.

Don't let the size of the place deceive you. Wayo packs a serious sushi punch.

You can tell instantly from the menu that this isn't a place where funky rolls are the highlights. Wayo is about the fish and the genuine art of traditional nigiri which focuses on the fish. Definitely a breath of fresh air and a reminder of why Sushi Rock is simply trash. 

I ordered multiple nigiri pieces, and a few specialty rolls. While it does take a bit to get your order ( about 20 minutes with the place being a little less than half full) it was worth the wait.

The sake and maguro pieces just melted in your mouth. Soft, buttery, and the dash of wasabi under the sushi hood made the pieces fly off the plate. Incredible.

The service was great, and while it's only 1 person, she does a fantastic job of staying on top of everyone's orders and wishes.

Will come back often and I have to say, I was a little hesitant to write this review because I'd like to keep it somewhat of a sushi secret. However, I have to give back to the Yelp community, because I for sure read your reviews on Wayo!
author: Mike K.

description: Came here for a little sustenance after a Funky Door class and was told upon arrival by the waitress that any sushi orders would take half an hour!  Disheartened but hungry, we decided to stay and just nosh on appetizers.  I got a seaweed salad and split 1) a small bowl of edamame and 2) a small tofu dish w/ bonito flakes & scallions.  This managed to fill me up and while I lusted after sushi, I didn't really need it.  The waitress was very fast and helpful.  I felt the prices were very reasonable.  I'd like to return another time and actually get some sushi...
author: Suzanne V.

description:
Went here with my brother on my first visit to San Fran and ended up having a great dinner on a quiet Sunday night. The atmosphere isn't by any means the best point, as it was sparsely decorated and rather plain. There aren't many tables at all and the sushi bar isn't all that big so I expect this place to have big waits on busy nights. 

With that said, the food was really tasty and quite filling for roughly twenty bucks a head. We tried the Dragon roll, the rainbow roll, and the salmon sashimi and then added a salmon roll at the end. The pieces of salmon sashimi were cut big and very fresh and the eel was delicious on the Dragon roll. Out waitress paid just the right amount of attention to us, and, even though we arrived somewhat late, wasn't in a rush to get us out at all. 

It'd probably be a good date place because its not really that loud and pretty casual; unless of course you're looking for a loud place so you don't have to listen to your date mindlessly tell you about themselves ;).
author: Danny K.

description:
Seriously.  The best "no frills" sushi I've had in the Bay Area.  

You walk in, and immediately you notice a couple of things.  

1) Small place, 3-4 tables + sushi bar
2) 1 Sushi Cheff
3) 1 Waitress

Just FYI, If you're not the 1st one in the door, the waitress will usually pre-empt your meal by saying, "It will be a 40-45 minute wait for your food, is that ok?"  It really does take about that long, but the sushi is no joke.  The chef is a real nice guy, and he's been there for 20 years, so you know this place is the real deal.  

The best thing about this place is the quality of the fish.  Usually I order a bunch of nigiris, a couple of rolls and I'm usually stuffed by the end of the night.  I love the tuna, salmon, yellow tail, makerel, unagi, albacore, their makis.  Try the snow leopard roll for something different and they also have mango and cream cheese rolls.   However, I stick with the basics.  

Also, the place is cheap.  It's about $4 per roll/nigiri, so you can really order about 10 different things and stuff yourself for the night for $40 for 2.  Anywhere else you're paying $60-70 for less quality fish but more "frills".  

5 STARS!
author: Davidson T.

description:
Wayo is good.  Quite good.  And they are cheap!  Quite cheap.  And the rice, if you like, is brown. Quite...brown.

These are the things you really need to know about Wayo, the rest is just window dressing.  But here you go anyway: this is no-frills neighborhood sushi joint that doesn't offer much in the way of atmosphere, but they make up for it in value. You're not going to get the Cherry Blossom Double Decker Firecracker roll here, but they've got all the nigiri and maki basics covered.  Their one foray into the exotic is a series of mango rolls they have on special (and have had on special for many months now).  All of these rolls will run you $3-$5.  Not bad at all.  And as mentioned, you can have any of your rolls with brown rice which may be sushi sacrilege but hey, it's a good way to healthy your dinner up a bit and they taste just fine. 

Every time I've been there the staff has topped out at 2 people: a chef and a waitress.  So, if when you walk in there are a lot of people, you may end up waiting a while.  

So while this place won't blow you away with creativity, it's tasty, inexpensive and a great go-to Tuesday night sushi spot.
author: Eric S.

description: Small little place with great sushi.  From the outside it doesn't look tempting and inside decor doesn't either but this place works.  Myself and my wife sat at the bar which could hold about 10 people and then there are about 10 other seats so it's not for big crowds.  The food is really fresh as it's hand made on the spot so it's fast.   Sitting at the bar is fun as you can watch the chef work his magic at lightening speed and order as you want it.  Everything I had I enjoyed.  The list is not huge which is plus for me anyway.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Great secret on Van Ness next to bomb scared Starbucks by Bush St. Looks like a one man sushi chef place that knows how to keep it low key. BUT ask what HE recommends. Sometimes his wife is in here helping out too. This is not a place for stuff like Californicated Rolled threebees or Tarantula Spider bites or Philadelphia Creamed double fried cheese steak rolls.

(Please NO crackers in the crack o yo donkey bridge or tunnel blondie airheads please!!! They are sooo LALA land...i will give them karate  chop for you Wayo Sensei...they are just NOT schooled...kinda like blonde trailertrashinghookahz. Completely appaling behavior and drunkeness with horrible attitudes...)
author: miriam b.

description:
What a great find!

I was pleasantly surprised at how fresh the sushi was. You can't beat the price too! No five star because the place is very small and we often have to wait to be seated.
author: Yelp T.

description:
When I'm not eating fried chicken/sweet potato pie (from Powell's) or omelettes and fried potatoes (from Grubstake), or sampling desserts at Stella's after working out, I'm here eating sushi.  We're talking copious amounts here, such that the amount of mercury buildup in my system outweighs my meal's nutritional benefits, and I may as well be eating at Powell's, Grubstake, or Stella's.

Again, this is one of the few Japanese-owned sushi restaurants in the city.  The menu is simple.  You can order sashimi, or nigiri sushi, or have the fish in a roll.  They have a special that I always order - spicy salmon or spicy tuna, with mango.  They don't have too many crazy rolls here, so don't go in expecting that.

Best of all, it's dirt cheap.  The specials that I mentioned above are $5 / order.  So, it's really easy to load up on sushi here.

PS - Their spicy tuna roll does not have mayonnaise in it.  :)
author: Dwigt S.

description: I have eaten here a handful of times and each time it was ok. Its the perfect place to swing by for a quick meal, on your own or if you are in a hurry on the way to a movie just down the street at AMC.  Everything tasted ok, the service is friendly, the prices are reasonable, even on the low side, the food tastes fine. I cannot rave about it, nor can I slam it for anything.  Small menu, small quiet place. A-Ok.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Wow!
I was not expecting the freshness of the sashimi for a place as cheap as this was.  For two people, we got five rolls and two sashimi plates and we paid 60 dollars after tax and tip.

The hamachi is freakin delicious.
author: Andrew K.

description: By far one of the best Sushi places in Pac Heights. It is small and quaint so you expect a little bit of a wait, but it is well worth it! My boyfriend and I have been coming here for date nights since we've been living in the city. The same man and women are always working and they are super cute and nice. To top it all off it is fresh, delicious sushi. Can't go wrong!
author: Kristi E.

description:
Cons:
Long wait
Overpriced
Average sushi

Pros:
Courteous service
Cozy place
Wasabi in sushi
author: Melv L.

description: Found this place on yelp one night and I've been a fan ever since. While they don't have toro or soft shell crab, everything else is as fresh as it gets. The freshest fish I've ever had!
author: Hansen L.

description: If you are looking for a small, authentic, cheap awesome sushi place this is it. I have been 10-15 times and live up the street. Wife is waiter, husband is the only sushi chef/cook. Just an awesome place.
author: Ryan P.

description:
Forgive me Wayo, for thinking I the CUSTOMER, had the right to choose whether  I wanted wasabi with my sushi, clearly I was mistaken.
          Instantly after eating my first bite, I felt a painful burning sensation surge up my nasal cavity, and travel with lightning speed, into every single one of my brain cells. Upon inspecting my rolls, I discovered the chef had tainted both my salmon and spicy tuna rolls with clumps of wasabi. Needless to say I'm not a fan of the green goop, so my entire meal was ruined. *Sigh* If I hadn't drained all my energy at the gym, I would've totally demanded that my rolls be remade, or at the very least popped my dine n dash cherry and bailed. Instead, I grudgingly paid my tab and walked out disappointed.
         With a limited menu, skewed pricing, inadequate service, and a sushi chef that cant take an extra minute to ask customer's preference on wasabi, I'd say skip this place.
author: Gabriella C.

description:
I'm a huge sushi snob, so when my friend raved that Wayo is the best sushi in the city I had to try it.

The restaurant is a tiny spot on Van Ness one could easily overlook. Wayo has only a few tables and one sushi chef, so get there early if you want to get a seat. The place was packed by the time we left.

I ordered hamachi sashimi, unagi nigiri, a spicy tuna roll and a shrimp mango roll. It took a little while but that is fine by me- the fresher the better! Our sushi was plated beautifully and was so incredibly fresh! The hamachi melted in my mouth and the rolls weren't overpowered by rice. The prices were amazing too which was a relief- sushi in the city can be so overpriced.

I was with one of my friends who has never really had sushi (evidenced by her dumping the entire blob of wasabi into her soy sauce thinking it would be fine- it was really funny watching her face turn bright red). She loved her choices as well.

This place doesn't have the crazy, elaborate rolls you'll see in some restaurants, but I think that simple is better. If the fish is fresh, it shouldn't need a ton of other ingredients to mask the flavor. Here, the fish is the star. 

Wayo rocks. I can't wait to return.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I really enjoyed Wayo Sushi. I went with a couple of friends on a Friday night and were immediately seated at the bar. Service was pleasant, polite, and attentive. The food came a bit slowly but we weren't complaining, as we could plainly see that the one chef was working as fast as he possibly could've.

The sushi was really tasty! Not the most amazing I've had but it was definitely better than most. I liked the brown rice; interestingly I barely noticed it in the maki (and usually I'm pretty anti-brown-rice). We ordered the mango-spicy-tuna roll and it was awesome--SO SO SO spicy. I liked that the tuna was chopped up and had spices added at the last minute, unlike the tuna mush you often get when you order spicy tuna at less expensive restaurants (HATE the tuna mush, I mean really, what's the point?). My vegan friend really enjoyed her sushi as well, especially the shiitake mushroom maki. As for the non-sushi items: seaweed salad was perfect. Edamame was warm and sooooo salty (mmm). I don't remember how the miso soup was, which probably means it was fairly good.

On a sushi scale of 1-10 I rate this sushi about an 8.
author: Heather H.

description:
It was good.  Try the brown rice.

Ok Fayza I've written a review.  Can I be elite now?
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Sushi restaurants proliferate San Francisco like foggy mornings and people heckling passersby to register to vote.  But, unlike the other little sushi places around the Tendernob / Nob Hill area, this place is almost (ALMOST) forgotten on the busy street of Van Ness, which is actually a really good thing.

Forget Sushi Rock and Nara Sushi, I would definitely recommend Wayo.  On a Friday night, a small group of us decided to give this place a try. It's nothing fancy, but the service is nice and the sushi was good.  There isn't any special dry-ice or frilly decor on your plate, but who cares?  It's cheap, the salmon cream cheese rolls, unagi, and any other basic Japanese sushi/sashimi are delish-i-ous, and you won't be fighting people or waiting around to be seated.  

And, even if you're one of the only patrons, you won't feel rushed or hurried along your way.  The only complaint?  The place closes down fairly early, even on the weekends.
author: Shay F.

description:
Great little place! My friend brought me here since she lives about 2 blocks away. 

The menu is pretty concise, which is perfectly fine with me. It can be quite exhausting at some other places to have to go through an extensive list of bob's roll, mary's roll, joe's roll, shaniqua's roll...only to see that the difference lies in the garnish. Concise menu also means that the chef's gotta be specialized...resulting in quick and delicious sushi! yum yum!~

Nothing's really out of the ordinary here. You get what you expect and there's no crazy surprise fusion secret sauce or over-the-top presentation. We had ordered a few rolls but what really stood out was the Sea Fairy Roll...which is fresh scallop on a california roll(?). I love, love, love fresh scallop. Oh, it was so tasty! it's hard enough to find a place that even offers scallops, alone having to find it fresh. Wayo earned my 5th star there.

I would definitely come back here again. Like everyone else has mentioned, sushi can be simple. At Wayo, there's fresh fish (& scallops), a seasoned chef and great service...all at a reasonable price. Can't ask for much more.
author: Jeremy F.

description:
Not the best sushi I've had, but considering I've walked out of that place absolutely stuffed for under 20 bucks, I've no right to complain.  The sushi is good, very good actually.  Decent enough fish as far as freshness goes, and very flavorful (which is more than I can say about Okoze on Hyde and Union).

What I particularly like about Wayo is the atmosphere.  I've only gone on weekdays and have only encountered - at the most - one other party at a time.  It's very quiet and relaxing.  No loud techno (Sushi Rock), but Jazz.  I'm sure they're a little more busy on the weekends.

The sashimi was good but not great, and I recommend the mango rolls (I could smell the mango from the other side of the bar when he pulled it out).  Wayo is my new weekly restaurant.
author: Eric M.

description:
Nice little place, very authentic, very simple, quite cheap. We had to wait 45 minutes for food on a Sunday evening (6pm) though -- the place was nowhere near full, but it's just the one chef and the one waitress. 

The brown rice sushi was pretty tasty, worth a try. The thing is.. it was good and I appreciate the simplicity about the place, but Sushi Time is still worlds better.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Awesome sushi restaurant. I called ahead, based on the reviews on Yelp, and they didn't accept reservations. Was expecting it to be crowded, but on a Saturday night at 8pm, it was just a handful of patrons.

Like other reviews have mentioned, the place is relatively small and homely. The service was good, the one and only waitress, and she took our order and didn't bother us. The sashimi was amazing, we chose the yellowtail, and it was so buttery-melt-in-your-mouth.

The sushi was also good, I think we go the dragon roll, some other roll, and some of the ebi prawn nigiri. Ordered a large sake and a large Sapporo, and walked out for around $50 for two. That's pretty damn awesome for sushi that's not from Cala-Foods.

We did have a homeless guy bang on the window. The chef had a few words with him. Would have been a little sweeter if he had taken his big knife with him out for the chat. Cool place, I hope to be back.
author: Joseph T.

description:
This is a sad review. I was very excited to try this place having read such great reviews. 
Very small restaurant, seating prob only 20-25 people. Husband and wife team, VERY hospitable, friendly. 
Yes, if it is crowded, you are going to wait. We went and there was only 5 other people. But service was still slow. 
I got a Miso soup, Seaweed Salad, Salmon Shashimi, and Tuna Maki. The Miso was good, except it was missing the Seaweed, the seaweed salad was slimy, the Salmon was great, and the Tuna Maki was good, but preloaded with a bit too much Wasabi. 
I wish I could 5 stars, but honestly I have had better sushi in PA. (Scary thought) 
But dont let me sway you, they are still good, and the owners are very friendly. 
At least give them a try if you are in the neighborhood. 
Oh, and they are CHEAP! $2 for miso, $4.50 for Tuna maki, $9 for 6 Salmon Slices. 
I would go back, if I lived here. :)
author: Jen S.

description: The sushi was definitely fresh and tasty!  I got a seaweed salad along with an order of shrimp, tuna, and scallop nigiri - all delish!  My friend got a couple rolls which were tasty too.  It's a small restaurant but felt warm and inviting.  The service was prompt and friendly too.  All in all, a great restaurant!
author: Chich S.

description: One of the best sushi restaurants in SF.  Small but charming interior and great service.  However, as there are only 2 staff members, I wouldn't advice going there hungry as it takes about 30 min to get your food.  But the wait is absolutely worth it!
author: S. I.

description: Awesome sushi.  Highly recommend and ask the sushi chef anything about sushi and he'll tell.  Incredible quality.
author: Ben E.

description: Love the atmosphere AMD the personal attention to detail with the fresh ingredients assembled right in front of you. So clean!
author: Z K.

description:
Bonus points to this place to being within walking distance.

Like others have said, you won't find this place featured in too many interior design award shows.  It's pretty humble inside, but not dirty or sloppy.

The food here is pretty good.  I had a couple different kinds of sushi.  I'm not Mr. Sushi, but I do like it every now and then.  The meat was tasty and tender, and presented well on the dish.  The prices are pretty reasonable too, and service was friendly.

I'd go here again.
author: Charles R.

description:
If brown rice gets you fired up, you'll have something to like about Wayo Sushi. It's funny how they advertise it in all these little places: on the door, with a sign on the wall, on the menu, and they'll remind you when you order it:

"...And can I have a bowl of rice with that, please?"
"The rice is brown!"
"Oh... okay, a bowl of brown rice, please."
"Excellent!"
"Thanks!"

I like the interior; it's Japanese but with elements of an all-nite diner thrown in. The bar, for instance, has cool chrome-lined stools actually anchored to the floor. And the place is tiny--I mean, cozy--and plays some awesome jazz in the background.

So far the food has been good. Wayo's definitely an overlooked contender in the sushi dept., so give it a try!
author: Patrick G.

description:
Wayo makes me happy. It isn't often that I say that about a restaurant but the atmosphere was peaceful, the tea was piping hot and frequently refilled, and the fish was fresh. In fact, it was fresh enough that I ordered some niigiri for myself even though I am technically supposed to stay away from raw fish and meat for the time being. We ordered mostly niigiri but the rolls we had were really good as well. I suppose that makes sense considering this is one of the few sushi places I have been to that are actually run by Japanese people.

Just sitting at the sushi bar letting the warmth from from my cup of tea seep though my hands and looking at the Ukiyo-e print was very nice. Knowing that I would soon be receiving some artfully prepared niigiri was even better.
author: Caroline B.

description:
As sushi bars go, this one has good fish and is decently priced.  I generally find myself waiting a little longer than I'd like for the sushi to come out.  

Overall, very chill small place, and generally pretty quiet.
author: Hilary K.

description:
Well, I waited until my 4th visit to give my yelp review because I didn't want to give 5 stars to Wayo without being sure it was a 5 star place. Dinner tonight was awesome. Besides the fish being delicious as usual and prices being very reasonable, the rice was perfect for our nigiris (which we mostly ate). Perfectly warm and soft, very slightly sweet, but not too sweet. Even the tea was steaming hot and delicious. Both the rolls we ordered were $5 (mango spicy hamachi and the house roll, eel and spinach), so with some sashimi and a variety of nigiris (5 in total) our bill came to $42. We were stuffed and satisfied. 

Oh, if you're looking for a scene, this isn't the place. Just great food at a great price.

I'll be walking back soon!
author: Chris L.

description:
I might consider selling my soul for the spicy scallop nigiri. That is how good the spicy scallop nigiri is at Wayo. I never understood the hype of raw scallop and when I had spicy scallop elsewhere, the intense flavor always made me feel like the chefs were trying to cover up the quality of the scallop. Only at Wayo, did I understand the meaning of delicious scallop. The sushi chef combines the perfect balance so that you taste the delectable texture of the scallop with a hint of spicy sauce and green onion. 

The place is intimate with jazz playing in the background and it was amazing to find a Japanese sushi chef serving sushi. That is so rare these days since most places are owned by the Chinese or Korean. So good that my fat ass is here every week to stuff myself full of spicy scallop and when I do not have time to eat in person, I will order to go. Ichiban!
author: Sophie C.

description:
I always sing "Walk Like an Egyptian" to myself when I'm trekking up the hill to get to Wayo.  "Wayo Wayyyo Oooohh Wayo Wayo..."  You get the gist.

The fact that I'm willing to leave my safe and cozy Mission bubble to go to Wayo, pretty much any time I have an excuse to, should tell you everything you need to know about the place.  This is the best sushi I've had in the city, hands down.  

Everything is super fresh and healthy--I especially love the brown rice substitutions they allow.  Make sure to try one of the special mango rolls, they are nom-arific.
author: Kevin H.

description: We ordered Tuna and Salmon Sashimi, Salmon Roe Nigiri, Hamachi Nigiri, etc. Overall, the fish is fairly fresh. Nothing impressive. Small restaurant. Cozy atmosphere.
author: Kate J.

description:
What a shame!!!
This restaurant is wonderfull, it's now my "cantine", I could eat only there, the sushis are so good.
When I went there the first time, there was nobody...but now it's crowded and we have to wait to be served.
But congratulations M. Ogawa!
author: Ana R.

description:
Big, beautiful slabs of sashimi.  

It's what stuck in my mind as I left.

The place is tiny, has one chef and one waitress.  The rolls were nice but the wait was long (there's just one chef-Defne A. who introduced me here said to come before 6:30 to avoid a long wait).  

But those big beautiful slabs of pomegranate red maguro.  Oh my.
author: Mike U.

description: Good for lunch, not crowded but we got there right when it opened. The salmon sashimi was at freshest I'd ever had and the prices were reasonable. The rolls were okay, very simple, no fuss so if you like elaborate things than this is not the place for you. I used to live in NYC and have had lots of sushi, so I feel im pretty dead on.
author: Katie H.

description:
Ach, the secret's out! 

Wayo, which looks like a total hole in the wall on Van Ness of all places, actually has really, really good sushi.

IMO, sushi is a basic staple--like burritos, pho, pasta or brunch. It's hard to pinpoint what makes some sushi better than others when it's all pretty straightforward-- rice, seaweed, fish, maybe one or four other ingredients. But whenver I get a sushi craving and I try a place, I either leave satisfied and not needing any sushi for a couple weeks, or I find that I still crave it... Wayo definitely satisfies the craving!

No crazy rolls with 12 ingredients, mind you, but simple rolls with fresh, tasty ingredients all in the right proportions, and excellent nigiri. And yes, as far as I can tell the chef is Japanese, or at least not Mexican and not speaking in Korean, which makes him pretty special in this town. That, along with his amazing sushi.
author: Amy D.

description:
Small little place - one sushi chef, one waitress. 
A few tables and a sushi bar. 

I came in on a Sunday and it was pretty empty so I guess I lucked out bc if it were full I could imagine the wait would be pretty long considering there's that one chef sweating it out by himself. But since it was fairly empty we got our food pretty quickly - we ordered quite a few of the rolls and some sushi. The Sea Fairy is my favorite - real big pieces of crab, no mayo, avocado and cucumber with scallops on top. Everything was light, clean, fresh flavors. I also dug the mango yellowtail roll - I've never had mango in my sushi before and it was a yummy combination. 

Parking was pretty easy too - there was plenty of street parking around the area and it was easy to find. Definitely come by and give this place a try - just avoid the busier hours bc from what I see in some of the other reviews the wait can be pretty long.
author: Anita W.

description: I am typically skeptical of fish in general, but I love sushi so I decided to check this place out. It was delicious. Honestly, the quality of fish is great and it's one of the least expensive sushi dinners I have ever had. Of course, since you're paying around $5/roll, you don't get tons of fish but you can order more of a variety and still pay less than what you would elsewhere. The only downside is there is one chef and one waitress so you must have a decent amount of time to spend at dinner. The restaurant only has 3 tables so you might end up sitting at the counter if none of those are open. Overall, a great meal, awesome sashimi and great rolls. I will definitely be making this my go-to sushi spot!
author: Tenley B.

description: I wanted to get some sushi before an event, and Wayo was on the well...way(o) to the venue. The Philadelphia roll was amongst the best I've had, and the Dynamite roll with tart Ponzu was excellent. Even the miso soup and sunomono were fantastic! Every thing at Wayo was incredibly fresh, and the staff was accomodating + friendly. I look forward to coming here again, and trying the mango rolls. Make sure to check out the specials before you order!
author: Neha T.

description:
Wayo is the closest thing you'll come to a no-frills, sushi-only type of restaurant. This place is really, really small. The menu isn't very  big either, which gives this place a nice touch of simplicity. They have some interesting signature rolls, such as ones with mango, but I stuck to the traditional ones. The hamachi and maguro were pretty impressive. Everything tasted really fresh.

For the price, you really get your bang for the buck here. A lot of the items on the menu range from $3-$5. I think I just spent over $10 on a meal here. You don't have to spend a lot of money to get good sushi!
author: Kristen R.

description: In SF on business. Ate at Saduchi down the street, which was good. Read good reviews on Wayo, decided to give it a try. The restaurant was empty and was pretty dingy. I immediately noticed the glass of water seemed dirty. I place my order and the chef goes and gets fish out of the fridge. But instead of slicing it in front of me, he pulls my presliced fish out of a bin and places my nigiri and sashimi on a plate. Who knows how long it had been sitting there! It wasn't even sliced properly. One of the worst sushi experiences I've ever had.
author: Tek N.

description: Delish!! Great, friendly service, awesome mango roll !
author: Erin M.

description:
I'm not a hard core sushi girl. I like rolls. I'm kind of a wimp that way, but I've come to accept it. 

I really want to like this place but I was just under whelmed. It's very reasonably priced: good. The staff is very friendly: good. Real crab in the California Rolls: good. Brown rice option: good. Miso soup and seaweed salad: good. But the actual sushi was mediocre at best. The rolls were so loose that we gave up using chopsticks because they were all falling apart even before we tried to pick them up; we just went with our hands. Spicy tuna wasn't spicy and the seared yellow tail was overdone and dry. 

It's not terrible but I wouldn't go back, especially when Kyoto Sushi is just a few doors down.
author: Gina L.

description:
I have gone here many many times over the years and love it.  To confirm my thoughts have brought Japanese friends on many occations and they all have raved about it.
