I usually go for the combo sushi plate special which includes 7 pieces of sushi, 1 roll, salad and miso soup for $14.50. Seems like last just year the same plate was $11.50 so prices have climbed.

Last Friday I had to ask for hot tea (free green tea), they used to bring it without asking. I noticed that the waitress did not bring anyone tea without them asking. Service was a little slow, one waiter and the owner....but it is a small place. 

Wish I was around Van Ness Ave more often to drop in, relax and enjoy a casual but GREAT sushi meal.
author: Bill B.

description:
If you find that decor affects how much you enjoy your meal, then Wayo Sushi is not for you.  It is sparsely decorated and very simple.  You're not paying for fancy china or mood-enhancing lighting.  Which is possibly why it's so inexpensive for the freshness and quality of the sushi.   We arrived just as they opened and sat at the bar.  Having walked from the Ferry building to Japantown and back towards our hotel, we were hungry and in need of an unhurried, leisurely meal.  Good thing we knew about Wayo Sushi!  The service was just enough, and the maki was tasty and filling.  We will definitely come again the next time we're in SF!
The california roll with scallop and the seared tuna maki were highlights.
author: Anjali B.

description: I f-ing love this place. The decor on the inside is minimalist, without a hint of cheese (cough, like other sushi bars, cough). The food was simple, delicious, and extremely well executed. Above all, the owners are extremely polite and friendly. What a gem. . .
author: M G.

description:
First of all, if you like really good, fresh sushi and sashimi with extremely good price, Wayo Sushi is the place to go to. 

Be careful though, 
do not come on weekend nights, 
because this place is run only by a japanese couple. 
the husband makes EVERY order from scratch while the wife serves the customers. 

But it is very good sushi though!
they even have uni! and for an extremely good price! $5 for 2. 
the rest of the sushi choices are always fresh too. 

The place is kind of small,
but that's why I like it =)
Definitely one of the best local sushi restaurants!
author: Miss C.

description: The rolls here SUCK!  If yo u like rolls don't come here.  You will be disappointed.  The rice around the rolls was dry so it didn't stay in roll form.  It looked like an beginner attempt at a roll.  The sashimi, however, is pretty fresh and fairly price.  I felt like I was eating a a funeral cuz the place was really quiet.  This place would be good for people that live near this place.  Otherwise don't waste your time.
author: Fatty A.

description: If you like great miso soup, perfect sea weed salad and sushi that is as perfect as it gets and don't mind waiting 30 to 45 mins for it then this is hands down the best sushi place in town.
author: Kaushick N.

description: This little restaurant was a gem of a fine for me.  Had to find a little food before my event  in the neighborhood and this was perfect.  Food was fresh and service was great.  I totally intend to go back and try the other menu items.
author: John L.

description:
MMMMMM......Wayo!!

Wayo Sushi has truly yummy food at reasonable prices...and this place is run by the hardest working man in show business.  Have you ever walked by Wayo during business hours and NOT seen chef Mamoru in there busting his hump??  His floors are so clean, you can eat off of them!  I think this is one of SF's true gem of local eateries.

...and Wayo is a prime example of why we should continue to eat out during these economic hard times...to support the local businesses that deserve our hard earned wages.  One person commented on Wayo's "amateur" sushi.  Are you kidding me??  Mamoru spent many years in Japan as a finely trained sushi chef, just ask him about it.  The quite man is really quite friendly and talkative when he's not too busy creating the customer's orders.  He serves food we love...in San Francisco.  It is both authentic and delicious.  If you want more authentic, go to Japan.
author: Cricket B.

description:
Traveling in the city, and looking for cheap, good sushi, we were put onto this place through Yelp; we were not disappointed.

The small, casual setting is fantastic, if not ideal for groups over four. But bring a date and you can sit at the bar and watch the sushi chef at work. He's extremely precise, and his kitchen is spotless and totally organised. We noticed that he got 100% on his cleanliness certificate. Cafe Jules only managed 92%, and they looked spotless too.

Fish was great, the saba (mackerel) was especially good, very fresh with just the right amount of oily roundness to the finish. Brown rice rolls were also excellet, the rice was just dry enough, without being too chewy. And to top it all off the price was well within our budget -- though we did overspend, but only because I kept ordering more saba. I have had better unagi at other places, but that's a minor quibble and I would recommend this restaurant to anyone.
author: Robin E.

description: Not certain what all the hype is about. The rolls were good, but just way too big and uber too much rice. I ended up eating the little pieces of fish in the middle and leaving the "roll" part, because that's what most of it was. The tea was good, and the edimame didn't taste like it came from a microwave, so that was good too. Price was reasonable, but I wouldn't seek this place out...
author: Danielle L.

description: The fish was fresh but there was so much wasabi in my nigiri I though I was gonna die! I had to pick out out of the rice first. Also I get why there is a wait but it took so so long, 45min-1hr after ordering.
author: Steph D.

description:
Okay - add to my favorites - this is top of my list for sushi spots in the city.

What I love about this place:
-Delicious fresh sushi
-Melt in your mouth sashimi
-Tasty rolls - you can even opt for brown rice
-Good portions
-Great service
-Friendly Chef
-Small and cozy atmosphere
author: Melanie T.

description: Delicious. Fresh. Unique. I'm new to the area but so far this is one of the best sushi restaurants I've been to.
author: Chris R.

description: The wait sometimes can be long but worth it. The sushi is fresh. I personally like to keep it simple and get the sashimi. It's my go-to spot!
author: Oscar F.

description:
If you like good, fresh, and delicious sushi served in a nice little restaurant with no frills, this is your spot.  I am going to make this one quick.  The menu is not overwhelming which is good because the owner is making the food.  He is quick, so if its busy, be ready to wait a little bit, but you get everything at once, they don't stagger the delivery of the food.  Be patient if it is busy, but your patience will pay off when you get your food.  We got 4 rolls, no alcohol this time (I know) and some nigiri.  It was a $45 bill, which really was not bad at all.  We both left stuffed, and very happy with our dinner.  We will go back for sure.  
One note, im a huge wasabi fan, if you aren't, just be careful, the chef isn't shy with making sure you leave with clean sinuses.
author: Mike G.

description:
Very solid!   Thanks Yelpers, I went here solely on the positive reviews posted.   I was not disappointed.  And neither was my friend and his Japanese wife - they were both impressed!  

Very simple presentation, no frills nigiri.   Total "pop-and-daughters" place.  I was not too impressed with the rolls I had but the nigiri more than made up for that.   Everything I had was extremely tasty and fresh.

The best part, the tab for the 3 of us was like 98 bucks before tip!

They only serve two types of beers - small Sapporo and large Sapporo.  And three types of sake - hot, cold and Nigori (unfiltered).

The chef/owner was very nice, apparently he's been at this same location for something like 20 years and lived down in Orange County (Santa Ana) before coming up here.   I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Chris B.

description:
Wayo why do people enjoy mango in their sushi rolls? What about cream cheese?! Since when did we start combining tropical and "Philadephian" foods with japanese?

Non-traditional ingredients aside, Wayo seems to offer up a good balance of nigiri and other traditional dishes like hiyayako (cold tofu with fish flakes) and sunomono (pickled cucumber). I've only been once but was very impressed with the freshness of the fish: sake, hamachi, maguro, saba. Sushi is reasonably priced too - around $3 - $5 for nigiri or maki (simple rolls) which is on par w/ other sushi joints in the city.

Go on a weekday and I can bet on decent parking, short wait and no fuss service. If you are a sushi fan (and eat raw fish...cause I know some 'sushi lovers' don't even eat raw fish!), don't want a fancy schmancy spot or to break the bank...stroll on over to Wayo. Your tummy will thank you.
author: Deann M.

description: You wouldn't think about stopping in here seeing it from the street, but this place is absolutely fantastic! I would say some of the best sushi I've ever had.
author: Nantas S.

description: Good quality fish. Go for some sashimi while you're there. The spicy tuna is actually quite spicy. The scallop nigiri is delicious. Friendly service and reasonable prices.
author: m t.

description: I wish more people knew about this place. Each time I have recommended it, I get a strange response like I'm from another planet. Regardless of what others think, this must be one of the best sushi restaurants in the city. It's a cozy little place with tons of style, and the owner seems very cool.
author: Evelyn B.

description:
I have been to Wayo enough times now to really say: I LOVE THIS PLACE!

It is within perfect proximity to the AMC theater for a quick meal before a movie. The restaurant is small, occupying the space next to the corner Starbucks, with only 4 tables and about 10 bar stools. That being said though, I have never had to wait for a table- even on a Saturday night. The fish is always fresh, and I have fallen in love with the Yellow Tail Sashimi. It seriously melts in your mouth. 

perfectly un-pretentious, comfortable and relaxing.
author: Cindy H.

description: At first I was slightly baffled by this place. We walked in, well more like squeezed in because the place is so tiny, and sat at the bar. We were hanging at the bar for a good while before even being acknowledged by the girl assisting the sushi chef. I would have been fine with waiting, just offer me a flippin drink and I will sip on sake or Sapporo until you CAN take my order. But no, we waited at least 15 minutes at the bar, in front of her eyes, before even being greeted. Sure, I was annoyed but I had great company so we just chatted while waiting for our existence to be acknowledged. When she did  acknowledge us, we ordered some beer and sake and 3 different rolls. The sushi chef was nice and efficient. The fish was fresh and the sushi delicious.  I find that service is an important factor when it comes to running a restaurant thus the three star rating. The place seems to generate enough business to justify hiring another person to maybe not ignore customers for upwards of 15 - 20 minutes. I have been to many great sushi joints that not only provide quality food but also quality service. I would have no reason to go out of my way to come here again.
author: Dana S.

description:
The absolute freshest fish I've tasted in the U.S.  I used to prefer maki rolls but this place turned me on to nigiri, I could eat a whole meal of it here.  They don't skimp on the portions either, each slice is a thick substantial cut of fish.

Everything is relatively cheap--we feasted on 3 beers, 3 special rolls, and 12 orders of nigiri, and it all came out to $85 + tip.  At most other places, the same amount of food would've cost us at least $120.

The wait for our food was indeed long, as other reviewers have pointed out.  We ordered at about 7:45 on a Wednesday when there were only 2 other tables there, but I don't think we got our food until almost 8:30.  Totally worth the wait though.

I would normally give Wayo 4 stars because ambiance isn't spectacular, but when it comes to sushi, quality and taste like this negate all other factors.
author: S L.

description:
A very low-key, chill sushi place that is truly a hidden gem for those who live around the area. It's the perfect place for a chill night, especially if you've had a long day of work and just want something that doesn't require too much maintenance (e.g. getting ready to go eat, dressing up, etc).

We went here on a Saturday night, and the place was about 60% full (capacity may be around 20?) with only two people on the wait staff - the sushi chef and a waitress. The menu is relatively simple - a few appetizers, some specialty rolls and mainly nigiri sushi and sashimi. The prices were extremely reasonable and so we ended up ordering a ton - so much that we could barely finish, and yet the check came out to be $60 for two. 

We've definitely have had better sushi but for 3-4 times the costs, so Wayo is definitely the best in terms of value. Even though we sat at the bar, we didn't really talk to the chef too much since he was busy working, but it was entertaining to watch. Fish was definitely fresh. He has a tendency to put a lil too much wasabi in the rolls but still pretty good.

Worth ordering - the chef's sushi special, hamachi sashimi, unagi sushi, and hiyakko (tofu with bonito flakes). The specialty rolls are definitely worth trying too!
author: buggy b.

description:
This is a great low key sushi bar.
If you are in a rush to be anywhere do not bother. Wayo is meant to be enjoyed slowly. 

With that said, I have never had anything bad here. Everything so far has been yummy and they have brown rice that they will make your sushi with. Very nice.
author: Shawn P.

description:
This place was fine. 
Nothing exceptional. Very rice-heavy sushi. 
It's definitely not a four and a half star sushi restaurant. 
though it was cheap. 

we ordered: 
2 orders albacore nigiri
1 order salmon nigiri
1 order hamachi nigiri
1 spicy tuna and mango roll (not good)
1 snow leopard roll (albacore and avacado with ponzu sauce)
1 dragon roll

the best things were the albacore nigiri and the dragon roll.  everything else just tasted like rice, but smelled like fish.
author: lindsay f.

description:
+1 for real Japanese chefs
+1 for brown rice sushi
+1 for some darn good pickings
author: La A.

description:
The best sushi around our neighborhood and they even have brown rice!
Wayo is our regular go-to place and even though they don't keep inventing new rolls we don't get bored of their selection. 
We also took sushi first-timers here who loved and raved about the food weeks after. 
Sometimes when it's crowded it takes a little while but since we know, we always find the wait worthwhile and have never gotten disappointed.
author: Alexandra D.

description:
I found this place a couple of years ago, walking home from my old job. You would never know it was there unless you were walking on that side of the street, and paying attention, which most of us are not--around 6ish on our way home from work. Anyways, I'm always willing and excited to try new spots--especially sushi dives! 

They are friendly and warm. There are only a few tables, but the sushi bar bends around the whole restaurant. The menu is simple, consistent, but the specials are unique and the fish is fresh. He works right in front of you with his red woven head band. He is willing to change rolls to accommodate your taste/requests; thoughtful, because he remembers your face and what you like. 

Prices are more than reasonable, especially considering our city, and sushi, as the trendy entity it has become. And, the service is more than good--they are always smiling. He told me they have been open for more than 20 yrs, and it is obvious they have an efficient system down, great service is second nature for them.

Modest, friendly, delightful, satiating, unassuming, delicious...all words that come to mind when I think of Wayo. I don't have a complaint yet.
author: Robin H.

description: Decent sushi.  the fish was fresh and the price point reasonable.  Its a tiny place, so not the best place for girls' night dinner.  It is however a great little place to have a bit of sushi before hitting up south polk.
author: Amanda B.

description: Sushi was fresh, service fast, sake crisp. Friendly owner.
author: Gelena C.

description: nice, relaxed bar atmosphere, very fresh sushi, jazz music, owner couple operated, wish we had that in NYC
author: Stefanowitsch H.

description:
3.25.2006
7:45PM

My girlfriend and I were going to see 300 at 9:30PM, and grab a bite before hand.  Chevy's crossed our minds....Harris's was just up the street....but we spotted this little hole on the way to Harris's.  

I initially thought, "...what a depressing little joint..." and left thinking, " I'm so glad I came in here."  I walk into random restaurants ALL THE TIME....searching for places like this.  

On this Sunday, there were only 2 people sitting at the counter...and later on, just me and my girlfriend.  Tables by the window and about 8 counter seats make up this little restaurant on Van Ness.  

"Healthy Japanese Food" is exactly what the chef serves.  No disgusting spicy sriracha/mayo sauce, minimal deep fried items, and brown rice available upon request.  Minimalist, simple, and refreshing Japanese flavors are highlighted in all of his food.    

I was thinking 4 stars....but everything was just right.  Price point, quality, and service was perfect.  Obviously no fancy decor...just a man and his shop.  

PERFECT.
author: William R.

description:
This is a fantastic sushi restaurant. I went on a Monday night and sat at the bar. The nigiri is the best that I have tasted in San Francisco.

It wasn't too crowded, and it only took about 10 minutes to get our order. I can imagine that on a more crowded night it would take a very long time to get your food though, as there is only one chef and one server.

It's not fancy or flashy - it does exactly what a neighborhood sushi restaurant should do: serve great sushi.
author: Mike D.

description:
decided to check this out based on other yelp reviews, and after last night, it will be one of my top "go-back" joints for sushi.  the fish was very fresh tasting, the rolls aren't huge or enormous, and they substitute brown rice.  I found the taste of the rolls, nigiri, and sashimi to be very good.  we were aiming for a "light" dinner, and this definitely got us exactly what we needed.  

while i haven't found a place in our side of the city that is reasonable and reliable, this is definitely the spot.  it's totally small, probably fits like 15 people max.  the service is a little slow, as there's only the chef + waitress, but its definitely worth the wait, and the waitress is really nice.
author: Jason J.

description:
Mello good sushi.

Nothing too fancy and not a lot of variety, but fresh fish and one - yes, I mean one, honest sushi chef.

I don't know what to say, other than, there is just something completely relaxing about the place - the jazz is flowing, vibe is friendly, service is prompt, affordable, and the owner/chef is just the nicest man.  So, let him hook you up with his selection - you won't regret it.
author: Kiki I.

description:
It's a Saturday night and I've just come home from dinner at Wayo.  The restaurant was very quaint. It looked like it could only fit around 25 people at most.  I counted three tables and stools at the bar which matched the number of chairs on the floor.  By all accounts and past experiences this should have made for a perfect dinner.

And though the food was just as expected - delicious - the service definitely left a bad taste in my mouth.  Reading the rest of the reviews I'm hoping tonight was an off-night service-wise - I'd really like to go back and try them out while they're on their A game.  

In summary:
1.) great food
2.) bad service
3.) hopefully tonight was an anomaly
author: Win R.

description: I just love this place!  Yes, sometimes when there are a lot of people there, the food takes awhile to make, but it's definitely worth the wait.  The fish here is fresh, and not to mention, the sushi chef makes quality sushi.  I eat here a lot and can certainly say that this place is consistent with it's excellent food and service.
author: Jen L.

description:
went for dinner, very excited because of the good reviews. 

so basically things we ordered fell into 2 categories: really really good, and really really mediocre, hence the 3 stars. 

the salmon sashimi is decently priced, 6 pieces for 12 bucks. and it was so good! i'd go back just for that. the seaweed salad was lightly dressed and so good, we ordered 2 lol.

however, the tuna sashimi was very disappointing.... even tho it is what the waitress recommended. and the rock and roll came with old eel in them, which we didnt care for.
author: Danielle A.

description:
Be aware it is possible, if not downright likely, that you will wait 45 minutes for your meal during peak times. And to be fair, they usually warn you when you walk in the door. 
However, if you can deal with that, it is some of the tastiest sushi in the city, at prices far under what I would expect to pay. The man is a purist. Definitely recommend the Snow Leopard roll.
author: J S.

description:
this is a cute place conveniently located near the AMC van ness movie theater (a little pre-cinema snack, shall we?). 

the hot tea was delicious (toasty green tea with a rice-y flavor). the edamame and miso soup were both tasty. 

wayo's biggest draw, for me, was that they offer brown rice in their sushi rolls, which is awesome. but... i ordered a couple of rolls (with brown rice), and they were just OK. the mango shrimp roll sounded delicious, but was kinda bland. also, they put wasabi inside the roll -- i don't like wasabi, so i would have preferred that they leave it out and let me add it myself if i wanted it.  the other roll i ordered was a grilled yellowtail roll -- also kinda bland, and it sounded better than it tasted. 

overall i wasn't blown away by my first dining experience at wayo, but i could probably be convinced to give it another try.
author: Elle B.

description:
Quality. Unpretentious. Intimate. Neighborhood. Best thing around here. Love coming in here at night having some awesome bite a beverage at the bar and having a great night sleep and great next day.
 Gotta love the city.
author: Fabian F.

description: Yelpers were spot on about this place. It's tiny. The sushi chef is also the owner. The special mango rolls were great. We didn't have to wait to get a table, but I got there before 7 pm. Prices were very reasonable, especially in this expensive city! Will definitely go back, for all the right reasons: food, ambience, and good quality for the price.
author: Sam Z.

description: Lovely place, very small, and great quality sushi without any silly trappings or a huge, bizarre roll menu.  The sashimi is so fresh, and the waitress will tell you what is best that day.  I enjoy going here before or after performances in the civic center, and often get seaweed salad, yellowtail sashimi, spicy tuna rolls, and one of their specials (mango was the theme recently). If you want no-frills, quality sushi, I like this place.
author: Katrina K.

description: Super traditional Japanese cuisine. Huge menu. Excellent sake and drinks menu. Karaoke rooms galore. Prices are great. Cooking is well above the average. What else is there? guy below me daniel i think is a child of drinking while pregnant...or is just a plain moron.
author: Michelle N.

description: Small, quaint and simple but fabulous. Had the tako maki and hamachi sashimi and both were delicious.
author: Jenna L.

description:
Definitely scores points for ambience. Like a little neighborhood diner, all cozy and simple and feels like you are truly in someone's dining room. Just one sushi chef and a dear woman doing soup, rice, and tea, on the night we were there. Lots of points for ambience. 

She must have come around the counter to refill our green tea, bearing a giant steaming kettle, 5 or 6 times. 

And price - totally reasonably sushi. The whole bill, with a "large" bottle of warm sake, came to just $45.

The best thing we had - Hamachi (yellowtail) sashimi, something like 6 delicious pieces of fish for just $9.
author: Seth N.

description:
God, I effing love this place.  My love is based on two main things:  The fish is super fresh and delicious (mmmm, sashimi), and two hungry people can stuff themselves with sushi and be hard pressed to spend $30 apiece.  Delicious fresh fish at a very reasonable price?  I'm sold.  The atmosphere isn't anything special, but for a Monday (or Tuesday or Saturday...) night sushi craving, it hits the spot.  I personally enjoy the sashimi and nigiri the most, but the rolls aren't half bad either.  We also triend the green tea ice cream last time we were there.  I'll probably stick to my Ben and Jerry's, but it was fun to try.

As other Yelpers have said, it does get super crowded and therefore slow, so either pick your time carefully or be prepared to wait.
author: Dale M.

description:
Verdict: Good Neighborhood Mom-N-Pop Sushi

My fiance and I tried Wayo after work on Monday, and had a good meal. The ambiance is very cozy and intimate - a great date spot! Since there is only one sushi chef, keep in mind that service is sloooow. Don't come here if you are looking to get a quick meal! The sushi was pretty good - We really enjoyed the Snow Leopard Rolls (yummy sauce!). However, this isn't a restaurant I would go out of my way to get to. Seems like a great place to go if you live in the neighborhood, or if it's on your way home from work. 

Decent prices - $40 for two of us, including tip, appetizers, and three rolls.
author: Nicole C.

description:
Went there last night and thought it was a decent place.  It's right on Van Ness and Bush, where there's a sushi restaurant on almost every block.  Not very identifiable due to lack of eye-catching signage, so look for the Starbucks that's right next to it.  Very small place, has about 3 - 4 tables and the bar, that's about it.  You will probably have better luck getting a table fast on a week night.

The food came slow, and I'm guessing because it's just one chef working there, who basically has to do everything.  The food is pretty good, though not spectacular, but at the price they charge you really couldn't complain --- it's very reasonable.  We tried a bunch of stuff, the highlights for me were the scallops (very tender, sweet and fresh), the amaebi (sweet shrimp), tender and buttery, and the uni was pretty good too.  

The only downside is the limited selection of fish.  I was surprised to find that they didn't have toro, didn't offer a lot of other stuff too like kanpachi (amberjack) or sea bass etc.
author: Jackson Z.

description: Wayo is my favorite neighborhood place to go.   The mango spicy tuna roll is a staple in my diet. Despite it getting busy and there only being one sushi chef they will always let you know howling the wait is for sushi. I highly recommend this place!
author: Stacy M.

description:
I like to think that my husband and I discovered this joint when no one else really knew about it, when we used to live down the block.  We recently stopped by for a visit, after we had not been there in a year, and due to Yelpers, the owner tells us that business has boomed dramatically.  While we were truly happy for him, we were also saddened by the fact that due to increase in customers, we practically had to wait in line. 

Simply stated, the sushi here is consistently fresh (tastes like it's right off a fresh catch!) and very very tasty.  Everyone needs to try it.  It is proof that good sushi need not always come at break the bank prices.
author: Christine L.

description: Underwhelming.  And with other options nearby, don't think I'd ever come again.  The only sushi place we've been to that didn't include shaved radish with the sashimi - wtf?
author: Allison B.

description:
fresh, cheap, prompt service.
not into the american-ized rolls like most places have. wayo has a nice extensive list of nigiri and sashimi at a fair price. they do have your maki's (calif, spider, etc) but the only one we got was the phili (hold the avacado). 
next time i go ill try the sake. will definitely come back.
author: Ryan L.

description: I really like Wayo after my dinner here. I've walked by it dozens of times and have been wanting to try it. First of all, its great for a person like me on a recession budget: we had salmon sashimi, four rolls and 2 beers for $45. Second, the sushi iteself was fresh and tasty and third, the service was very attentive and friendly. Not much more to ask for than that. I will definitely be back!
author: Carolyn K.

description:
This is without a doubt my fav place to dine in the city.  Aside from the ideal location to my apartment (directly below it), I love the food.  
There is nothing fancy on the menu, no real SF inspired rolls, but what they have, they do just right.

The decor is nonexistent, but then again you know you are paying for quality fish, and not overhead.  The place is small and has sort of a diner feel, but its a great way to watch the sushi chef work if you sit at the "U" shaped bar. 

You can't go wrong with the Spicy Tuna Mango Roll, Sake Nigiri, and the Salmon Cream Cheese Roll. approx $17.63 to go.  I would say the highlight for me is the Nigiri, I would put it up against any in the city.  They have a nice Nigiri Chef Special, great presentation, but I have not ordered it (yet).
 
On busy nights I have heard the phone ring and the sushi chef will answer it and say "sorry too busy, no carry out."  But if there is no seat and you don't mind waiting they will always make it for you to go.

There is only one chef and two waitress (although they work on differing nights) so it can be VERY slow on the weekends.  The cozy feel, good company, and some warm sake makes the wait fly by.
author: Brian F.

description: I liked the restaurant's intimate setting (very cute and homely, and you can tell that the place has been around for a long time), and the sushi are very authentic.  It's not fancy but it's good quality sushi at a very reasonable price.  The service was great, not overbearing and very quick.  The chef was really impressive.  He worked very quickly and was pretty much running the show by himself.  It was definitely very interesting to watch him make the sushi.
author: Shirley Z.

description:
I loved everything about Wayo. The sushi chef/owner was so kind and friendly. He even helped the waitress when she was busy by bringing food out to us.The decorations were authentic and beautiful yet simple. Its really a great quiet spot on such a busy street.
So, the first thing we ordered was some squid sashimi. It was the most tender squid Ive eaten, and I was loving it--at the time. (more about this later.) All the fish we got was so fresh, and thick slices of it too. We tried one of the mango rolls on their specials board which was yummmmmy!
A large sapporo bw the two of us, and enough sushi to fill our bellies only ended up costing us 25 each total.  Not bad!
Now for the -1 star:
I think I may have had some kind of reaction to the squid. Pretty much as soon as I ate it, my stomach started hurting with pressure--like gas bubbles. This continued through the night and the next morning. Weird! My friend didnt experience anything like me. I have eaten squid before and never a reaction, so im not sure why now:( 
I will be coming back here soon!
author: ella a.

description: There were 5 people in the restaurant, two waitstaff. Took 10min to get a menu, ordered 2 rolls, got them a half hour later. Sushi about par, so, overpriced. Thats all.
author: Jakob S.

description:
So over the weekend my bf and I came to the conlusion that we would cook more at home. We eat out wayyy too much and we REALLY need to save more money, especially in times like these!

Monday night comes around and we are both really craving sushi. We end up at Wayo, a place we passed by while on our way to BevMo the other day. They have a note on their front door that says they have brown rice for sushi. A few reviews back I made it my mission to find more places offering brown rice sushi. PERFECT! So much for cooking at home.

We were the first customers of the night (went in at 6pm which is when they open for dinner). The little asian lady greeted us warmly and immediately brought us to a table. Tea and water followed. I was really happy when I saw the menu of basic sushi rolls. Sometimes I want really crazy rolls but tonight I just wanted to taste the fish. We ordered:

Rock'n Roll - Sometimes places put too much sauce on this one but Wayo did it perfectly. 
(2) Alaska Roll - I really love avocado and salmon so I had to get two. These were smaller rolls but the fish was still a good size and tasted very fresh. 
Uni Nigiri - SEA URCHIN IS SO GOOD! Don't let the name scare you. It almost reminds me of the insides of a crab shell but creamier and more flavorful. You have to try it. And it's so cheap here, only $5! I've paid way more than that for uni.
Salmon, Cream Cheese, Avocado Roll - This was supposed to come with cucumber but I think the chef forgot. No biggie, just as long as he didn't forget the fish! YUM.
Sea Fairy Roll - My favorite of the night! California roll with scallop on top. I hate to say it but I usually avoid Califorina rolls because the imitaion crab tastes way too fake and creamy but it was amazing here. THEY USE REAL CRAB! And the fresh scallops on top were huge! Most places cut them up so small they don't even look like scallop anymore, NOT here. Served with just a dot of creamy sauce on each piece, you could taste how fresh everything was and how great it all went together. 

We requested that all these rolls be prepared with brown rice. When I was at Homma's Brown Rice Sushi in Palo Alto, they used too much rice vinegar and it ended up tasting too tangy. At Wayo, they didn't use any at all so it was just regular brown rice instead of sushi brown rice. This was my only complaint of the night. 

Though the brown sushi wasn't what I expected, everything else was wonderful. Louis Armstrong playing in the background. Clean and warm environment. Quick service even with two people (the chef and the waitress) working and even after other customers had come in, the lady was still very attentive. They have exellent fish that make up their simple yet flavorful sushi rolls. Lastly affordable prices. Cheapest sushi in the city that doesn't compromise or skimp on anything. I don't remember the last time we spent so little on sushi. I guess it wasn't SO bad that we didn't stay home and cook that night!
author: Julia T.

description: Best sushi in town. Forget those complicated rolls, this plays knows what sushi is supposed to be about.  Simple and delicious and extremely well priced.
author: Brian G.

description: I like Wayo.  It's convenient and reasonably priced.  The sushi tastes good and well made.  Having brown rice as an option is nice, and potentially a bit healthier.  The kitchen is sparkling clean and the staff is friendly.  All good things!  Overall this is a decent sushi place and much better than many mediocre sushi meals I have had... but it doesn't rise to the level of a destination sushi experience as suggested by many of the reviews.  For that there are much better (and more expensive) options. I prefer Ryoko's or Sushi Ino.
author: Seth G.

description:
Great sushi from a "small" (literally and figuratively) establishment . 

Seaweed salad delicious.

Tuna melted in our mouths.

Have to watch your timing as with only the 1 sushi chef you can either hit it right with a seat at the bar or landing one of the 3 tables available.
author: Michael B.

description:
I went there today, it was pretty empty when I arrived but it had started to fill up by the time I left.  I guess because I went pretty early for dinner (as it was my breakfast).

Good prices, and the sushi wasn't bad, but not outstanding in any way.  The nori was a bit chewy, the chef probably should have crisped it up a little more.  It was still tasty though, I ordered more after I finished my first round.  I had some ebi maki (shrimp rolls) and could barely taste the shrimp.  The fish could have been a little fresher and a little more care could have been put into the creation of the items.

I don't mean to harp on all the bad things, sushi is such a simple yet extremely complex food, that its much easier to identify things that are done wrong than praise whats done well.

I left there full and satisfied, it was pretty inexpensive so it was worth the price.  I probably wouldn't go back unless I was really craving sushi and walking down that specific block of van ness.  Personally I'd rather go to Red Box sushi which isn't all that far away, and closer to my apartment - though admittedly slightly more expensive, but its definitely a better value.
author: Dennis M.

description:
Classy and unpretentious. This place is wonderful for an intimate meal with another person or two, or even to spend time alone. It's a mom+pop joint with an old school vibe. Everything is done by a party of 2, who I think are married? The chef makes the meal and the waitress is very attentive to service. Additionally the food is fantastic and the cool jazz music in the background makes it easy for anyone to unwind, open up, and relax here. 

They have a simple menu, though it covers everything you need for a good sushi meal- even including a brown rice substitution! 
My love and I eat here to have an intimate time together, or get it to go and pick  up a starbucks on the way back home. (coffee and sushi? that's city life for ya). It is also conveniently located on the 101. So unless you're entertaining a party of 5+, there is really no reason to not have had a meal at Wayo Sushi.
author: Sara C.

description:
i love everything about this place-- from the hole-in-the-wall location outside, to the ma&pa atmosphere inside-- this place is a real gem. i love that there are less than 10 tables, one waitress, and one sushi chef. they really make you feel like you're at home.
the rolls were nothing short of delicious. the fish was fresh, and the roll selection was fairly large. i especially liked the creativity behind some of the rolls. my particular favorite was the yellowtail & mango roll. it was a combination that really worked for me. the best part was the option of brown rice in any of the rolls! it never occurred to me to use brown rice in sushi, but boy was it good! it adds a totally different flavor to the sushi. delish and a must-try!
the prices were very well priced: ~$5 per roll.
overall, a great place for a date. i would definitely like to revisit.
author: AJ T.

description: If it's fresh sushi you're looking for, you'll be happy here. Run by a Japanese couple -- actually by two Japanese individuals who for all I know may not be otherwise paired -- Wayo doesn't get distracted by the teriyakis, tempura and sukiyaki that many American Japanese restaurants serve. Here it's just sushi and some simple appetizers like hiyayakko, edamame and seaweed salad. Oh, and sake. The restaurant is small, immaculate and tastefully appointed. Apparently it's very busy on Fridays and Saturdays, so I try to go on weeknights. Works for me!
author: Rafa R.

description: EXCELLENT SERVICE.  Small place but cozy, made me want to be on a date.  Sushi was very good.  And I'm not a connoisseur or anything but the ginger and wasabi were the best I've ever had.  They have a lot of mango roll options, and they also give you the option of having your sushi rolled with brown rice- which I tried, but it wasn't my bag.  Support this place!  They are hard-working and the prices are very reasonable.
author: ella j.

description: In business for over 21 years & it is very obvious why. In what seemed like an odd location, it is kinda like diner style seating. The couple who are the only ones who work there are charming, hospitable, and so ultra hard working. The fish was melt in your mouth fresh and delicious. I will definitely be back for more. The spicy tuna salad was my favorite and the sashimi will be on my mind for a long time. The sake was the hugest glass of sake I have ever been served. There is also a brown rice option if you like a little nutrition with your starch.
author: Paulette B.

description: I would love to give Wayo 3.5 stars.  This is what a sushi place should be like, neighborhood-y, small, and not fussy.  There are no sake bombs nor are there crazy sushi rolls named after celebrities.  Go for some nigri and slowly unwind from your day.
author: MJ C.

description: Great sushi, always fresh seafood! The rolls are awesome and especially the brown rice rolls. There's only one waitress and one chef so they might be a little slow to serve you but the wait is definitely worth it. Their "sea fairy" roll is so good...a little bit california roll, topped with fresh scallops. The place is also small so make sure you get there early or are prepared to wait in case it fills up, because it will.
author: Alyssa G.

description: I went here last night for dinner not knowing anything about this place.  We walked in and there were about 4 other tables of Japanese people, so you know it must be authentic Japanese sushi.  It's super CHEAP too.  We each payed $20 (I had a glass of wine and she had a glass of Sake) and had three rolls, Edamame, and the Tuna Tartar + Avocado salad.  The salad was amazing.  The avocado was the freshest I've ever had and the tuna was super flavorful.  THe rolls we had were the yellowtail, the house special, and another roll with BBQ eel.  Delicious. Nothing left, yet it filled us both up. What a hidden gem! My new favorite sushi restaurant.
author: Jenny W.

description: Fish selection is fresh but very limited.  I am turned off by the fish to rice ratio.
author: Wakako U.

description: Great, inexpensive sushi.  Not a place to go if you're in a hurry though.  They only have one chef, so it just takes a little longer than you might be used to.
author: Jonah H.

description: A totally hidden treasure. (Well not really, since it's on a major highway, but I'm always surprised at how few people know about it.) You know, I'm no expert but I really love this place. It's friendly, it's reasonable, the food is always good. I mean, what else do you really need, you picky bastard?
author: Megan W.

description: A no frills neighborhood sushi place. Fresh fish, good service considering the one waitress, family owned and operated (such a cute couple) without the fancy overcompensating rolls. Don't come here with groups, I would say that 4 is the biggest table they have (plus you would be tainting the local vibe). In addition, it is all super reasonable--I rarely spend more than $25 for 2 of us which is a steal for high quality sushi in the city!
author: Rena Z.

description: You want good sushi and a cool place to hang out with some friends... this is the spot! I've been to a handful of Sushi Bars/Restaurants and this place had alot going for it despite it's humble size! The place was very clean and looked great! Of course it was not cheap but it was worth the experience! If you are in the San Francisco area.... a must to go place. Did I mention their delicious selections?
author: C G.

description:
$5 kani-su?! i think i'm in love! did i mention  the chef uses REAL CRAB!?!  as im looking around, i notice the crab and mango roll on the board.  i LOVE crab and mango! so i was curious to try it! but when you combine the two ingredients together....in a roll...ummm....its really not the best of both worlds. but he DID use REAL CRAB! but then again, i dont like it when sushi is too big that it cant even fit in my mouth. not to mention, he DID have alot of  "JIVE ASS ROLLS" on the menu.

the food was good, the service was okay, and i think im in love with the prices. DIRT CHEAP! i had to take away half a star only because i got really sick right after we left the restaurant.   lucky for me there was a bathroom in the walgreens my friends and i went to. but thats a different story. (i was sick for 2 days!) traumitized? uh...yes. did i learn my lesson? no. coming back here? Fo' sho! where else can you find a japanese owned restaurant with cheap ass rolls?! 

3.5 stars.
author: B B.

description: Wayo sushi is such a little gem, I almost feel regretful revealing my secret. It is run by the same guy every night (I think he is the owner/chef) and the fish so fresh! The menu is authentic sushi, no cream cheese-macademia-basil-garlic roles here (although Cali-sushi has its place too). This is a great play to bring your boyfriend/girlfriend because it is so quiet and personal. The last three times I went they were playing really nice jazz: Ray Charles and Billy Holiday, if I recall. The miso is hot and flavorful and the roles are are priced so low for what you get. I went  with a friend and we ordered five roles and two miso's. Our total was under $25! The unagi is fresh and the california role uses real crab. If you are headed to Kyoto's after a workout, consider walking the extra blocks to Wayo. They might not have 99 cent beers, but the sushi is cheaper and way better.
author: Becca A.

description: The spiciest wasabi I've ever had, but it is good!  The sushi is simple (no crazy rolls), but it is done very well.  It is also very reasonably priced.  We had 5 rolls, 1 nigiri and 2 miso soups and it was $40 (not including tip).  It was delicious!
author: Mitzi C.

description: Being from the east coast, and suffering frozen sushi even at expensive Japanese restaurants, this is obviously a 5-star review. However, in San Fran - all the seafood is better, so you then have to start comparing the butter-soft sushi restaurants against each other. This one ranks high, but not the highest. I always suggest going up to the waiter and saying "2 of everything from the specials" when im feeling saucy, but none the less ask him to go bother the chef and have him suggest a plate $40 worth of the different specials. Great dinner!
author: Marc F.

description: I'm lucky enough to work nearby this hidden little gem. It's a pleasant unassuming restaurant with excellent service and fish as fresh as can be. Can't ask for more than that.
author: Lydia F.

description: The sushi here is no better than average. I used to go here all the time because it was super cheap and they have brown rice. They still have brown rice but it's no longer super cheap. They recently raised their prices making it your standard sushi price so I suggest going to somewhere better at the same price. The wait is super long if they have more than 4 tables. They only have one guy making sushi so it makes sense. I've seen the place packed and they tell people sushi will take 1.5 hours or more. People seemed shocked and leave. It's almost commical because I've been in there so many times where they quote people over an hour and the party seems super confused and leaves. Pretty average place, the draw was cheap prices but now that's gone.
author: Andrew M.

description:
This is my favorite sushi joint in San Francisco, mostly for the fact that they are the only place that manages to have good sushi AND good prices.  Everyplace else in the city either has cheap crappy sushi or good expensive sushi or expensive crappy sushi (I'm looking at you Union Square).  I also like the no-nonsense menu.  Its pretty straight forward and easy.  This isn't a line sushi place where there are three or more sushi chefs working, so be patient with the man behind the counter.  
      My one issue with the place is that they need a message on their phone when they aren't open (I order out a lot here).  My big fear is that they will close and I'll be out of luck to find anyplace else with cheap sushi this damn good, so when they don't pick up I panic.
author: Sean B.

description:
wayo is way old school....reminds me of sushi joints before they got all hip and trendy. cheap decent fish, little atmosphere, family run small place with a good amount of seats at the sushi bar. they keep it simple by serving one kind of beer (in two sizes) and one kind of hot and cold sake (also in two sizes). this place has been opened for a long time, so they must be doing something right! 

the fish was all fresh and nice cuts. we ordered our nigiri and maki with brown rice, which is a nice and healthier option if you choose, but i don't recommend it. brown rice really changes the whole flavor and consistency. (i love brown rice alone however).
author: Isabel C.

description:
This place is OK at best.  If I lived in the neighborhood or was close by then its fine, but there's no need to trek around town to come here.  

Sushi is decent, the spicy tuna/mango roll was good and the prices were relatively cheap for sushi at $5 for most rolls, $4 for Nigiri, but the wait was too long since there's only one chef.
author: Golden A.

description: We went here specifically due to the overwhelming number of positive reviews on Yelp. Unfortunately the sushi was mediocre at best. I'd call it a step above Safeway. We both left with stomach aches and even 2 shots of Fernet hasn't made me feel better. Nothing about this sushi was good - not the rice, not the fish, not the shrimp, not the rolls, nothing. If you're looking for some good sushi try Eiji, Warakabune, Sushi Time, Tokyo a GoGo, or Sushi Zone.
author: Shimone S.

description:
they serve simple authentic sushi made by one chef in this tiny place off van ness. 

i've been here at least five times and it's always amazing, and cheap! $5 rolls! $3.50 nigiri! $3 maki rolls!

If you like wacky "crouching tiger explosion extreme godzilla" rolls whilst blaring electro-club hits and dry ice fog surround you then wayo is not your place.
author: amber c.

description: The sushi chef at Wayo is the hardest working guy around. Wayo is my "go to" sushi place -- consistently good with really fresh fish, perfectly chewy rice, and creative rolls.  The Sea Fairy Roll is the best roll that is NOT on the menu. It is on the "specials" menu sitting on the tables. This roll has a fresh scallop on essentially a California Roll with fresh crab and avocados.  Other good rolls are also NOT on the menu -- Spicy Hamachi Mango and Spicy Tuna Mango.  The service can be a bit slow, because it is only one waitress/helper and one sushi-chef.  So, make sure you get your order in quickly, as he makes all the rolls for an order based on the order that he receives the order.  Go and check this place, but not too frequently, as there are only a few tables and bar stools.  I may regret raving about Wayo  on Yelp if a bunch of you end up taking my table at this place.
author: Liz C.

description: The sushi was decent and affordable, but the service was SLOOOOOOW.
author: angela t.

description: Really really good. Prices are very reasonable. The service takes a lil bit but here were only 2 people working there total. So its understandable. Everything was very good. I highly recommend this place if you're in the area.
author: K C.

description: Now I'm no expert in sushi -- in fact I only recently became a convert. And even though that takes away from my credibility, believe me when I say that Wayo is the greatest. The sushi is really fresh, with just the right amount of flavor. My favorite is the dynamite roll, and I always order the miso soup and edamame (I actually crave it). I've even brought true sushi lovers there just to prove I know what I'm talking about (including my cousin from New York, who is so proud that I can now eat nigiri without making a face). Plus the atmosphere is really intimate, with great jazz in the background. My goal is to get the two owners to recognize me since I eat there so much but alas, they only give me a pleasant smile. They must reserve their true gratitude for the patrons who have been showing up for 17 years.
author: Pia S.

description: There are like 4 tables at this restaurant. The sushi here is good, but when I came here with one other person, we were told we could have a table but would have to wait 30 or 40 minutes for food. We waited because I really wanted to try this place, but it was pretty excruciating to sit, hungry, watching other people eat. When we finally got our food, it was good but I wasn't blown away. I do really like that they serve brown rice rolls, though.
author: Mem W.

description: My girlfriend and I come here often when we're nearby for a movie. The sushi is simple yet fresh. Service is excellent. I like the small feel of the place which sets it apart from bigger names like Okoze. The green tea ice cream is also quite nice.
author: Solomon B.

description: This is some of most fresh sushi I have had in SF.  The owner always  has a smile as he prepares your favorite sushi. Highly recomend. If ambiance is real important to you, you may be disappointed.  If you want great food, Wayo is for the place
author: Art S.

description: This is a great sushi restaurant that I found while working in the area.  The sushi chef (maybe owner) is really nice.  I was there last week and he waited on us until the waitress arrived.  The service is consistently pleasant and attentive.  They have a great lunch special (I must confess I haven't tried anything else) with 5 pieces of nigiri and california rolls and they allow you to substitute.  I always get an extra piece of unagi instead of the ebi and my friend always gets the spicy tuna roll instead of the california roll.
author: Jenn M.

description:
Restaurants like Wayo is why I love SF.  There are so many little gems that are yet to be uncovered throughout the city.  (and of course new ones popping up as well)  

When my friend told me to stop by the Japanese rest. over on Van ness and Bush... I gave her a blank look.  I don't remember ever seeing one there.  Wayo is very easy to overlook  overshadowed by the overpowering Starbucks right at the corner.  

The owner and chef Mamoru is a really nice guy, very friendly but quiet.  I guess its been there for about 20 years now!  As they were closing and the other customers left, I had a great view of the traffic running up and down Van Ness while deceptively sheltered by the large glass window parallel to the street.  The light jazz music drowned out what was left of the street noise that made it through my translucent protector.

The nigiri was good, I loved the hamachi, saba and the sake was very fresh.  The mango and yellow tail roll was delicious as well.  The two complimented each other.  

*note that the service is polite and prompt with everything but the food.  It is very slow service, so don't go if you are looking to eat and run.  Plan to soak in the atmosphere.
author: Kevin K.

description: My favorite neighborhood joint for sushi!  Very small--I wouldn't bring more than groups of 4 here.  Very very reasonably priced, very fresh.  Wouldn't pay more for the same kind of rolls elsewhere, unless I'm trying something out of the ordinary. Downside is there's one sushi chef and one woman waiting on all the customers, so plan on spending a bit of time here....
author: Vivian T.

description: I usually got to Wasabi and Ginger but thought I would give Wayo a go. This place has a great selection of sushi and sashimi and boasts a cosy and friendly atmosphere. The fish was very fresh and prices were on par with other middle of the road sushi restaurants. I will definitely be back!!
author: Matt R.

description: I really love a good Japanese cuisine, and im not talking about the fusion kind of japanese food where it has already been mixed with the western culture and Wayo has proven its expectations to me. The place is pretty small, they have a sushi bar that is like a traditional Japanese restaurant. The facility is really clean and the service is great. If you can speak Japanese, they would have like you even better. If you are looking for a tradtional Japanese food, then this is the place to go. They dont really serve don or cooked food but literally nigiri sushi and sashimis. They also have appetizers which is good if you order in case you have too wait quite some time because this is a family business. The Sake with sushi is a perfect combination for an evening dinner. I love the nigiri sushi here, like really love it. Overall, you should definetly check out the place to see why it is really good.
author: Cavin T.

description:
I'm just so happy to see that there are folks out there who know good sushi!  This place is excellent, besides the fact that they try very hard to sidestep the whole "Ace Wasabi" mindset -- no loud music, no obnoxious sounding roll names...just good old fashioned, traditional sushi.  Prices are extremely moderate and the place NEVER fills up (which is a good and a bad...)...

The fish has always been fresh on my visits and I love the fact that the owner / sushi chef will do "omakase" if asked.
author: Hannah H.

description: Yes, the sushi is good, but five stars just for having the brown rice rolls.  For those of us who are gluten-free, this is a guilt-free way to have sushi, and a delicious relief.
author: Elli F.

description: Dude... best place to go for cheap and good quality sushi.  Close to where I live, I go there like every week!  All those other places on Polk.. ok priced, but sucky quality- I can't believe they charge that much for such crappy fish.  Wayo.. they got my back.  Totally check it out if you have cravings for sushi, but wanna save some $$$.  Only drawback, one cook and one server.   Takes some time to get your food, if there's a lot of people.  Generally the wait isn't that long.
author: Young K.

description: I'm pretty stingy with the fifth star, but I think Wayo deserves it.  Here's why: it hits the sweet spot of authentic and flavorful sushi, relaxed jazz-playing ambiance, super-friendly staff, and fantastic value.  This is a rare mix in San Francisco.  What's more, I doubt you'll ever have to wait for a seat.  I wouldn't be sad to have to wait a few minutes, the owners deserve the business.
author: James B.

description:
ok. so after two long months, i was finally able to get my grub on at wayo.  and let me tell you, i literally sprinted home to bump this place up to four stars because outside of the hours mix up on yelp this place is amazing.

i came here at around 630 on a friday and it wasnt packed at all. ordered the miso soup, salmon sashimi, spicy tuna roll and rock n roll (eel and avocado)

the miso soup was delicious. what made this soup was the fact that the green onions were still crisp and the tofu was buttery soft. perfect texture contrast.

the salmon was great. rather large portion for about 9 bucks. and the seaweed salad that came along side of it provided a perfect pop both on the plate and on my palate.  fresh and flavorful. what more can you ask for?

the spicy tuna roll was good. it was not as good as other spicy tuna rolls i have had. there really wasnt that much tuna in it. but for 4 bucks what was i really expecting? nevertheless, even for 4 bucks it wasnt really that great. the nori on the outside kind of fell off as i picked the rolls up as well.

the rock n roll was real tasty. the crispness of the bbq eel played perfectly off the soft texture of the avocado. the flavors also went real well with each other.  all in all it was a solid roll, and again-only four dollars! amazing!

i couldnt even finish everything and for about 25 bucks (with tax and tip) i walked away very full and very happy.

so yea i definitely have to give props where they are due and i really wish that the hours on yelp had not led me to a negative review of this place.  it will stay with me like a scarlet letter of poor review decisions. but  i am glad to say that today i can finally give wayo the review it deserved.
author: Jason B.

description: Terrific Sushi!!!  We have been going for years and it's always fresh, delicious and relaxing.  They have a wonderful variety of amazing Sushi at very reasonable prices.  If you like seeing the same, qualified Sushi Chef, you will adore the Chef at Wayo who is there, morning, noon and night.  He consistently prepares fantastic Sushi which always makes for a pleasurable experience.  Enjoy.
author: Kara B.

description: My husband and I slip into this place when we want non-scene sushi.  A cozy hidden gem.   The sashimi is fresh and tasty.   If you want snappy service, you'd be better off going to one of those sushi joints with the boats going around.
author: Ynez C.

description: Super traditional Japanese cuisine. Huge menu. Excellent sake and drinks menu. Karaoke rooms galore. Prices are great. Cooking is well above the average. What else is there?
author: Peter C.

description:
love it.
love the brown rice sushi.
the adorable couple running the joint.
the fact that they kept filling up my tea cup long after the open sign had flipped to closed.
the fact that she said, "wow thas a lotta food!" and we couldn't finish it. 
and that I stepped off of the terrors of van ness into the coziness of wayo.
author: Jeremi M.

description: NEWEST BIG FAN RIGHT HERE.  Sushi rolls for $5 each + good conversation = awesome dinner.  Glad I faced the rain to make it out!
author: Lindsay T.

description: I come here to eat dinner often alone. The last time I did I sat down at the bar and noticed I had 20 extra dollars in my wallet! Thank you luck dragon! 5 stars.
author: Cameron Scott C.

description: Top shelf. Great appetizers, fantastic seafood, and a simple, clean atmosphere. I'll definitely be back.
author: Eric S.

description: This place really hits the spot.  Great sushi (small Japanese size, not giant ham fist size) and interesting, tasty apps.  And the price is definitely right.  As compared to a chic, overpriced place like Typhoon (or is Tsunami or Hurricane?  Whatever), it's similar quality sushi at 1/3 the price.  If you're not on a date and just want great sushi, save your wallet and come here.  Come early though, it fills up fast.
author: Patrick Z.

description: This place literally looks like you stepped into the kitchen of a SF townhouse.  The whole restaurant is an open space house kitchen with the 'counter' being the sushi bar and about 5-6 small tables surrounding it.  1 Sushi chef makes very well priced rolls and good-sized, fresh nigiri as the 1-2 waitresses (maybe his daughters?) serve it.  Great change of pace to have an intimate, cozy setting with good priced sushi.  Thanks Yelp, this place deserves the good reviews.
author: Jenny L.

description: Another overly hyped Yelp situation - folks, I just don't get it! The fish was seriously nothing to write home about, and it was all precut. No atmosphere whatsoever. Zero service. The only reason I'd come here is say I lived two doors down, and wanted to grab cheap sushi to go. That's about it.
author: Sarah R.

description: We thought we'd try this place out based on Yelp reviews.  Bad idea.  The fish wasn't great.  It's no different than a sushi boat restaurant.  Pre-cut fish is not ok.  It tastes dry and makes the texture mealy.  The uni here was horrendous, bitter, slimy.  No creativty in the menu, not fresh.  It's not cheap enough to justify the mediocrity and I have no desire to go back.  Yelpers let me down on this one.
author: M M.

description:
who said healthy food can't taste good? they obviously haven't had brown rice sushi from wayo. 

teeny tiny wayo lets you swap out the rice in any of their rolls with brown rice. and its not the grainy, sand-like brown rice but the good stuff. and you might wonder if it makes the sushi taste weird, but surprisingly,it doesn't because the fish is fresh and the combos are delish. (there are basic rolls and then a few with mango. mmm!)

to enjoy wayo, you must love sushi (they don't have much else) and you have to be patient. there are only two employees - the waitress and the sushi chef - so what they lack in speed, you get in a very quaint, family-feel. wayo is a great find. thanks yelpers!
author: eileen b.

description: This is my favorite place in the neighborhood to grab fresh, delicious rolls and sashimi. The chef concentrates on the basics. The atmosphere is warm and relaxed, a great place to hunker down with your fish and sake!
author: Sahra H.

description:
This place has really simple sushi. Nothing too fancy except maybve for their mango rolls. Their shrimp tempura rolls are soo good and they're only $5!! so cheap... Been wanting to eat here for a while and finally decided that I did. My first dish was the snow leopard roll I didn't like it at all it tasted funny to me. The spicy tuna roll is o so good. Even the bf liked it b/c it wasn't spicy.

I would eat here here again if I wanted something simple
author: Crum B.

description: This place is decent, reasonably priced and close to the Van Ness movie theater for a post movie bite. DO NOT go to Kyoto. I give the albacore tuna roll with ponzu sauce a whole star all its own. Wow. Yum. Yum. Yum.
author: Jackie B.

description: A great little place in my hood. Everything is very fresh and delicious! Menu is pretty basic, but they offer some really good, creative specials up on the wall. It is usually packed on weekends, so I suggest going earlier in the week so you don't have have to wait, as it IS small - maybe 4 tables and some seating at the sushi bar. And there's only the owner and his wife running the place as mentioned in the previous reviews. Very gracious hosts and a great experience overall.
author: Barbara K.

description: Favorite neighborhood sushi place - great cozy atmosphere, sashimi was good but would recommend the rolls and salads. They were something special. This has become our go-to spot for sushi.
author: Mel C.

description: This review has been long overdue. I believe I was introduced to Wayo back in 2006 when I worked near by.  Out of the numerous sushi restaurants on Van Ness including the ones in close-by Japantown--this is by far the best choice for fresh and affordable sushi--yes, fresher than even most of the sushi spots in "JAPAN"town.  This is the only sushi spot I'd order the Rainbow Roll from!  Their menu offers a small selection of simple but delicious and FRESH sushi rolls and plenty of sashimi choices.  They also have a few simple donburi's--I like the shrimp tempura one best.  The sauce they use for the donburi's is awesome and perfect over steamed rice--so awesome that you don't even need much meat or sides to enjoy the dish with.  They also always have a list of specials up on the wall.  The service can be a bit slow since there's only 1 sushi chef working and 1 waitress.  I believe they may be a wife/husband team.  The wait however is totally worth it.  The restaurant is super small and intimate--probably could seat ~20 people maximum.   If you like a small, casual setting, simple but delicious Japanese food, and of course, REALLY fresh fish then you've got to try Wayo!
author: Ivy Z.

description: This place was GREAT. If you are looking for an authentic sushi experience that is moderately priced, but still tastes great go to Wayo. There are only two employees - the chef and his assistant (I assumed they were the couple that owned the place) so if you go on a weekend, you may have to wait for a bit for your sushi. But they kindly warn you advance. I didn't mind the wait - in fact, it was a great long dinner date. Try them soon!
author: Jenica M.

description: Love this place! It's only 2 blocks from where I live so we frequent it a lot. The sushi chef and waitress are the nicest people ever. Their mango rolls are fantastic! Yes, service is slow, but it's worth the wait! Everything is cheap and yummy. I highly recommend this place.
author: J K L.

description: I would give this place more like a 3.5 so I rounded up. It's run by a single man on slow days and he's helped by someone when it's busy. Not really veggie/vegan friendly unless you like shitake maki or sushi with just avocado. If you're not either, than you'll like this place perhaps because it's cheap? It's a long wait so expect to have some good conversation with whoever you dine with. I personally wouldn't come back because there's not much I can eat but feel free to test out these waters if you're an avid diner of sushi restaurants.
author: Lauren L.

description: Great for low-key sushi. I always see the same people working there, and the waitress keeps the green tea coming... The rolls aren't very inventive. I know, I know - it doesn't have to be crazy for it to be good. But still. All in all, 4-star sushi. Yippee!
author: Krissy D.

description:
Pretty good, cozy, friendly atmosphere.  

Thursday nights after work hours isn't that bad.  People start trickling in by 7pm.  

Try their specials..they're good.  Not such a fan of the "brown rice" sushi, but I had to try it.  It was just aight for me.  Other than that..the sushi is pretty good for the prices.
author: Minnie M.

description:
Damn good!

Here's why:
-High quality fish
-No frills, no BS
-Cheap
-Cold beer and sake
-Husband and wife team, who clearly take pride in their work

Eat it!
author: J S.

description: Wayo is a wicked little hole-in-the-wall sushi joint on Van Ness that has never disappointed my friends and I. I was introduced to Wayo about 6 months ago when a friend recommended I go there for the spicy tuna salad. It's amazing, by the way! What I love about Wayo is that the fish is so fresh (not like some other places I've been!) and, although the selection of rolls is limited to the traditional favorites like spicy tuna, dynamite, and avocado, they are among the tastiest I've ever had. Be sure to try some miso soup, the seaweed salad and, if they still have it, the mango salmon roll--amazing! While there's only one sushi chef for the restaurant, he is very meticulous and obviously knows what he's doing. I've never had a roll fall apart on me yet! I would recommend this place to students or young professionals because it's so reasonably priced and relaxed. A great place for a first date too!
author: Eileen S.

description: this is a good neighborhood sushi place.  reasonable prices and good food.  what more do you want on a school night and are too lazy to trekk far from the hood.....
author: Mao K.

description: Okay, I admit I am a bitch!  Not just for food, but about everything; especially food.  My favorite has been Sushi, and I have four Black and Japanese brothers, so sushi has always been a mainstay.  However, there is only one place that I truly love for the best sushi in this city, and it is found here, at Wayo Sushi.  My first date with my true love was held at the table in the corner, over sushi.  The fish and all offerings are fresh daily, and once we were invited in to wait until the delivery of fresh fish arrived.  It came fifteen minutes after we were there, and we waited for the Sushi Chef to cut and prepare the offerings, before we ordered.  I do mean fresh!!!  I could eat here daily, but my finances won't allow it, though there prices are reasonable.  They have many great offerings, but the best is anything made with the brown rice instead of white.  I have never been a brown rice fan, but this is one of the only places that I eat it and love it.  For those who can't have high sodium, they even have a low sodium soy sauce offering.  The Chef's Special is great, and so is their green tea ice cream, and sake.  I love the miso soup, and his wife works with him during lunch when she is not in Japan, and he has a wonderful assistant at night during the dinner shift.  It is small, but it is absolutely the best sushi place in San Francisco!!!  Oh!  There is no imitation crab, or anything else unreal on the premises!!!  You will not be disappointed ever!!!  Tell them Veronika sent you!!!
author: Veronika F.

description: A hidden enclave off the expansive cement artery of SF otherwise known as Van Ness.  Cant say enough about the Value of this place.  Fresh.  Innovative without being over-the-top.  Try their catepillar roll..velvet avocado and BBQ eel that melts, literally.  They do brown rice justice by deleting any crunch to it.  A close second to Moki's and Much Much more affordable.  In fact, I hope you cultivate resistance to this review and dont go.  More for me..
author: Jen L.

description: Wayo is a great place to relax and have some good sushi.  Don't expect this place to be high on frills but somewhere you can get good sushi at a reasonable price. The place is pretty small so the wait can get long, around 40-45 minutes for sushi.  But... they do have a magazine rack there if you ever get bored.  If you're in the area, make sure to check out this place.
author: Michelle A.

description:
Very reasonably priced decent quality sushi!

The Nigiri and Sashimi are really good - the unagi nigiri and shiro maguro sashimi were by far my favorites. Salmon nigiri and hamachi sashimi were just ok. My friends seemed to enjoy the maki, but I am more of a really want to taste the fish person myself. 

The ocha was nothing to write home about - but not too bad either!
author: Nors P.

description: I've walked/driven by this place a million times yet I never actually noticed Wayo since it's such a cute hole in the wall.  I had the sashimi here and everything was so fresh!  The servers were actual japanese - which is rare these days.  I really liked it and will definitely come back!
author: Cristina L.

description: We liked this place.  Yes there was a 30-40 minute wait to get our food and yes, there's just one guy making the Sushi, but after a somewhat disappointing sushi experience up the road at Sanraku, this made up for it.  We sat right at the bar and watched the guy (who I'm assuming is the owner -- Mamoru) prepare our sushi, and it was quite obvious that he's got some skills.  Everything was tasty, the complementary green tea was nice, and my girlfriend and I got four rolls for $18.  Can't beat that!
author: Matt G.

description:
best. sushi. ever.
small menu w/o a bunch of special rolls stuffed with the whole ocean and glammed up with spicy mayo or ponzu or whatev. just simple, tasty fish. if fish mated with butter and their offspring mated with an angel, and that offspring ate something really delicious and nutty before getting served up on a plate, it would probably taste like wayo's albacore sashimi. so so so good. the place is tiny and food comes slow, but the service was excellent and the cucumber in the side salad was so fresh i bet they have a garden hiding behind the counter.
for the fantastic quality, it was not expensive at all.
author: Dana D.

description: Please Yelpers - please stop giving this place good reviews. If you honestly think its good please just stop reviewing. Please. First, I am not picky. Second, the food is "ok". I dont dislike it. Its fine. Not great. Just ok. And the old dude that runs it seems like a nice cute old man. And the woman (wife or daughter?) seems nice enough. That said, they are the most incompetent business owners in SF. Went there the first time - 4 other patrons - 45 mins for food. 45. Do the math. The second time I showed up there were 2 other tables with people - the lady told me "between 30-50 mins" to eat. No joke. Been there 5 or six times with same experience - a basically empty restaurant and this vapid lady telling us we'd have to wait 45 mins. Weird.  This place is ridiculous. I am not writing because of "one" experience - this is based on a dozen times going there and other reviewers agree. The people who run it are ... as I've said ... nice. But they are incompetent and should be shut down. Period. Giving them good reviews just encourages mediocre businesses. If the food was ridiculously exceptional - I'd get ut. It isnt.
author: Dirk G.

description:
Hidden gem.  Totally randomly walked in and $5 rolls by 1 (just 1!) authentic sushi chef, quaint atmosphere and fresh fish (real crab meat in the rolls, and spicy mango yellowtail rolls make ya mouth wata) make this an all around good time.

I'm going for dinner!
author: Hope N.

description:
still have a love affair with wayo, though it gets more and more crowded by the second. i really need to stop introducing people to it.

standard order:
saba (just the right amount of fat in it for it to melt into your tongue)
amaebi (no fried head, sorry!)
uni (always fresh and unbelievably good)
sake (sometimes hit or miss... they won't always give you the yummy belly portion)
hamachi (soft and oh! so delicious)
shiro maguro (consistently good)
snow leopard roll(california roll topped with fresh scallops and japanese mayo-- rich and delicious)

yes, all for one person. deal with it!

love you, mamoru!
author: Kerry N.

description:
wayo sushi is two things i really like:
cheap +2
brown rice +2

fish was good from what i could tell but i'd like to go back to confirm for sure by getting sashimi ...the pieces weren't that huge.

i got three different sushi (mango & salmon; a tuna special; rock n'roll maki) and the tastiest was the most cheap ($4 i think) -- rock n'roll. just order lots of maki & you'll probably be pretty happy and not too poor.
author: Sasha L.

description: Very fresh fish, non-traditional ingredients, and a cozy atmosphere. Could be crowded on a friday or a saturday evening.
author: Margarita B.

description: This is easily one of the top 10 sushi restaurants in SF.  I say top 10 because I haven't been to EVERY sushi restaurant in SF....that would take years and maybe $100,000. But Wayo is top tier because the Ikura (salmon eggs) are always super fresh. Fresh Ikura is the hallmark or great sushi. Trust me on this folks.
author: Will R.

description: This is the best place in the city for sushi. On weekends, there can be up to a 45 minute wait for food - but believe me when I say it's worth it. Everything is rolled by hand on a bamboo mat, and everything is delicious and amazing. No frills, no fancy decorations, just the best sushi at an affordable price.
author: Jay F.

description:
I love this place!!!!  Very quiet and cozy atmoshphere.  Sometimes the wait can be awhile since there is only one guy making the sushi, but it is worth the wait!!!  Very small place, only seats maybe 15, so if you are in a hurry I recommend getting there when they open.  The sushi is the best I have had in the city!!  The price is pretty reasonable too.

VERY GOOD!!!!
author: Kristi F.

description:
Whenever anyone asks me what the best sushi in town is (and, granted, that's only happend twice), I think long and hard and can't find any better than Wayo.   They don't have a huge menu, but with fish this fresh and a chef this good, they don't need one.  Very reasonably priced and fantastic service.

Not really recommended for more than 2 people because the dining room is very small.
author: Kris E.

description: This is a lovely, tiny business with great sushi - consistent, fresh. It was my fave "neighborhood joint". My only complaint is that the selection tends to be limited and they dont' change their specials (in the MANY years I lived in the neighbhorhood, the specials board never changed! it was also mango with x, y, or z). The sushi chef and waitress - and there is only one- really take pride in their work. highly recommended.
author: Monica K.

description: A couple, mid week late evening, after work wanted to grab 2-3 rolls for a light dinner either sit in or to go. We came in and the place was not full at all.
