They told us it will take an hour for 2 rolls. We said we would take it to go they answered that it will still take an hour. Since we live close by we asked for a phone number so next time we would order in advance- they replied that they don't answer the phone. I guess they don't really want our business or that there are enough people in SF who are willing to wait for an hour for 2 rolls of sushi. We will not try again.
author: Ronnie P.

description: excellent! fairly priced, good quality fish. nice quaint place. menu avoided those excessively filled rolles. i hight reccomend looking at the specials on the wall, the mango and salmon was our favorite. will defintitly return.
author: Solstice B.

description: Great inexpensive sushi.  The wait may be a while since there is only the owner who is making the sushi.  But, it's a well worth it, especially if you're in good company and aren't in any rush to enjoy a beer while waiting.
author: J.A. T.

description: one of the best sushi places in SF a true gem - I go once a week!
author: Rachel C.

description: Sushi is about the fish. Specifically, its about the freshness of the fish. Thus far, Wayo has some of the freshest fish of all the sushi places I've been to in SF. Admittedly I haven't been to every sushi joint in the city (read: I only go to cheapo sushi locations), but I'm fairly certain Wayo has the best freshness:affordability ratio. Sushi restaurants fall under two categories. "Hip" sushi bars that specialize in a thousand varieties of silly named rolls (Barrel Roll, Lead Roll, Look-at-me-I'm-on-a-Roll), that are usually drowned in mayonnaise and then deep-fried and "traditional" Japanese restaurants that make you feel like committing hari-kiri for keeping your shoes on during dinner. Wayo is neither. It's a down to earth eatery that serves honest food by  a committed chef. The slices of fish on the nigiri are extremely generous and his rolls are simple and flavorful. And if you're lucky, you'll get to see the World's Biggest Teapot lugged around by a very tiny woman.
author: Raymond P.

description: I've been going to Wayo for about 10 years now and it's just about the only sushi restaurant I will go to in SF.  We used to go to Kyoto if Wayo was already closed but the quality of Kyoto's sushi made us give up that habit.  Wayo puts Kyoto's crap to shame.  The sushi is always extremely fresh - one of the few places I feel comfortable eating sashimi.  They do not have a ton of "special" rolls, just basic good sushi.  I've been working my way through the salads over time - all have been fantastic (cucumber salad with octopus, spicy tuna and avocado salad, crab and mango salad to name a few).  The atmosphere is quiet with soft jazz playing and the chef has a very sweet energy and is very good at what he does.  His presentations are almost food art.  For having to pay Van Ness rent the sushi is very affordable.  We always feast for about $20 a person including a beer or some sake.  This is the perfect place to take an out of town guest who can't get sushi where they live, without all the noise and sketchy service of a place like Sushi Rock.  One note, this is a "mom and pop" sushi bar with 3 tables and a few seats at the bar.  If you go at a busy time be prepared for a wait...but hang out, order some edamame and a beer, watch the artist at work and relax.  It's TOTALLY worth it!!
author: Jon B.

description: i cant tell you how much i fell in love with this place. great service, a  cool, relaxing ambiance (chef was playing jazz), and some great sushi that you might as well be stealing from the owners (the lady and i had 5 rolls and it was less than 40 dollars!)! lets start with the service. this sushi bar was literally a one man show. the owner was the greeter, waiter, chef, and the bus. so you know everything had to be on point. all the sushi looked fresh. and if you haven't tried one of their mango shrimp rolls, try one and it'll change your life! the reasoning behind the 4 stars was just the wait time. like i said, its a one man wrecking crew in there but i wont complain. he looked like he loved his gig and that's what i like to see. the presentation was nice, looked like the rolls were made with love. so trust me, the wait is worth it. i will most definitely come back to this spot.
author: erick m.

description: Good sushi!  Small inside.  I was surprised that there weren't very many people when I went on a Friday night, although it was raining.  Overall it was a good experience.
author: Leslie R.

description: my yelp homies have failed me on this spot~this place is kinda weak,,,watered down....not alot on the menu...only thing goin for this place is the location & price....dont let the pics fool u....
author: elmer d.

description: I almost don't want to Yelp about this wonderful secret spot.  It has authentic simple sushi, huge slices of fresh fish.  You have the option of white or brown rice.  It's a cozy little place with one sushi chef.  Ask the chef what he recommends, he won't let you down.
author: Ashley Q.

description: This place has only one sushi chef but they usually warn you if the wait is going to be super-long.  The first time i went in there, they told us it'd be 45 minutes later. I was intrigued that so many people were in this little restaurant on Van Ness so went back a couple of weeks later.  No wait and the sushi was superfresh!  The hamachi sashimi was the best.  The salmon in the cream cheese roll was good, but no very big pieces of salmon.  The hot tea was really good too.  Definitiely would go back!
author: CM C.

description: Best brown rice sushi in San Francisco! I've been coming to this Sushi restaurant for 20 years!!! and it's still my favorite. The prices are on the inexpensive side. They offer low-sodium soy sauce on request. Request it! When it's real busy the food can come slow; your patience will be rewarded. Warning, once you do brown rice sushi, it's hard to go back to white rice.
author: Joe B.

description: I dont really understand some of the great reviews about this place. The food is fairly inexpensive but i think you can find better sushi places for the price. The service took a really long time to get my order and then to get the sushi. When I got it I didn't think it was anything too special...
author: Michael P.

description: a friend and i had our inaugural meal in the most recent visit to SFO this weekend. it was right accross my hotel [holiday inn]. in a cozy space consisting of a central bar seating and 4 tables. it is staffed by a couple: a very efficient waitress and an equally industrious sushi maker of a gentleman. upon seating, we were infromed that sushi orders would take about 45 minutes. which was fine. that is why god made the large sized kirin beers! there were about 4 other couples seated around the bar in various states of finishedness... and in time our ice cold beers arrived along with a miso soup for my friend and a cold tofu appetizer for me.
author: Suburban R.

description: the best part about this place it that it is unpretentious. the owner is the only sushi chef and he will remember the little things that you like even if he doesn't ever ask your name. he always brings out the low sodium soy sauce and brings me extra ginger with out me asking!! now that's good customer service. AND the edamame is ALWAYS fresh. they make it per order in a real steamer so it comes to you literally steaming and freshly salted. somtimes it's too hot to eat! AND he keeps good magazines right by the door so if you want to come alone, you don't have to bring your own reading material! i just love this place.
author: stephanie g.

description: Wayo Sushi had the neighborhood sushi bar feel which I absoltely love! I wouldnt suggest myself and 5 of my closest girl friends go there to go sake bombing but if I was relaxing around my apartment, which is upstairs from Wayo, it would definetely be my first choice of a place to go for dinner. Their service is speedy considering there is only a sushi chef and a waitress that work there. It's not group friendly because it is so small and it looks out onto the street so no matter where you are in the restarurant, you can see and been seen by everyone. That being said, the fresh mango and spicy tuna roll is to die for! It's worth every bit of the minimal price they charge here!
author: Sarah I.

description: the shitake in my shitake maki was too sweet. the tea was good and settled my hungover tummy.
author: gertie s.

description: wayo is in the strangest place - on van ness right across the street and up a block from the movie theater.  good sushi at a decent price and the couple that works there are very nice people and give great service.
author: michelle k.

description: Very reasonably priced sushi.  Fish is fresh, and the sake is... alcoholic.  Service is a little bit slow when it gets busy, but I would definitely choose this over Wasabi & Ginger or Nara.  For those of you thinking about going here with non-sushi eaters, they only have sushi - no teriyaki or katsu.
author: Ian C.

description: my go-to sushi spot, since it's just down the block from me.  the food is cheap, the fish is fresh.  there are only two employees, though - the chef and the waitress, so it can get slow.  also, they never pick up their phone, so i have to actually go there and wait if i want carryout.  still, i haven't found a better deal, in terms of comparing price to quality.
author: Cindy M.

description: This is the best sushi that I've had this part of town.  We came on a Saturday night and the place was surprisingly empty and we were seated right away.  Reasonable prices, friendly staff, and fresh fish definitely make this a place worth checking out if you are in the area and in the mood for some sushi.
author: Mike D.

description: Fresh, cheap and healthy. That combination gets it four stars. I wouldn't say the sushi is the most flavorful, and the loosely made rolls don't hold together well. But for day-to-day sushi, all I want is fresh, cheap and healthy. The place is also super clean, the atmosphere is peaceful, and the staff is very attentive.
author: Midori S.

description: If it was just a grading of the service, I would give our wonderful server five stars without reservation.  Hower, the food really only rates about two stars, so three stars it is combined.  This is a place to avoid the few choices for nigiri sushi and concentrate mostly on rolls.  There were not any fresh fish choices and the saba nigiri was so soft and fishy that I am honestly worried about waking up in the morning with a bowel problem (unchi bakahatsu).  However, the hotate nigiri was the exception to the rule and was actualy quite nice.
author: Richard P.

description: A hidden gem of a sushi restaurant, with very friendly service and great fish.
author: Claudia G.

description: Been in the bay area for 2 years now with my girlfriend looking for some good sushi. I'm from hawaii and the sushi there is always fresh and good. took me a few times to find a great here, but finally found it at last. The sushi here is affordable, nicely presented, fresh and EXTREMELY GOOD. The owner/chef is also a very nice man and said that hes been here for 18 years! I am so happy that we FINALLY found a great place for sushi. this is the only place ill go to get sushi in the bay now. period. most rolls are about 5 dollars, depending on your appetite you can probably get a lunch/dinner for 2 for 25-40. only thing is, if its crowded it may take while to get your food, but at least its FRESH! enjoy!
author: scott b.

description: Excellent sushi.  The fish is fresh, the preparation is excellent and the service friendly.   On the more affordable side for sushi (we came in starving and left with a bill for 73$ for two, after a huge meal and a reasonable amount of sake).  The Uni (sea urchin) and salmon were particularly good, especially for the price.  I'd believe that the service could be slow, but we found it fast arriving right after they opened at 6 on saturday (it had started to fill up as we were leaving).
author: David O.

description: If you expect sushi extravaganza, don't count on this place.  This is a one-man standard sushi selection, simple place.  It stands out with the special sushi/with/mango menu, large cold sake glasses, and optional brown rice sushi.
author: Anastasia V.

description: Local, friendly, delicious, fresh, good prices.  Everything you can ask for in a sushi place.  Perfect.
author: Greg D.

description: Amazing!  It is great to sit at the bar and watch the chef work.  Its not super-fast but service is friendly and you know you are getting something fresh when you see it being made.  Great low key atmosphere and VERY reasonable prices.  I will be back next week for sure.
author: Emily C.

description: One of my favorite Sushi Restaurants.  It's a great place without trying too hard.  Delicious, reasonably priced sushi. I love coming here.
author: Robin T.

description: I would give this place a 4 1/2 but I'll round up since my friend really liked it. I'm not a huge sushi fan but my friend is and I'm basing it solely on their non-raw fish options (yeah, I know, who goes to eat sushi and don't get raw fish, right?). So, I got their California Roll and New York Roll, both were very good in my opinion although I'll probably get their Snow Leopard Roll as well on top of those two since it sounded interesting. Their non-raw fish options are limited, so if you're going to be bringing someone who doesn't like it, I would recommend them getting the California Roll and New York Roll (not sure if Snow Leopard Roll is cooked, or at least cooked all the way through). If you're a sushi fan, I would recommend it, albeit not from personal experience, since my friend is a huge fan and have tried it both here in San Francisco and Japan. It is also rather inexpensive when it comes to sushi as well, so I highly recommend this place for both quality and price. The atmosphere is nice, although a bit small. There's a bar/counter that can seat about 15 people and 3-4 tables that can seat 2 people. The one night I did go there though, it wasn't crowded at all and the wait time wasn't that long. It took about 30 minutes (maybe a little less) for our food to be served when they weren't busy. As many others have stated, it is only one chef and one waitress working, so I'm not complaining. I definitely look forward to coming back.
author: Richard C.

description: great sushi place. always good quality.  easily one of the top five places in the city
author: debbie s.

description: my favorite sushi in sf, period.  the place is small, simple and purely minimilist.  nothing fancy here, but great care is taken to prepare ultra fresh high grade fish.
author: Greg J.
